CAVEAT
In this compilation of this City Code, Sterling Codifiers, Inc., was given the
authority by the City of Taylorville to use a supplemented copy of the City's
1979 Code which contained various ordinance amendments. Sterling Codifiers is
not responsible for the accuracy of those amendments as they appeared in the
supplemented 1979 Code copy. Therefore, this City Code contains those
provisions from said supplemented 1979 Code, which provisions are cited as
(1979 Code Ch.    , Art.    , §    ), and appropriate ordinances passed prior
and subsequent thereto.
PREFACE
         This code of the City of Taylorville, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 4303, passed 4-7-2025. Ordinances of
the City adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to
the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code
has been amended, superseded or repealed.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 2492
   ORDINANCE ADOPTING TAYLORVILLE CITY CODE OF 1993
   WHEREAS, the CITY OF TAYLORVILLE is desirous of adopting a new Taylorville
City Code, and
   WHEREAS, the CITY OF TAYLORVILLE has compiled a new codification of
ordinances to be published in book form, published by authority of the City
Council of the City of Taylorville, Illinois, now therefore,
   BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF TAYLORVILLE, ILLINOIS:
   SECTION 1. The City of Taylorville does hereby approve and adopt the
TAYLORVILLE CITY CODE OF 1993.
   SECTION 2. Said TAYLORVILLE CITY CODE OF 1993 shall be published in book
form, published by authority of the City Council of the City of Taylorville.
   SECTION 3. This Ordinance adopting the TAYLORVILLE CITY CODE OF 1993 shall
take effect and be in force from and after its passage and publication in book
form as provided by statute.
   SECTION 4. The TAYLORVILLE CITY CODE OF 1993, printed in book form, and
published by authority of the corporate authorities of the City of Taylorville,
shall be prima facie evidence of the contents, passage, and legal publication
of such ordinances, as of the date mentioned in such book, in all courts and
administrative tribunals.
   SECTION 5. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
its passage and approval according to law.
   PASSED AND APPROVED this 15th day of March, A.D. 1993 by a roll call vote of
8  in favor and  0  opposed.
Voting in favor: Aldermen Barding, Brown, Mathon, Passoni, Scott, Servi,
Wright, and Zeitler
Voting against: None

TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL MUNICIPAL CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-5: Copies of Code
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the City Council, this City Code is hereby declared to be
and shall hereafter constitute the official Code of the City. This City Code of
ordinances shall be known and cited as the TAYLORVILLE CITY CODE, and it is
hereby published by authority of the Council and shall be kept up to date as
provided in Section
1-1-3 of this Chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this City Code by title in any legal documents. (1993 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The City Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
State as the ordinances of the City of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in Section
1-2-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
   A.   General Requirements: Any ordinance amending the City Code shall set
forth the title, chapter and section number of the section or sections to be
amended, and this shall constitute sufficient compliance with any statutory
requirement pertaining to the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of
this City Code. All such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be
immediately forwarded to the codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall
be prepared for insertion in its proper place in each copy of this City Code.
Each such replacement page shall be properly identified and shall be inserted
in each individual copy of the City Code. (1993 Code)
   B.   Penalty Clauses: In case of amendment of any section of this Code
containing the provisions for which a penalty is provided in another section,
the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the
amended section or the amending section, whether re-enacted in the amendatory
ordinance or not, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. (1979
Code Ch. 25, Art. II, §2)
   C.   Recording Amendments: It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to keep at
least one copy of the Municipal Code which shall be marked in the following
manner: Whenever any ordinance which amends or makes an addition to the Code is
passed and approved, the City Clerk shall note on the margin of the section or
sections amended that such amendment has been made, where the amendment may be
found and, in the case of an addition, shall mark in the appropriate place a
notation that such addition has been made, with a similar reference to the
aforementioned amendment book.
The City Clerk shall also keep a separate book containing every amendment or
addition passed to this Code, with a reference on each copy of such amendment
or addition as to the place in the record of ordinances where the original
reference may be found. (1979 Code Ch. 25, Art. II, §3)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this City Code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages may
be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by the
City Council. The City Clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly
inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the Clerk. 1  Any
person having in his custody an official copy of the City Code shall make every
effort to maintain said Code in an up-to-date and efficient manner. He shall
see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such are
delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the City Clerk.
Said Code books, while in actual possession of officials and other interested
persons, shall be and remain the property of the City and shall be returned to
the office of the Clerk when directed to do so by order of the City Council.
(1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  1-1-3C of this Chapter.
1-1-5: COPIES OF CODE:
   A.   Distribution of Copies: All of the printed copies of this Code
belonging to the City shall be deposited with the Clerk, and he shall deliver
one copy thereof to the Mayor and each Alderman and copies to such other
persons as the City Council may direct. (1979 Code Ch. 25, Art. III, §2)
   B.   Presentation of Copies: The Mayor or Council shall have the power to
extend or reciprocate courtesies of other municipalities by presenting them
with a copy of this Code, bound at the expense of this City, as to them shall
seem suitable, and they shall also have the power to present two (2) copies of
this Code to the Illinois Municipal League. (1979 Code Ch. 25, Art. III, §3)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the City passed prior to the adoption of this City
Code are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being still
in force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject
to the saving clauses contained in the following sections), from which are
excluded the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy
ordinances; appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and
annexations; franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights
to persons or corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the
execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances;
ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public
places; improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to
elections; ordinances relating to the lease, transfer or acceptance of real
estate by or from the City; ordinances relating to the City Airport; ordinances
relating to personnel policies; ordinances relating to sewer tapping charge in
certain areas; ordinances relating to water connections in certain areas and
all other special ordinances. (1979 Code Ch. 25, Art. IV, §1; 1993 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this City Code or by virtue of the
preceding Section, excepting as the City Code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case this City Code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (1993 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable, if
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party affected, applied to
any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the City herein repealed
and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this Code shall be
deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the same
provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
City under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this City Code. (1993 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this City Code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this Code, or any part thereof. The City Council
hereby declares that it would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the
fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this City Code importing the plural number
is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons, any
single matter, part or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used. When any subject matter, party or
person is referred to in this City Code by words importing the singular number
only, or the masculine gender, several matters, parties or persons and females
as well as males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included; provided,
that these rules of construction shall not be applied to any section of this
City Code which contains any express provision excluding such construction or
where the subject matter or context may be repugnant thereto. (1993 Code)
All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code
shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent of the Mayor and
Council may be fully carried out. (1979 Code Ch. 25, Art. I, §6)
The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the City has been changed
in the content of this City Code to "Title", "Chapter", "Section" and/or
"subsection" or words of like import for organizational and clarification
purposes only. Such change to the City's ordinances is not meant to amend
passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (1993 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
   AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
express or implied, to do so.
   CITY: The City of Taylorville, County of Christian, State of Illinois.
   CODE: The Municipal Code of the City of Taylorville.
   EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a City employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the
City of Taylorville".
   FEE: A sum of money charged by the City for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation. (1993 Code)
   FISCAL YEAR; MUNICIPAL YEAR: The fiscal year of the City shall begin on May
1 of each year; the Municipal year shall coincide with the fiscal year. (1979
Code Ch. 25, Art. VI, §2)
   LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
   NUISANCE: Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or
any act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the City, or any activity which by its perpetuation can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of another
person or persons within the community.
   OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with
others.
   OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of
any act required by the provisions of this Code.
   OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a City officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the City of
Taylorville".
   OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or
profession.
   OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
   PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
   PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods,
chattels, effects, evidences of rights in action and all written instruments by
which any pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created,
acknowledged, transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and
every right of interest therein.
   RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to
relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small
quantities direct to the consumer.
   RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
   STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
   TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such buildings or land, whether alone or with
others.
   WHOLESALER: The terms "wholesaler" and "wholesale dealer" as used in this
Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate to
the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who
purchase for the purpose of resale.
   WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person, or in case he is unable to write, by his proper
mark. (1993 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the City Code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-
enacted. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-4: City Jail
1-4-5: Prosecutor's Fee/Attorney Fees And Costs
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   A.   General Penalty Imposed: Except as otherwise specifically stated
elsewhere in this code, any person found to have been in violation of any of
the terms and provisions of this code shall be assessed a fine or penalty in an
amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day upon which a
violation occurs or continues shall be deemed to be a separate offense. A
violation hereof may be established by a preponderance of the evidence. A
penalty imposed for each violation may include, or consist of, a requirement
that the defendant perform some reasonable public community service work such
as, but not limited to, the picking up of litter in public parks or along
public highways or the maintenance of public facilities or performing services
for a not for profit charitable corporation or entity approved by the court.
   B.   Misdemeanor: If, by the terms of the ordinance or city code section, an
act that would be consistent with the criminal laws of Illinois is declared in
this code to be a misdemeanor, the penalty therefor shall be for a period of
incarceration in a penal institution other than the penitentiary not to exceed
six (6) months. Such matters may be prosecuted as criminal offenses by the city
attorney in the circuit court by an information, or complaint sworn to,
charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to Illinois
rules of criminal procedure. In such matters, conviction shall require the city
to establish guilt of the defendant beyond reasonable doubt.
   C.   Failure To Pay Fine: No imprisonment authorized by 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1-2-9 for failure to pay any fine, penalty or cost shall exceed six
(6) months for each offense.
   D.   Municipal Ordinance Violation Complaint And Notice To Appear:
Notwithstanding anything in this code to the contrary, and pursuant to Illinois
supreme court rule 574, a defendant or offender concerning any nontraffic/
nonconservation ordinance violation that is listed or identified on a form from
time to time entitled "municipal ordinance violation complaint and notice to
appear" may be afforded the opportunity to settle such ordinance violation and
thereby avoid a court appearance by admitting guilt and completing and signing
the "plea of guilty and waiver" included within and set forth on said municipal
ordinance violation complaint and notice to appear and paying in full the
applicable fine in cash or by money order, certified or cashier's check, or
traveler's check to the city clerk, all within fourteen (14) calendar days of
the date said municipal ordinance violation complaint and notice to appear was
issued.
The aforesaid "municipal ordinance violation complaint and notice to appear"
form and the applicable listed or identified ordinance violations thereon may
be amended or revised, in whole or in part, from time to time by approval of
the mayor. (Ord. 3622, 6-17-2013)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed, but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for each such breach, the provisions of this
chapter shall apply. (1993 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the city council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is
specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1993
Code)
1-4-4: CITY JAIL:
   A.   City Jail Established: The place in the city heretofore established and
used as the jail, or any other place which may be hereafter established by the
city council for that purpose, is hereby declared to be the city jail. (1979
Code § 9-2-1)
   B.   Keeper Of The Jail 1 : The chief of police shall be the keeper of the
jail and shall have custody over all persons confined therein and of all
property pertaining thereto. (1979 Code § 9-2-2)
   C.   Prisoners:
      1.   Incarceration: The jail shall be used for incarceration of all
persons arrested for violating any laws of the state, the United States or for
violating any city ordinances until such person shall be lawfully brought
before the court for a hearing or until such person shall be lawfully
transferred to some other place of incarceration or otherwise lawfully
released. (1979 Code § 9-2-3)
      2.   Escape And Aid In Escape Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
person to escape, attempt to escape or to assist any prisoner to escape or
attempt to escape from the city jail. (1979 Code § 9-2-4)
      3.   Communications With Prisoners: It shall be unlawful for any person
to communicate with any prisoner held in the jail without the permission of the
chief of police. (1979 Code § 9-2-5)
   D.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall, for each offense, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this chapter. (1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  5-1-2B1 of this code.
1-4-5: PROSECUTOR'S FEE/ATTORNEY FEES AND COSTS:
   A.   Pursuant to 55 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-2002(b), the city shall
be entitled to a twenty five dollar ($25.00) prosecution fee for each
conviction for a violation of a city vehicle ordinance or nontraffic ordinance
which results in a finding of guilt before a circuit or associate judge or in
which a defendant has stipulated to the facts supporting the charge or finding
of guilt and the court has entered an order of supervision. Such prosecutor's
fee shall be taxed as costs to be collected from the defendant upon disposition
of the case. The city shall have a lien for such prosecution fees on all
judgments or fines procured by the city attorney from prosecutions for
violations of the Illinois vehicle code and city vehicle ordinances or
nontraffic ordinances.
   B.   A default in the payment of any fine or penalty or any installment of a
fine or penalty may be collected by any means authorized for the collection of
monetary judgments. The city attorney may retain attorneys and private
collection agents for the purposes of collecting any default in payment of any
fine or penalty or installment of that fine or penalty. Any fees or costs
incurred by the city with respect to attorneys or private collection agents
retained by the city attorney shall be charged to and paid by the offender 1
(i.e., the person who owed such fine or penalty or any installment of a fine or
penalty). (Ord. 3622, 6-17-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.
CHAPTER 5
MAYOR
SECTION:
1-5-1: Elected Official; Term Of Office; Hours
1-5-2: Bond
1-5-3: Powers And Duties
1-5-4: Absence Or Vacancy From Office
1-5-1: ELECTED OFFICIAL; TERM OF OFFICE; HOURS:
   A.   The mayor shall be elected for a four (4) year term and shall serve
until his successor is elected and qualified as is provided by statute 1 . The
mayor's term of office shall commence as of and from the date of the first
regular or special meeting of the city council held in the month next following
the mayor's election. (1979 Code Ch. 1, § 1; amd. Ord. 2000, 3-16-1981; Ord.
2945, 2-22-2000)
   B.   The office of mayor of the city of Taylorville, Illinois, is hereby
established as and shall be a full-time position. The mayor shall perform the
duties of his office and actually work for the city on a full-time basis, and
shall keep and maintain regular daytime office hours (i.e., 8:30 A.M. to 4:30
P.M.), and in any case, not less than forty (40) hours per week, except
Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, in addition to attendance at city
council meetings, committee of the whole meetings, and any committee meetings
the mayor attends, and except during vacation time periods, and except during
times in which the mayor is sick or ill. The mayor shall have his or her office
at the city hall. The mayor shall not have any other outside noncity employment
or business requiring more than an average of five (5) hours per week of his or
her time, and otherwise the mayor shall devote the whole of his or her time to
the management of city affairs. (Ord. 2945, 2-22-2000)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-10.
1-5-2: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the mayor shall execute a bond
in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by the council,
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his office, provided
the amount of such bond shall not be less than three thousand dollars
($3,000.00). (1979 Code Ch. 1, § 8)
1-5-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the city.
He shall preside over the meetings of the council and perform such duties as
may be required of him by statute or ordinance. He shall have supervision over
all of the executive officers and employees of the city and shall have the
power and authority to inspect all books and records pertaining to city affairs
which are kept by any officer or employee of the city at any reasonable time.
(1979 Code Ch. 1, § 2)
   B.   Appoint Officers: The mayor shall appoint, by and with the advice and
consent of the city council, all officers of the city for whom election or
appointment is not otherwise provided. Any vacancies occurring in any
appointive office shall be filled in the same manner. (1979 Code Ch. 1, § 3;
amd. 1993 Code)
   C.   Designate Duties Of Officers 1 : Whenever there is a dispute as to the
respective duties or powers of any appointed officer of the city, this dispute
shall be settled by the mayor, and the mayor shall have the power to delegate
to any appointed officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific
officer has been directed to perform that duty. (1979 Code Ch. 1, § 4)
   D.   Represent The City: The mayor shall act for and on behalf of the city
on formal occasions and receptions, but in his absence or inability to attend
any such function, the mayor may select any other city officer to so act. (1979
Code Ch. 1, § 7)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  1-9-5 of this title.
1-5-4: ABSENCE OR VACANCY FROM OFFICE:
   A.   Mayor Pro Tem: During a temporary absence or disability of the mayor,
the city council shall elect one of its number to act as mayor pro tem who,
during such absence or disability, shall possess the powers of mayor, as is
provided by statute 1 . (1979 Code Ch. 1, § 5)
   B.   Acting Mayor: In the event of a vacancy in the office of mayor, the
council may appoint one of its members as acting mayor to serve until the
vacancy is filled at a regular or special election as provided by law 2 . (1979
Code Ch. 1, § 6)
 
Notes
1 2. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-35.
2 3. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-50.
CHAPTER 6
CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election; Term Of Office; Functions
1-6-2: Meetings Of The Council
1-6-3: Presiding Officer
1-6-4: Quorum
1-6-5: Committees
1-6-5-1: City Negotiating Team
1-6-6: Rules Of Order
1-6-7: Remote Meetings Rules
1-6-1: ELECTION; TERM OF OFFICE; FUNCTIONS:
The members of the city council shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year
term. The term of office of each council member shall commence as of and from
the date of the first regular or special meeting of the city council held in
the month next following the council member's election. (1979 Code Ch. 2, Art.
I, § 1; amd. Ord. 2000, 3-16-1981)
The council shall be the legislative division of the city government and shall
perform such duties and have such powers as may be authorized by statute 1 .
(1979 Code Ch. 2, Art. I, § 1)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-5 et seq.
1-6-2: MEETINGS OF THE COUNCIL:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the council shall be held at
the city hall on the first and third Mondays of every month at the hour of
seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.; provided, that if the regular meeting falls on a
legal holiday, the meeting shall take place on the next secular day at the same
hour.
   B.   Adjourned Meetings: Adjourned meetings may be held at such time as the
council may determine. (Ord. 2138, 5-31-1984)
   C.   Special Meetings: Special meetings of the council may be called by the
mayor or three (3) aldermen; provided, that a written notice of such meeting
shall be given to each member of the council at least twenty four (24) hours
before the time set for the meeting; provided further, that in case all of the
elected members of the council are present at any special meeting, then the
requirement of notice shall be unnecessary and shall be deemed waived. (1979
Code Ch. 2, Art. I, § 3)
   D.   Disturbing Meetings: It shall be unlawful to disturb any meeting of the
city council or of any committee thereof or to behave in a disorderly manner at
any such meeting. Any person violating any provision of this subsection shall,
for each offense, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title. (1979 Code Ch. 2, Art. I, § 10; amd. 1993 Code)
1-6-3: PRESIDING OFFICER:
The mayor shall be the presiding officer of the council at all regular or
special meetings and when the council meets as a committee of the whole. (1979
Code Ch. 2, Art. I, § 4)
1-6-4: QUORUM:
A majority of the elected members of the council shall constitute a quorum
thereof, but no ordinance or measure for the expenditure of money shall be
passed except upon the favorable vote of the majority of the elected members as
provided by statute 1 . (1979 Code Ch. 2, Art. I, § 5)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20.
1-6-5: COMMITTEES:
   A.   Standing Committees: The following shall be the standing committees of
the city council:
Emergency services committee (fire, police, and emergency service and disaster
agency)
Finance committee
Lake/airport committee
Ordinance committee
Personnel committee
Public facilities committee
Street and sewer committee
Water/environmental committee
(Ord. 3125, 5-19-2003)
   B.   Special Committees: The mayor shall appoint such special committees as
he may deem necessary or as may be directed by the city council. (1979 Code Ch.
2, Art. I, § 7)
   C.   Membership Of Committees:
      1.   Generally: The mayor shall appoint the members of all standing and
special committees and shall designate the chairmen thereof. Every standing
committee of the city council shall consist of four (4) aldermen, including the
chairman, with one alderman from each ward being selected, unless the city
council shall provide otherwise.
      2.   Personnel Committee: The personnel committee shall also:
         a.   Compile information and make recommendations on all city employee
positions and compile job descriptions with the mayor's, city clerk's and city
treasurer's advice.
         b.   Screen all potential hirees.
         c.   Evaluate all department heads in relation to job performance and
pay raises.
         d.   Review the retention, addition or elimination of employee
positions in each department.
   D.   Committee Divisions: Such standing committees of the city council shall
be divided into the following four (4) divisions:
      1.   Public Safety: Public safety shall consist of the emergency services
committee.
      2.   Public Utility: Public utility shall consist of the lake/airport
committee and the water/environmental committee.
      3.   Finance: Finance shall consist of the finance committee, the
ordinance committee and the personnel committee.
      4.   Public Works: Public works shall consist of the public facilities
committee and the street and sewer committee. (Ord. 2790, 5-19-1997)
   E.   Meetings Of Standing Committees:
      1.   Unless otherwise scheduled by the city council or by the chairman of
the particular standing committee, each standing committee should schedule,
when possible, any necessary meetings on the following dates:
         a.   First Thursday of each month: emergency services and personnel.
         b.   Second Thursday of each month: lake/airport and water/
environmental.
         c.   Third Thursday of each month: finance and ordinance.
         d.   Fourth Thursday of each month: street and sewer and public
facilities. (Ord. 3335, 5-7-2007, eff. 5-7-2007)
      2.   For each standing committee meeting, the respective Chairman of such
standing committee, together with the appropriate Superintendent, shall
coordinate an agenda for their standing committee; and such standing committee
Chairman shall present same to the City Clerk's Office the Friday before such
standing committee meeting date.
      3.   The City Clerk shall coordinate the specific priority such standing
committees will meet on each of the aforesaid meeting dates. (Ord. 3125, 5-19-
2003)
1-6-5-1: CITY NEGOTIATING TEAM:
   A.   The City's negotiating team shall include the Mayor, the Human Resource
Manager, the appropriate Superintendent, the Chairman of the Finance Committee
(or in such Chairman's absence or unavailability, an Alderman designated by the
Mayor from time to time), and any necessary legal counsel. (Ord. 3809, 6-19-
2017)
   B.   The negotiating team shall negotiate on behalf of the City with any
unions representing the City employees.
   C.   The negotiating team shall make recommendations to the City Council
from time to time concerning labor negotiations with any unions representing
City employees.
   D.   The City Council shall make all necessary decisions concerning labor
negotiations. (Ord. 3043, 8-20-2001)
1-6-6: RULES OF ORDER:
   A.   Agenda For Meetings: An agenda of the meeting shall be prepared by the
City Clerk and delivered to the members of the City Council in advance of the
meeting. (1979 Code §2-2-1)
   B.   Order Of Business: The order of business at meetings of the City
Council shall be as follows:
      1.   Invocation and Pledge of Allegiance.
      2.   Roll call.
      3.   Omnibus vote designation regarding approval of minutes of previous
Council and committee meetings and any amendments, additions, revisions or
corrections thereto.
      4.   Communications to the Council, presentations, swearing in of
officials or employees or appointees, announcements.
      5.   Ordinances, resolutions and motions to be considered for adoption.
      6.   City Attorney updates.
      7.   Mayor updates.
      8.   Committee reports and any committee motions to be considered for
adoption.
      9.   Consideration of and motion to approve and/or ratify payment of
bills.
      10.   Public's right to speak.
      11.   Adjournment.
      12.   Any additional or other order of business may be made by order of
the Mayor from time to time to accommodate other City business matters of any
kind, nature or extent whatsoever, including, but not limited to, public
hearings, Plan Commission hearings and reports, Zoning Board of Appeals
hearings and reports, closed session matters, etc. (Ord. 3637, 10-21-2013)
   C.   Rescinded Action: No vote or action of the City Council shall be
rescinded at any special meeting unless there be present at such special
meeting as many members of the Council as were present at the meeting when such
vote or action was taken, as provided by statute 1 . (1979 Code §2-2-3)
   D.   Resolutions: Any resolution submitted to the City Council shall be
reduced to writing before being voted upon, at the request of the Mayor or any
two (2) members of the City Council. (1979 Code §2-2-4)
   E.   Additional Procedural Rules:
      1.   This following notice shall appear at the end of the respective
agendas for all City Council and committee meetings:
Per subparagraph (g) of 5 ILCS 120/2.06, this portion of the City Council (or
Committee) meeting is reserved for any person wishing to address the Council
(or Committee) on any relevant subject matters concerning the City. The
Illinois Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.) mandates NO action shall be
taken on subject matters not listed on the agenda, but the Council (or
Committee) may direct staff to address the topic or refer the subject matter to
a future Council and/or Committee meeting. If anyone wishes to address the
Council (or Committee) please provide your name and address, limit your
comments or presentation to three (3) minutes, and avoid repetitious comments.
Thank you.
      2.   At committee meetings when members of the public are present, the
Chairman in his discretion may open the floor to the public or to any
particular persons for discussion; or alternatively, a motion can be made and
seconded by committee members to allow the public present or such persons to
address the committee during the discussion of a pending subject matter agenda
item. If such motion is made, the Chairman shall recognize such motion and call
for a second to such motion and if made such motion shall be voted upon and if
approved by a majority vote of committee members present, the committee
Chairman is obligated to comply with such motion.
      3.   At city council meetings when members of the public are present the
mayor in his discretion may open the floor to the public or to any particular
persons for discussion; or alternatively a motion can and be made and seconded
by aldermen to allow the public present or such persons to address the city
council during the discussion of a pending subject matter agenda item. If such
motion is made, the mayor shall recognize such motion and call for a second to
such motion and if made such motion shall be voted upon and if approved by a
majority vote of aldermen present, the mayor is obligated to comply with such
motion.
      4.   Notwithstanding the above rules, persons attending public hearings
or persons specifically invited to attend a city council or committee meeting
or persons put on the agenda to speak about a particular subject matter agenda
items (e.g., insurance personnel, accountants or auditors, persons doing or
wanting to do business with the city, etc.) may address the city council or
committee as the mayor directs without any motion to allow such matters.
      5.   In any event, the mayor or any aldermen or city official can ask at
any time during any city council or committee meeting that the city attorney,
city engineer, city officials, employees, officers or superintendents address
the city council or committee concerning any subject matter relevant to the
city or to the discussion at hand. In those events, no motion need be made to
allow such matters. (Ord. 3637, 10-21-2013)
   F.   Suspension Of Rules: The rules of order, other than those prescribed by
statute, may be suspended at any time by consent of a majority of the members
present at any meeting. (1979 Code § 2-2-6)
   G.   Robert's Rules Of Order: Except when in conflict with the foregoing
provisions, the latest version of "Robert's Rules Of Order" shall govern the
deliberation of the city council and committee meetings. (Ord. 3637, 10-21-
2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-55.
1-6-7: REMOTE MEETINGS RULES:
   A.   If a majority of a quorum of the members of the City Council or a
majority of a quorum of the members of any City committee, as the case may be,
is physically present, they any member of the City Council may attend such
regular or special City Council meeting or City Committee of the Whole meeting,
or any City committee meeting by other means (i.e. by video or audio
conference) if such member is prevented from physically attending such meeting
because of:
      1.   Personal illness or disability; or
      2.   Employment purposes or the business of the City; or
      3.   A family or other emergency; or
      4.   Unexpected childcare obligations.
   B.   If a member wishes to attend such a meeting by such other means, the
member must notify the City Clerk before such meeting unless advanced notice is
impractical.
   C.   Subject to the requirements of Section 2.06 of the Illinois Open
Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/2.06), but notwithstanding any other provision of law,
an open or closed meeting subject to the Illinois Open Meetings Act may be
conducted by audio or video conference, without the physical presence of a
quorum of the members, so long as the conditions as set forth in 5 ILCS 120/?
(e) are met. (Ord. 4218, 12-4-2023)
CHAPTER 7
CITY CLERK
SECTION:
1-7-1: Election; Term of Office
1-7-2: Bond
1-7-3: Duties
1-7-1: ELECTION; TERM OF OFFICE:
The City Clerk shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year term and until a
successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute. 1  The Clerk's term
of office shall commence as of and from the date of the first regular or
special meeting of the City Council held in the month next following the
Clerk's election. (1979 Code Ch. 3, §1; Ord. 2000, 3-16-81)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. ch. 24, ¶3-5-9.
1-7-2: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of the office, the City Clerk shall execute a
bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by the Council,
conditioned upon the faithful performance of duty. (1979 Code Ch. 3, §2)
1-7-3: DUTIES:
The City Clerk shall:
   A.   Signatures: Seal and attest all contracts of the City and all licenses
and other such documents as shall require this formality. (1979 Code Ch. 3, §3)
   B.   Money Collected: Turn over all monies received by him on behalf of the
City to the City Treasurer, promptly on receipt of the same, and with the
money, he shall give a statement as to the source thereof. (1979 Code Ch. 3,
§4)
   C.   Accounts: Keep accounts showing all monies received and the source and
disposition thereof and such other accounts as may be required by statute or
ordinance. (1979 Code Ch. 3, §5)
   D.   Records Kept:
      1.   In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the
Clerk is required by statute to keep, keep a register of all licenses and
permits issued and the payment thereon, a record showing all of the officers
and regular employees of the City and such other records as may be required by
the Council. (1979 Code Ch. 3, §6)
      2.   Keep the minutes and records of the Council proceedings. (1979 Code
Ch. 2, Art. I, §9)
   E.   Collect License and Permit Fees: Collect all license and permit fees
which are paid to the City. (1979 Code Ch. 3, §7)
   F.   Custodian of City Seal: 1  Be the custodian of the City Seal and shall
affix its impression on documents whenever this is required. (1979 Code Ch. 3,
§8)
   G.   Custodian of Documents: Be the custodian of all documents belonging to
the City which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer of the
City by the Mayor or Council. (1979 Code Ch. 3, §9)
   H.   Indices: Keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records
kept by him so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. (1979 Code
Ch. 3, §10)
   I.   Additional Duties: In addition to the duties herein provided, perform
such other duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance.
(1979 Code Ch. 3, §11)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  1-12-1 of this Title for description.
CHAPTER 8
CITY TREASURER
SECTION:
1-8-1: Election; Term Of Office
1-8-2: Bond
1-8-3: Duties
1-8-4: Policy Concerning Borrowing And Transferring City Funds
1-8-1: ELECTION; TERM OF OFFICE:
The city treasurer shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year term and
until a successor is qualified, as provided by statute. The treasurer's term of
office shall commence as of and from the date of the first regular or special
meeting of the city council held in the month next following the treasurer's
election. (1979 Code §4-1; amd. Ord. 2000, 3-16-1981)
1-8-2: BOND:
The treasurer shall give bond conditioned upon the faithful performance of duty
and to indemnify the city for any loss due to neglect of duty or wrongful act,
and the amount of such bond shall be such amount as prescribed by the council
or the state. Such bond shall be filed with the clerk as required by statute.
(1979 Code §4-2)
1-8-3: DUTIES:
The treasurer shall:
   A.   Generally: Perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute
or by ordinance; he shall receive all monies paid in to the city, either
directly from the person paying it or from the hands of such other officer as
may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or orders properly
signed by the city clerk or the mayor. (1979 Code §4-3)
   B.   Deposit Funds: Deposit the city funds in such depositories as may be
selected from time to time as is provided by law, and he shall keep the city
money separate and distinct from his own and shall not intermingle his own
money with it or make private or personal use of the city funds. (1979 Code §4-
4)
   C.   Records Kept: Keep records showing all monies received by him, the
source from which it was received and the purpose for which it was paid out,
and he shall keep a record showing at all times the financial status of the
city. (1979 Code §4-5)
   D.   Books And Accounts: Keep such books and accounts as may be required by
the city council and shall keep them in the manner required by the city
council. (1979 Code §4-6)
   E.   Reports Required: Make monthly reports to the council showing the state
of finances of the city and the amounts received and spent during the month,
which reports shall be filed, and he shall make an annual report between May 1
and May 10 with the total amount of all receipts and expenditures of the city
and his transactions as treasurer during the preceding year. (1979 Code §4-7)
   F.   Register Of Warrants: Keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders
filed with him or paid by him and all vouchers, as is required by statute.
(1979 Code §4-8)
   G.   Ex Officio Collector: Be ex officio collector of special assessments.
He shall see to it that same are properly recorded and credited to the
particular account entitled thereto, and he shall receive, on behalf of the
city, all fees and charges, the collection of which is not delegated to some
other officer or employee 1 . (1979 Code §4-9)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  1-7-3E of this title.
1-8-4: POLICY CONCERNING BORROWING AND TRANSFERRING CITY FUNDS:
Any requests from the city treasurer to borrow funds from the city's water fund
or from any other city fund from time to time for transfer to another city fund
shall be decided each time by the city council upon each finance committee
motion recommending approval for such requested borrowed funds; and any such
approved borrowed and transferred funds shall be repaid to the water fund or to
any other city fund that provided the borrowed funds as the case may be, within
the same fiscal year that such funds are borrowed. (Ord. 3703, 4-6-2015)
CHAPTER 9
CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-9-1: Appointments; Terms Of Office
1-9-2: Qualifications
1-9-3: Oath; Bonds; Salaries
1-9-4: Powers And Duties
1-9-5: Assignment Of Duties; Disputes
1-9-6: Inspection Of Records
1-9-7: Vacations; Sick Leave
1-9-8: Employment Restrictions
1-9-9: CPR Required For Members Of Police And Fire Departments
1-9-10: Payment Of Litigation Costs
1-9-11: Employee Recognition
1-9-12: Impersonating City Officials Prohibited
1-9-13: Personal Use Of City Owned Vehicles And Equipment
1-9-14: Evaluations
1-9-15: Safe Passage Coordinators
1-9-1: APPOINTMENTS; TERMS OF OFFICE:
The mayor, with the consent of the council, shall make appointments of all city
officers provided by ordinance; all other employees hired by the mayor, city
clerk or city treasurer, after screening by the personnel committee, shall be
selected from the list submitted by the personnel committee; provided, that
full time members of the police and fire departments, other than the chief of
police and deputy police chief, and fire chief, shall be appointed by the board
of fire and police commissioners 1 . (Ord. 3218, 1-18-2005)
Every appointive officer of the city shall hold office until May 1 next
following or until his successor is appointed and qualified unless it is
otherwise provided by law or ordinance. Employees selected shall serve so long
as their services are desired. (1979 Code § 9-1-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 4 of this code.
1-9-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Residence Requirements:
      1.   Elective City Office: No person shall be eligible to any elective
city office unless such person is a qualified elector of the city and has
resided within the city for a period of one year next preceding the election.
      2.   Appointive City Office:
         a.   No person shall be eligible for an appointive office unless such
person becomes a qualified elector of the city of Taylorville and becomes a
resident within the corporate limits of the city of Taylorville within ninety
(90) consecutive days following employment and remains a qualified elector and
resident within the corporate limits of the city of Taylorville during the term
of the appointive office.
         b.   Provided, however, the foregoing requirements shall not apply to
the city engineer, health and building officer, city attorney, attorneys, or
other city officers who require technical training or knowledge, but the
foregoing requirements do apply to the fire chief, chief of police, deputy
police chief, and police lieutenants.
      3.   City Employment:
         a.   Fire Department:
            (1)   Employees: Except for the fire chief which appointive
position is governed by subsection A2a of this section, and except for
volunteer firemen which are governed by subsection A3a(2) of this section, no
person shall be eligible to be or remain a full time firefighter or assistant
fire chief or captain or employee within the city's fire department until and
unless such person becomes a city resident or establishes residency within a
6.5 mile radius of the Christian County Courthouse within ninety (90) days
after the completion of their probationary period. Failure to become and remain
a resident of the city or to establish residency within a 6.5 mile radius of
the Christian County Courthouse shall result in an immediate termination.
Employees who are city residents or establish residency within a 6.5 mile
radius of the Christian County Courthouse shall maintain said residency or
continue to reside within a 6.5 mile radius of the Christian County Courthouse
during the term of employment or be subject to immediate termination. Employees
who do not live within the city limits are not allowed to take city owned
vehicles to their residence.
            (2)   Volunteer Firemen: No person shall be eligible for or remain
eligible for appointment or services as a city volunteer fireman unless such
person is a qualified elector and resident of the city at the time of such
appointment and during all times while a volunteer fireman for the city;
provided, however, at any one time, a total of ten (10) city volunteer firemen
need not be qualified electors or residents of the city.
         b.   Police Department: Except for the police chief, deputy police
chief, and police lieutenants, which appointive positions are governed by
subsection A2a of this section, no person shall be eligible to be or remain a
police officer or employed within the city's police department until and unless
such person becomes a city resident or establishes residency within a 6.5 mile
radius of the Christian County Courthouse within ninety (90) days after the
completion of their probationary period. Failure to become and remain a
resident of the city or to establish residency within a 6.5 mile radius of the
Christian County Courthouse shall result in an immediate termination.
Employees who are city residents or establish residency within a 6.5 mile
radius of the Christian County Courthouse shall maintain said residency or
continue to reside within a 6.5 mile radius of the Christian County Courthouse
during the term of employment or be subject to immediate termination. Employees
who do not live within the city limits are not allowed to take city owned
vehicles to their residence.
         c.   High School Students: The mayor is hereby authorized to hire
Taylorville Senior High School (unit district 3) students as are enrolled in
said school's cooperative education program. Such students need not be
residents of the city as a prerequisite to such employment.
         d.   Seasonal Employees: A "seasonal employee" shall mean a person who
is either: 1) over sixteen (16) years old and who is considered a full time
Taylorville High School student, or 2) a full time student attending a college
or university who had a full time Taylorville residence for at least twelve
(12) consecutive months immediately prior to acceptance into such college or
university. Upon approval of the city council, "seasonal employees" may only be
hired for all or part of the "seasonal employment period" by the lake
department, the street and sewer department, the water department, the
municipal department at city hall, or the cemetery department. For purposes
hereof, the "seasonal employment period" is defined as the period of time from
April 1 to October 31 of each year. A "seasonal employee" job shall be
considered a manual routine work position performing such manual routine job
duties and operation of small power tools, small vehicles, and power mowers as
may be determined by the lake superintendent, the street and sewer
superintendent, the water superintendent, the mayor, or cemetery sexton, as the
case may be. A "seasonal employee" shall not be considered a "permanent part
time employee".
         e.   All Other City Employees, Including Full Time Or Permanent Part
Time Employees: No other person shall be or remain eligible for city employment
until and unless such person becomes a city resident or establishes residency
within a 6.5 mile radius of the Christian County Courthouse within ninety (90)
days after the completion of their probationary period. Failure to become and
remain a resident of the city or to establish residency within a 6.5 mile
radius of the Christian County Courthouse shall result in an immediate
termination.
Employees who are city residents or establish residency within a 6.5 mile
radius of the Christian County Courthouse shall maintain said residency or
continue to reside within a 6.5 mile radius of the Christian County Courthouse
during the term of employment or be subject to immediate termination. Employees
who do not live within the city limits are not allowed to take city owned
vehicles to their residence.
      4.   City Librarian: The city qualified elector and residency
requirements in subsection A2 of this section shall not apply to the city
librarian.
      5.   Defaulter: Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary stated in
this subsection A, no person shall be eligible to any city office who is a
defaulter to the city.
   B.   Physical Requirements:
      1.   No person shall be employed by the city unless he is in satisfactory
physical condition and physically able to perform the duties of the position of
employment. (1979 Code §9-1-14)
      2.   All persons to be employed by the city shall submit themselves to
such licensed physician or surgeon as may be selected by the city for physical
examination. A written report of the physical examination shall be filed with
the city clerk. (1979 Code §9-1-13) (amd. Ord. 3046, 9-17-2001; Ord. 3103, 11-
18-2002; Ord. 3244, 9-6-2005; Ord. 3590, 11-5-2012; Ord. 3615, 3-18-2013; Ord.
3766, 9-19-2016; Ord. 4054, 7-19-2021; Ord. 4055, 7-19-2021)
1-9-3: OATH; BONDS; SALARIES:
For each of the Aldermen whose term of office commences on or after the first
regular or special meeting of the City Council held in May 2023, each such
Alderman’s salary and compensation benefits shall be as follows:
   A.   During the aforesaid term of office, each such Alderman’s monthly
salary shall be Five Hundred Seventy-Nine Dollars and 63 Cents ($579.63).
   B.   During his or her aforesaid term of office, the City of Taylorville
shall also pay such Alderman Forty Dollars ($40.00) per day and reimbursement
for all expenses reasonably incurred by such Alderman for attending City of
Taylorville business meetings occurring at a distance of more than twenty-five
miles from the City of Taylorville; provided, however, either the Mayor or City
Council in session must approve expense reimbursements.
   C.   During his or her aforesaid term of office, at the call of either the
Mayor or of the City Council in session, the City of Taylorville shall also pay
such Alderman Thirty-Five Dollars ($35.00) for attending committee meetings
consisting of the City Council as a whole.
Such salary and compensation benefits shall be payable according to the payroll
policies of the City of Taylorville. (1979 Code §9-1-8; amd. Ord. 4125, 9-19-
2022)
1-9-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Money Received: Every officer of the city shall, at least once every
week, turn over all monies received by him in his official capacity to the city
treasurer with a statement which shows the source from which the same was
received. (1979 Code §9-1-5)
   B.   Books And Records To Successor: Every officer of the city, upon the
termination of his office for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his
successor all books and records which may be the property of the city, and if
no successor has been appointed within one week after the termination of
office, such property shall be delivered either to the clerk or to the
treasurer. (1979 Code §9-1-10)
   C.   Conservators Of The Peace: The mayor, members of the city council,
members of the fire department 1 , health and building officer, electrical
inspector and plumbing inspector, as well as members of the police department 2
, are hereby declared to be conservators of the peace with such powers to make
arrests as are given to the conservators of the peace by statute. (1979 Code
§§5-5-1, 9-1-9)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  4-1-9 of this code.
2 2. See also section
  4-1-9 of this code.
1-9-5: ASSIGNMENT OF DUTIES; DISPUTES 3 :
The mayor shall have the power to assign to any appointive officer any duty
which is not assigned by ordinance to some other specific officer and shall
determine disputes or questions relating to the respective powers or duties of
officers. (1979 Code § 9-1-3)
 
Notes
3 3. See also subsection
  1-5-3C of this title.
1-9-6: INSPECTION OF RECORDS:
All records kept by any officer of the city shall be open to inspection by the
mayor or any member of the council at all reasonable times, whether or not such
records are required to be kept by statute or ordinance. (1979 Code § 9-1-4)
1-9-7: VACATIONS; SICK LEAVE:
The rules and regulations governing vacations and sick leave for city employees
shall be such as are set, from time to time, by the mayor and council. (1979
Code § 9-1-12)
1-9-8: EMPLOYMENT RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Nepotism: No two (2) or more members of the same "immediate family"
shall henceforth be or remain as full time or part time employees anywhere
within the municipal government of the city. The term "immediate family" as
used herein shall mean all persons who are included within any person's
natural, step, foster, or adopted relationship with the following persons:
husband, wife, mother, father, brother, sister, child, grandchild, grandfather,
grandmother, and the spouse of any and all of said persons and all other
persons living in the said household of any of said persons. This section shall
not apply to any person of the same "immediate family" who is employed with the
city on the effective date hereof; provided, however, this section shall apply
to each and every subsequent application for city employment by anyone within
such applicant's same "immediate family". This section shall further not apply
to those police officers and/or firefighters hired through testing procedures
and recommendations of the city police and fire commissioner. This section
shall further not apply to those hired as seasonal employees, provided that
such seasonal employees not work in the same city department with any
"immediate family". This section shall not apply to those hired as a "seasonal
employee" (as defined in subsection
1-9-2A3d of this chapter), provided that such "seasonal employee" not work in
the same city department with any member(s) of the same "immediate family".
(Ord. 2906, 4-5-1999)
1-9-9: CPR REQUIRED FOR MEMBERS OF POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS:
All members of the city fire department and sworn officers of the city police
department shall enroll and train in and become certified to administer
cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). Such persons who are now members of either
department shall achieve certification within six (6) months following the
effective date hereof. New members shall achieve certification within six (6)
months following the date of entry into employment with such department.
The chief of each of said departments shall notify each of his respective
members, in writing, of the requirement hereinabove set forth. A member's
failure to promptly enroll and train in courses and/or instruction leading to
certification shall constitute grounds for such member's suspension for periods
not less than three (3) days nor more than five (5) days from the department.
Members may not be suspended more than three (3) times. A member's failure to
become certified within the applicable six (6) month period so provided shall
constitute grounds for dismissal from the department or for such other
disciplinary action as the city board of fire and police commissioners 1  shall
decide and determine. (Ord. 2707, 7-3-1995)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 4 of this code.
1-9-10: PAYMENT OF LITIGATION COSTS:
The city is authorized and directed to pay all costs incurred by, for or on
behalf of all city officers and employees to the extent such costs are not
otherwise subject to insurance reimbursement and provided they are reasonable
and were incurred in the legitimate defense of claims, suits or other
litigation resulting from or arising out of such person's actions, errors or
omissions occurring within the scope of such officer's and employee's
employment with, for or on behalf of the city. (Ord. 2060, 8-2-1982)
1-9-11: EMPLOYEE RECOGNITION:
The city clerk shall prepare and maintain a roster setting forth the names and
lengths of service of all full time city employees, officers, council members
and other elected officials. Based thereon, full time employees, as they mark
five (5) years' service with the city and as they mark each fifth year
anniversary thereafter, will be recognized in a manner deemed appropriate and
shall, in particular, include the award of a recognition pin to mark each fifth
year anniversary and gold watch, appropriately engraved, to mark twenty five
(25) years of service with the city. These provisions shall be implemented
retroactively. (Ord. 2110, 9-6-1983)
1-9-12: IMPERSONATING CITY OFFICIALS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate, without lawful authority,
any city officer or employee. Any person violating this section shall, for each
offense, be punished as provided in section
 1-4-1 of this title. (1979 Code § 9-1-11; amd. 1993 Code)
1-9-13: PERSONAL USE OF CITY OWNED VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT:
It is the policy of the city that the personal use of city owned vehicles and
equipment is not permitted except for de minimus use and except for bona fide
noncompensatory reasons. Any private use, except in an emergency situation,
must receive the prior approval of the department superintendent which has
charge of the vehicle or equipment and the mayor. A record shall be kept by any
employee who is authorized the personal use of city vehicles or equipment,
including, but not limited to, commuting, and such record shall be submitted to
the city treasurer on a quarterly basis by each department head or
superintendent. An appropriate amount shall be included in the employee's W-
2 form for the year for such usage based upon federal and state law. The city
shall not withhold income taxes on the value of the personal use, but the
employee may adjust form W-4 to increase withholding from regular wages to
compensate. (Ord. 2232, 12-15-1986)
1-9-14: EVALUATIONS:
   A.   The job performance of the following officers and employees shall be
annually evaluated in October of each year and rated by the Mayor, Personnel
Committee Chairman, and Human Resource Manager, to-wit: Superintendent of
Streets and Sewers, Chief of Police, Fire Chief, Water Superintendent, Cemetery
Superintendent, Airport Manager, Health and Building Officer, Lake
Superintendent, and Mayor's Administrative Assistant.
   B.   The job performance of the Human Resource Manager shall be annually
evaluated and completed in October of each year and rated by the Mayor and
Personnel Committee Chairman.
The job performance of the Deputy Police Chief and each Police Lieutenant shall
be annually evaluated and rated by the Chief of Police at such times as the
Chief of Police may determine.
The job performance of the Assistant Fire Chief shall be annually evaluated and
rated by the Fire Chief at such times as the Fire Chief may determine.
   C.   All such completed evaluations shall be subject to approval by the
Personnel Committee, at such times as the Personnel Committee may determine.
The Personnel Committee shall forward any such approvals to the City Council
for consideration and final approval.
   D.   Each of the aforesaid evaluations shall be recorded on such performance
evaluation forms as the Personnel Committee may adopt from time to time.
   E.   The following rating guidelines shall be used with such performance
evaluation forms and each of the aforesaid officers and employees shall be
annually rated accordingly:
 
Ratings                               Percentage Range of Potential Salary
                                      Increase
Category #1 Superior                  0-6%
Category #2 Exceeds expectations      0-4.5%
Category #3 Meets expectations        0-3%
Category #4 Needs improvement - to be 0-1%
reevaluated in 6 months
Category #5 Unacceptable - put on     0%
probation for 1 year
 
   F.   Such ratings shall be used by the City Council to determine the
percentage increase, if any, in the annual salaries for the aforesaid officers
and employees.
   G.   For each rating category, the City Council may hereafter annually by
motion approved by a majority affirmative vote, establish the specific
percentage salary increase, if any, within the ranges set forth in subsection E
of this section. Such percentage increase, if any, shall apply and become
effective on January 1 for the period of January 1 to the following December 31
of each salary year; commencing with the annual period starting January 1,
2021. If an increase is approved in any rating category, then the annual
salaries of such officers and employees who are rated in such category shall be
adjusted accordingly.
   H.   The aforesaid job performance evaluations and salary reviews of any one
or more of the aforesaid officers and employees may also occur, at the sole
discretion of the City Council, during any year at any other times than the
time designated for the aforesaid designated annual evaluations; and such
percentage salary increase and salary shall apply for whatever period the City
Council, in its sole discretion, may determine from time to time. (Ord. 2682,
1-17-1995; amd. Ord. 2973, 7-3-2000; Ord. 3218, 1-18-2005; Ord. 4066, 9-20-
2021)
1-9-15: SAFE PASSAGE COORDINATORS:
   A.   Office of Safe Passage Coordinator/Appointment:
      1.   There is hereby created the temporary (non-permanent) part-time
office of Safe Passage Coordinator.
      2.   Subject to the City's receipt of a State of Illinois grant
sufficient to fund two Safe Passage Coordinators, the Mayor may appoint two
temporary (non-permanent) part-time Safe Passage Coordinators, with the advice
and consent of the Aldermen, for the purpose of providing services for the
City's Safe Passage Program operated through the City's police department.
      3.   The salary or hourly rate of pay for each such Safe Passage
Coordinator shall be determined by the City Council.
      4.   A Part-Time Safe Passage Coordinator shall be considered an "at
will" employee of the City and shall receive no employment benefits of any
kind, nature or extent whatsoever, including, but not limited to, pay or other
benefits related to vacation days, holidays, sick days, bereavement days,
personal days, personal time off ("PTO") days, maternity leave, or health,
accident, dental, vision, life insurance, or retirement benefits; provided,
however, a Safe Passage Coordinator who works for the City in excess of 599
hours shall be included as a IMRF participant subject to IMRF's terms,
provisions, conditions, laws and regulations.
      5.   Subject to earlier termination by the City Council for any or no
reason whatsoever, a Safe Passage Coordinator's employment shall not exceed 28
hours per week and shall expire on July 1, 2022.
      6.   Because of the technical training and knowledge required for this
office, the qualified elector and residency requirements as set forth in
Section
1-9-2 A.2.a. shall not apply. (Ord. 4079, 11-1-2021)
ARTICLE A. CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-9A-1: Appointment
1-9A-2: Powers and Duties
1-9A-3: Other Counsel
1-9A-1: APPOINTMENT:
The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Council, may retain an attorney
to act as legal advisor to the City. (1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. I, §1)
1-9A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The City Attorney shall:
   A.   Suits and Actions: Prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at
law or equity to which the City may be a party or in which it may be interested
or which may be brought against or by any officer of the City on behalf of the
City or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the City. (1979 Code
Ch. 5, Art. I, §2)
   B.   Advice: Be the legal advisor of the City and shall render advice on all
legal questions affecting the City whenever requested to do so by any City
official. Upon request by the Mayor or Council, he shall reduce such opinion to
writing. (1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. I, §3)
   C.   Draft Ordinances and Contracts: Draft or supervise the phraseology of
any contracts, leases or other documents or instruments to which the City may
be a party and to draft ordinances and resolutions covering any subjects within
the powers of the Municipality. (1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. I, §4)
1-9A-3: OTHER COUNSEL:
The Mayor, with consent of the Council, may retain or authorize the employment
of other legal counsel to give advice or render service to the City. (1979 Code
Ch. 5, Art. I, §5)
ARTICLE B. HEALTH AND BUILDING OFFICER
SECTION:
1-9B-1: Office Created; Appointment
1-9B-2: Powers and Duties
1-9B-3: Stop Work Orders
1-9B-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the position of Health and Building Officer who shall
be appointed by the Mayor, with the consent of the Council. (1979 Code Ch. 5,
Art. II, §1; Ch. 5, Art. V, §1)
1-9B-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Health and Building Officer shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Health Provisions:
      1.   To be the enforcing officer for all ordinances concerning the health
of the City, including growth of plants and weeds, dangerous buildings, 1
garbage, 2  refuse,2 wrecked or abandoned vehicles, 3  scavengers 4  and other
duties assigned by the Mayor or Council. (1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. V, §2)
      2.   Make or cause to be made analysis of any food or drink alleged to be
tainted or unwholesome and to analyze the drinking water of the City whenever
requested to do so by the Mayor or City Council. The Health and Building
Officer shall assist in the enforcement of all ordinances relating to the sale
or storage of food and drink intended for human consumption and shall make or
cause to be made such tests and analyses and inspections as may be necessary
for this purpose. (1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. V, §3)
   B.   Building Regulations:
      1.   To issue building permits to see to the enforcement of all ordinance
provisions relating to signs, 5  to buildings 6  or to zoning 1  and to inspect
all signs and buildings or structures being erected or altered as may be
necessary to insure compliance with the ordinances of the City. (1979 Code Ch.
5, Art. II, §2)
      2.   To act as ex officio Plumbing Inspector and shall have all the
powers and perform all the duties connected with that office unless a separate
Plumbing Inspector is appointed. 8  (1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. II, §3)
      3.   To act as ex officio Electrical Inspector and shall have all the
powers and perform all the duties of that office unless a separate Electrical
Inspector is appointed. 3  (1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. II, §4)
      4.   To make or cause to be made an entry into any building or premises
where the work of altering, repairing or constructing any building or structure
is going on, for the purpose of making inspections, at any reasonable hour.
(1979 Code Ch. 5, Art. II, §6)

6 6. See Title 9 of this Code.
1 1. See Title 10 of this Code, particularly Section
  10-9-1.
8 2. See Article D of this Chapter.
