Every person engaged in the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in the City shall
pay a license fee to the City according to the application classification as
stated herein. As used herein, the term "annually" or "annual" shall be the
period of time commencing May 1 of each year until April 30 of the immediately
succeeding year.
CLASS A LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
taverns or lounges to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on and
off the premises. The fee for such license shall be nine hundred fifty dollars
($950.00) annually. Notwithstanding the above, no Class A liquor license shall
be issued for any premises associated with or primarily used as a sports
facility, recreational facility, or public park. A Class A license does not
allow for or permit video gaming. The application form for a Class A license
and the issued permit for a Class A license shall each state thereon as
follows:
   A CLASS A LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS A-1 LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
taverns or lounges to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on and
off the premises where the Illinois Gaming Board has authorized the placement
and operation of video gaming terminals. The fee for such license shall be
three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) annually. Notwithstanding the above, no
Class A-1 liquor license shall be issued for any premises associated with or
primarily used as a sports facility, recreational facility, or public park.
   A CLASS A-1 LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS B LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
grocery stores and convenience stores (as defined herein for a Class B license)
to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption off the premises where sold.
The fee for such license shall be nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00)
annually.
The application form for a Class B license and the issued permit for a Class B
license shall each state thereon as follows:
   A CLASS B LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS C LICENSES: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
restaurants (only as defined in Section
3-3-1 of this Chapter) to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on the
premises. Licensees shall not permit signs advertising alcoholic liquor on
or about the outside of any building or other structure on the premises. The
fee for such license shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00) annually. A Class
C license does not allow for or permit video gaming. The application form for a
Class C license and the issued permit for a Class C license shall each state
thereon as follows:
   A CLASS C LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS C-1 LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
restaurants (only as defined in Section
3-3-1 of this Chapter) to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises
and allows for the placement and operation of video gaming terminals authorized
by the Illinois Gaming Board. Licensees shall not permit signs advertising
alcoholic liquor on or about the outside of any building or other structure on
the premises. The fee for such license shall be three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) annually.
   A CLASS C-1 LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS D LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
clubs, as defined in Section
3-3-1 of this Chapter, to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on
the premises where sold. The fee for such license shall be seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) annually. A Class D license does not allow for or permit
video gaming. The application form for a Class D license and the issued permit
for a Class D license shall each state thereon as follows:
   A CLASS D LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS D-1 LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
clubs, as defined in Section
3-3-1 of this Chapter, to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on
the premises where sold and allows for the placement and operation of video
gaming terminals authorized by the Illinois Gaming Board. The fee for such
license shall be nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00) annually.
   A CLASS D-1 LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS E LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
the retail sale of beer and/or wine only for special events for consumption on
the premises. The license shall be issued for periods not to exceed seventy-two
(72) hours as specifically set forth in the permit issued. This license shall
only be issued to duly certified educational, fraternal, political, civic,
religious organizations or not for profit organizations; provided, however, the
licensee shall furnish satisfactory proof of purchase of dramshop insurance and
public liability and property damage insurance to provide for indemnification
due to death, personal injuries, property damages and loss of means of support,
as appropriate, in amounts not less than one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00) with respect to one individual and three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) with respect to one occurrence. Licensees shall not advertise the
sale of said beverages from signs visible to the general public from outside
the premises. The fee for such license shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) per day
or part thereof.
   A CLASS E LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS F LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
public golf courses (excluding what is commonly known as miniature golf
courses) to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on the premises.
The fee for such license shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   A CLASS F LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS G LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
reception halls and banquet halls to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for
consumption on the premises. The fee for such license shall be eight hundred
fifty dollars ($850.00) annually.
   A CLASS G LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS H LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
package liquor retail stores, including, but not limited to, wine and cheese
specialty shops, whose primary business is to sell alcoholic liquor for
consumption off the premises. The fee for such license shall be nine hundred
fifty dollars ($950.00) annually. Notwithstanding the above, no Class H liquor
license shall be issued for any premises associated with or primarily used as a
sports facility, recreational facility, or public park.
   A CLASS H LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS I LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
brewpubs to sell only microbeer at retail for consumption on and off the
premises where at least thirty percent (30%) of the total gross revenue at the
premises are the retail sales of microbeer. The fee for such license shall be
nine hundred fifty dollars ($950.00) annually. Notwithstanding the above, no
Class I liquor license shall be issued for any premises associated with or
primarily used as a sports facility, recreational facility, or public park. A
Class I license does not allow for or permit video gaming. The application form
for a Class I license and the issued permit for a Class I license shall each
state thereon as follows:
   A CLASS I LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS I-1 LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
brewpubs to sell only microbeer at retail for consumption on and off the
premises where the Illinois Gaming Board has authorized the placement and
operation of video gaming terminals. The fee for such license shall be three
thousand dollars ($3,000.00) annually. Notwithstanding the above, no Class I-
1 liquor license shall be issued for any premises associated with or primarily
used as a sports facility, recreational facility, or public park.
   A CLASS I-1 LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS J LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
bowling alleys to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on the
premises. The fee for such license shall be nine hundred fifty dollars
($950.00) annually. A Class J license does not allow for or permit video
gaming. The application form for a Class J license and the issued permit for a
Class J license shall each state thereon the following:
   A CLASS J LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS J-1 LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
bowling alleys to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption on the
premises and where the Illinois Gaming Board has authorized the placement and
operation of video gaming terminals. The fee for such license shall be three
thousand dollars ($3,000.00) annually.
   A CLASS J-1 LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS K "CATERER RETAILER" LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this
classification shall permit the holder to serve alcoholic liquors for
consumption, either on or off site whether the location is licensed or
unlicensed, as an incidental part of food service that serves prepared meals
(which excludes the serving of snacks as the primary meal) and where the
alcoholic liquors are sold at a package price agreed upon under contract. The
fee for such license shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) annually. A
Class K "caterer retailer" license does not allow for or permit video gaming.
The application form for a Class K "caterer retailer" license and the issued
Class K "caterer retailer" license shall each state thereon the following:
   A CLASS K "CATERER RETAILER" LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO
GAMING.
CLASS L "SPECIAL USE PERMIT" LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this
classification shall permit a City liquor license holder to additionally apply
for such Class L "special use permit" license to allow such existing licensed
retailer to transfer a portion of its alcoholic beverages from its existing
licensed retail premises to a designated site for a specific event for sale at
retail for use or consumption only at the location and on the specific dates
designated in such Class L "special use permit" license (i.e., 1 day or less; 2
or more days to a maximum of 15 days per location in any 12 month period). The
fee for such license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per use. A Class L
"special use permit" license does not allow for or permit video gaming. The
application form for a Class L "special use permit" license and the issued
Class L "special use permit" license shall each state thereon the following:
   A CLASS L "SPECIAL USE PERMIT" LICENSE DOES NOT ALLOW FOR OR PERMIT VIDEO
GAMING.
CLASS M LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit
grocery stores or convenience stores (as hereinafter defined) to sell alcoholic
liquor at retail for consumption on the licensed premises but only in a
separate enclosed room where video gaming terminals are located and the plans,
dimensions, specifications, and location of such enclosed room have been
approved by the City Council, and the Illinois Gaming Board has authorized the
placement and operation of such video gaming terminals only in such enclosed
room location. The fee for such license shall be three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) annually. The licensee must provide a separate address (e.g.,
"Suite A") for the Class M licensed premises that is registered with the United
States Post Office located in the City.
   A CLASS M LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR AND PERMITS VIDEO GAMING.
For purposes of a Class M license, a "convenience store" shall mean a small-
size retail business and gas station establishment that sells gasoline, fuel
and petroleum products and a limited range and selection of household goods,
grocery items, snack foods, confectionery, soft drink beverages, alcoholic
liquor for consumption off the premises, tobacco products, over-the-counter
drugs, health and beauty aids, toiletries, newspapers, magazines, etc.
CLASS N LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall only
permit one convenience store (as hereinafter defined) to sell alcoholic liquor
at retail for consumption on the licensed premises but only in a separate
enclosed room where video gaming terminals are located and the plans,
dimensions, specifications, and location of such enclosed room have been
approved by the City Council, and the Illinois Gaming Board has authorized the
placement and operation of such video gaming terminals only in such enclosed
room location. The fee for such license shall be three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) annually. There shall only be one Class N license issued at any
time. The licensee must provide a separate address (e.g., "Suite A") for the
Class N licensed premises that is registered with the United States Post Office
located in the City.
   A CLASS N LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR AND PERMITS VIDEO GAMING.
For purposes of a Class N license, a "convenience store" shall mean a small-
size retail business establishment that sells a limited range and selection of
household goods, grocery items, snack foods, confectionery, soft drink
beverages, alcoholic liquor for consumption off the premises, tobacco products,
over-the-counter drugs, health and beauty aids, toiletries, newspapers,
magazines, etc.
CLASS O LICENSE: Licenses issued pursuant to this classification shall permit a
business establishment that may be approved by the City Council from time to
time that is located in a C-1 (Commercial C-1) zoning district or in a C-2
(Commercial C-2) zoning district to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for
consumption on the licensed premises but only in a separate enclosed room where
video gaming terminals are located and the plans, dimensions, specifications,
and location of such enclosed room have been approved by the City Council, and
the Illinois Gaming Board has authorized the placement and operation of such
video gaming terminals only in such enclosed room location. The fee for such
license shall be three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) annually. The licensee must
provide a separate address (e.g., "Suite A") for the Class O licensed premises
that is registered with the United States Post Office located in the City.
   A CLASS O LICENSE DOES ALLOW FOR AND PERMITS VIDEO GAMING.
CLASS P COMBINED LICENSE: Combined licenses may be issued pursuant to this
classification to those business establishments who request: (1) a Class B
liquor license and a Class M liquor license; or (2) a Class B liquor license
and a Class N liquor license; or (3) a Class B liquor license and a Class O
liquor license.
In such cases, the annual fee for such Class P combined license shall be as
follows: three thousand nine hundred fifty dollars ($3,950.00) plus two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) for each video gaming terminal plus seven hundred
dollars ($700.00) for late closing hours (if City Code Section
3-3-10 is applicable) plus four hundred dollars ($400.00) or six hundred
dollars ($600) as the case may be for Sunday sales (if City Code Section
3-3-10 is applicable) plus a one hundred fifty dollars ($150) initial service
fee for the first Class P combined license issued to an applicant therefor. The
additional annual service fee for each combined license renewed thereafter to
the same Class P combined license applicant shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00).
Such Class P combined license fee shall be in addition to any applicable
background check costs, change of manager or agent fee or "initial application
fee" as provided in City Code Section
3-3-5.
SUNDAY LICENSES: Liquor license holders qualified to sell or offer to sell at
retail alcoholic liquor may do so at any time on Sunday from twelve o’clock
(12:00) noon to twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight upon payment of an additional
Sunday license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) annually; provided,
however, such liquor license holders may do so on Sunday from six o’clock a.m.
(6:00 a.m.) to twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight upon payment instead of a total
Sunday license fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) annually.
LATE CLOSING FEE: All licensees qualified pursuant to Sections
3-3-10 and
3-3-15 of this
Chapter to sell alcoholic liquor may elect to close at two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
on Friday and Saturday nights and on the evening preceding a legal holiday upon
payment of an additional annual late closing license fee of three hundred fifty
dollars ($350.00).
CHANGE OF MANAGER OR AGENT FEE: Each licensee whose place of business is
conducted by a manager or agent shall pay an additional one hundred dollar
($100.00) "change of manager or agent fee" for each time a manager or agent
exists and for each time a change in the identity of such manager or agent
occurs during the license term; provided, however, this additional "change of
manager or agent fee" shall not apply to Class E license holders.
COST OF BACKGROUND CHECKS: At the time of submittal of an application for a
license hereunder, each applicant for a license hereunder shall pay the cost
incurred by the City, in processing such application, to conduct a criminal
background check on the applicant and/or the applicant's manager and/or agent.
INITIAL APPLICATION FEE (DOUBLE ANNUAL LICENSE FEE): Each new applicant for a
license hereunder shall pay at the time such original application is filed with
the City, in addition to the aforesaid applicable annual license fee, an
"initial license fee" equal in amount to such applicable annual license fee.
This "initial license fee" shall be charged and paid only one time for each new
applicant for a license hereunder; provided, however, this "initial license
fee" shall not be required of any new applicant who held a license hereunder,
under the same applicant's name, as of April 29, 2003; and such "initial
license fee" shall not be required of any new applicant who first applies for a
license hereunder only because the new applicant's place of business was
annexed into the City after April 30, 2003, and such new applicant held a
liquor license under the same name of such new applicant which license was in
existence and issued by Christian County, Illinois, or by any municipality
within Christian County, Illinois, at the time of such annexation into the
City; and such "initial license fee" shall not be required for new applicants
for a Class E license.
REDUCED LIQUOR LICENSE FEE FOR "POUR ESTABLISHMENTS" FOR THE MAY 1, 2021 TO
APRIL 30, 2022 LIQUOR LICENSE TERM ONLY: For the May 1, 2021 to April 30, 2022
liquor license term only, the annual liquor license fee for all liquor
licensees that are considered "pour establishments" as determined by the Mayor
shall be reduced by fifty percent (50%) provided such liquor licensee held and
paid for a City liquor license for the entire May 1, 2020 to April 30, 2021
liquor license term. Those "pour establishments" as determined by the Mayor are
set forth on a written list in the City Clerk's office.
(Ord. 3836, 3-5-2018; amd. Ord. 3866, 10-1-2018; Ord. 3877, 11-19-2018; Ord.
3909, 8-19-2019; Ord. 3933, 12-2-2019; Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020; Ord. 3949, 3-16-
2020; Ord. 4032, 5-3-2021; Ord. 4089, 1-4-2022; Ord. 4133, 11-7-2022; Ord.
4303, 4-7-2025)
3-3-5-1: VIDEO GAMING SIGNAGE PROHIBITED ON CITY PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person or licensee to place, locate, or maintain
any signage or banner or any device or structure of any kind, nature or extent
whatsoever on City property or on any City right-of-way or on any City
boulevard or on any City street, roadway or alleyway that advertises or
displays or indicates the presence or availability of video gaming.
(Ord. 3866, 10-1-2018; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-6: PAYMENT AND DISPOSITION OF FEES:
All license fees shall be paid to the City Clerk at the time application is
approved by the Mayor, and all license fees shall be turned over to the City
Treasurer for deposit in the General Corporate Fund. (1979 Code §13-10; amd.
Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-7: TERM OF LICENSE; PRORATING FEE:
Each such liquor license shall terminate on April 30 next following the date of
issuance. The liquor license fee to be paid shall be paid in full prior to
issuance or renewal of a liquor license; and such liquor license fee shall not
be reduced or prorated because such liquor license was issued or renewed on any
calendar day other than May 1 of any year.
Notwithstanding the foregoing and only because of the current COVID-19
pandemic, applicants for issuance or renewal of liquor licenses issued or
renewed after May 1, 2020 but prior to June 1, 2020 may pay the full annual
license fee for such liquor license in two installments as follows: one-third
(1/3) of the full license fee shall be paid on or before June 1, 2020; and the
remaining two-thirds (2/3rds) of the full license fee shall be paid on or
before July 1, 2020. (1979 Code §13-6; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020; Ord. 3956, 4-
20-2020)
3-3-7-1: NO REFUNDS OF LICENSE FEE:
A licensee shall not be entitled to any refund of any portion of the liquor
license fee paid for any period in which the licensee shall be voluntarily or
involuntarily prevented from operating under the license, whether same is due
to the licensee's death, suspension or revocation of the liquor license,
cessation of conducting business, court order, bankruptcy, insolvency, or any
other reason or cause. (Ord. 2775, 11-4-1996; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-8: TRANSFER OF LICENSE/SALE OF BUSINESS:
   A.   A liquor license shall be purely a privilege, good for not to exceed
one year after issuance, unless sooner revoked as in this Chapter provided, and
shall not constitute property nor shall it be subject to attachment,
garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable,
voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated.
Such liquor license shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate
devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that
executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the
trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in
part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture
of alcoholic liquor under the order of the appropriate court, and may exercise
the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the
death of such decedent or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of
such license but not longer than six months after the death, bankruptcy or
insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of that portion of the
liquor license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be
prevented from operating under such license in accordance with the provisions
of this subparagraph A.
   B.   A liquor license shall earlier terminate upon the sale of the liquor
licensee’s business. The new owner(s) of such business must apply for a new
liquor license if such owner(s) intend(s) to operate and conduct a retail
liquor business at said previous liquor licensed location; provided, however,
if any previously existing co-owner of such business remains a co-owner of such
business following the sale thereof, then a new liquor license for the
remaining unexpired one-year license term may be issued to the new owners of
such business without the payment of any additional license fees provided all
applicants are then eligible to receive a liquor license under this Chapter.
(Ord. 2775, 11-4-1996; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020; Ord. 4113, 6-20-2022)
3-3-9: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   Any existing or future licensee may apply to renew a liquor license at
the expiration thereof, provided however, that such existing or future licensee
is then qualified and eligible to receive a liquor license under this Chapter,
and the premises and business establishment for which such renewal liquor
license is sought are suitable for the stated purpose and satisfies all
requirements and conditions for the particular class of liquor license applied
for under this Chapter, as may be amended by ordinance from time to time, and
which shall be in effect at the time of each renewal of such liquor license. In
any event, this Section shall not be construed as giving any existing or future
licensee vested right or privilege to obtain any renewal of any liquor license.
   B.   The Mayor and/or the City Council may from time to time decrease the
number and/or modify the kind of liquor licenses to be issued or renewed within
the City.
   C.   The renewal application for a liquor license shall be accompanied with
proof of completion within the last three (3) years of a State certified
Beverage Alcohol Sellers and Servers Education and Training Program or other
State of Illinois Liquor Control Commission approved program as otherwise set
forth in subsections
3-3-3B1 through B5 of this Chapter.
   D.   Any applicant for a liquor license who intends to sell alcoholic
liquors for use or consumption on his or her licensed retail premises must have
in force liquor liability insurance coverage for that premises for the entire
term of the requested liquor license in an amount that is at least equal to the
maximum liability amounts set out in subsection (a) of 235 ILCS 5/6-21 or any
amendments thereto; and such applicant shall provide the City prior to issuance
of the liquor license with a certificate or certificates of such insurance
showing the City as a certificate holder and evidencing that the insurance
company will provide prompt written notice to the City in the event of any
cancellation or termination of such insurance.
   The issuance of a liquor license for the sale of alcoholic liquors for use
or consumption on the licensed retail premises is conditioned upon the City's
receipt of such certificate of insurance and the maintenance of such insurance
in force during the entire term of such liquor license. In the event such
insurance is canceled or terminated during the term of the liquor license, then
such liquor license shall be deemed revoked instanter without any further
notice or hearing and the mayor or his delegate shall be entitled to enter the
licensed premises at their convenience and repossess such liquor license. (Ord.
3710, 4-20-2015; amd. Ord. 3713, 5-18-2015; Ord. 3890, 3-4-3019; Ord. 3943, 2-
18-2020)
3-3-10: CLOSING HOURS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person or licensee to sell or offer for
sale at retail any alcoholic liquor between the hours of one minute after
twelve o’clock (12:01) A.M. and six o’clock (6:00) A.M. on any weekday or
Saturday except where the licensee has qualified for late closing by paying the
requisite additional annual license fee of three hundred fifty dollars
($350.00) as set forth in Section
3-3-5 of this Chapter. Those licensees qualifying for late closing by paying
the said requisite additional annual license fee of three hundred fifty dollars
($350.00) will be permitted to close at two o’clock (2:00) A.M. on Friday and
Saturday nights and on the night before a legal holiday.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any liquor license holder to sell or offer for
sale at retail any alcoholic liquor at any time on Sunday except from twelve
o’clock (12:00) noon to twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight with the exception of
those liquor licensee holders who have qualified for late closing on Saturday
nights by paying the requisite additional license fee of three hundred fifty
dollars ($350.00) set forth in Section
3-3-5 of this Chapter; and with the further exception of those liquor license
holders who have paid the requisite total Sunday license fee of three hundred
dollars ($300.00) as set forth in Section
3-3-5 of this Chapter that permits them to sell or offer to sell at retail any
alcoholic liquor at any time on Sunday from six o’clock a.m. (6:00 a.m.) to
twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to keep open for business or to admit any person
except the proprietor and employees thereof to any premises where alcoholic
liquor is sold at retail during the hours when such sales are prohibited;
except, that restaurants, clubs and retail grocery stores may be open at such
hours, but no alcoholic liquor may be sold during such hours. (Ord. 2103, 8-1-
1983; amd. Ord. 3909, 8-19-2019; Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020; Ord, 4089, 1-4-2022;
Ord. 4133, 11-7-2022)
3-3-11: LOCATION:
   A.   Location Restrictions:
      1.   No liquor license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any
alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school other
than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for the aged or indigent
persons or for veterans, their spouses or children or any military or naval
station; provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering
restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food shops or
other places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal business
carried on; nor to the renewal of a liquor license for the sale at retail of
alcoholic liquor on premises within one hundred feet (100') of any church or
school where the church or school has been established within such one hundred
feet (100') since the issuance of the original license. In the case of a
church, the distance of one hundred feet (100') shall be measured to the
nearest part of any building used for worship services or educational programs
and not to property boundaries.
      2.   No person shall hereafter engage in business as a retailer of any
alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any undertaking
establishment or mortuary.
   B.   Change of Location: A liquor license shall permit the sale of alcoholic
liquor only on the premises described in the application and license. Such
location may be changed only upon a written permission to make such change
issued by the mayor. No change of location shall be permitted unless the
proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor
under the laws of this state and the City Code or ordinances of the City. (1979
Code §§ 13-14, 13-16; amd. 2103, 8-1-1983; Ord. 3737, 12-7-2015; Ord. 3943, 2-
18-2020)
3-3-12: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Premises: All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or
for the storage of such liquor for sale shall be kept in full compliance with
the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage and/or
sale of food for human consumption.
   B.   Employees: It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises used for the
retail sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or who is a
carrier of any contagious, infectious or venereal disease, and it shall be
unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or is a carrier of any such
disease to work in or about any premises or to be engaged in any way in the
handling, preparation or distribution of such liquor. (1979 Code §§ 13- 19, 13-
20; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-13: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Sales to Certain Persons Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
holder of a liquor license to sell, deliver or give any alcoholic liquor to any
intoxicated person or to any person known to him to be a habitual drunkard,
spendthrift or insane, feeble minded or distracted person.
   B.   Consumption on Premises Not Licensed for Consumption: It shall be
unlawful for anyone not having a liquor license providing for consumption on
the premises where sold to offer for sale or sell any alcoholic liquor for
consumption on the premises where sold.
   C.   Peddling Liquor: It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the
City.
   D.   Drive-Up Facilities Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for a licensee to
sell, dispense, deliver, or give any alcoholic liquor(s) to any person or
persons through or by use of a “drive-up” facility located in, on, or about the
premises where the sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is otherwise permitted
under the licensee’s license. For purposes hereof, a “drive-up” facility shall
include, but is not limited to, any premises which has any type of facility or
structure which allows the delivery of an item of goods or property by the
licensee or its agents or employees to any person who is situated in or on any
vehicle or to any person situated outside any premises and without such person
having to enter the premises where such item of goods or property is sold or
made available to any such person.
   Notwithstanding anything contained in this paragraph D to the contrary, a
Class B liquor license holder who receives a call-in purchase order or an
online purchase order through its online business website for curbside pickup
of groceries that includes the sale of alcohol liquor may deliver such sold
alcoholic liquor on such Class B liquor license holder’s property but outside
its business building provided such sold alcoholic liquor is in its original
unopened container and is delivered by an employee of such Class B license
holder who is at least 21 years of age to the same customer who ordered such
alcoholic liquor online or by a call-in order and such customer proves he or
she is over the age of twenty-one years by exhibiting such customer’s valid
driver’s license that evidences such minimum age.
   E.   Video Gaming Signage, Banners, Etc., Restricted:
      1.   A licensee is permitted to locate and maintain one outdoor
advertising banner affixed to a metal pole with a ground spike on the exterior
of the licensed premises that advertises or displays or indicates the presence
or availability of video gaming within the licensed premises, provided such
banner is either a feather flag style banner or a rectangle flag style banner
or a teardrop flag style banner, not to exceed in any case a width of two feet
(2') and an overall height of eight feet (8') from the ground level.
      2.   A licensee is permitted to locate and maintain one sign, not to
exceed twenty four inches (24") by thirty inches (30") in size, affixed on the
exterior of the licensed premises that advertises or displays or indicates the
presence or availability of video gaming within the licensed premises.
      3.   A licensee is permitted to locate and maintain one sign, not to
exceed twenty four inches (24") by thirty inches (30") in size, affixed in the
interior of the licensed premises where such signage is visible to persons
outside the licensed premises that advertises or displays or indicates the
presence or availability of video gaming within the licensed premises.
      4.   Except as otherwise permitted in subsections E1, E2, and E3 of this
Section, it shall be unlawful for any person or licensee to place, locate, or
maintain any flag, banner, signage or any other device or structure of any
kind, nature or extent whatsoever that advertises or displays or indicates the
presence or availability of video gaming within the licensed premises on or
about the exterior of the licensed premises and/or in the interior of the
licensed premises such that it is visible to persons outside the licensed
premises and/or on any adjoining property. (1979 Code §§ 13-15, 13-18, 13-25;
amd. Ord. 3069, 4-1-2002; Ord. 3890, 3-4-2019; Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020; Ord. 4005,
11-2-2020; Ord. 4049, 7-6-2021)
3-3-14: MINORS:
   A.   Sales to Minors Prohibited: No licensee or agent of licensee or other
person shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age
of twenty-one (21) years.
   B.   Age Misrepresentation: It shall be unlawful for any person under the
age of twenty-one (21) years to misrepresent his or her age for the purpose of
purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor in any tavern or other place in the
City where alcoholic liquor is sold.
   C.   Persons Under Age Twenty One On Leased Premises: It shall be unlawful
for any holder of a liquor license or his agent or employee to suffer or permit
any minor to be or remain in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to
or situated in the room or place where such licensed premises is located;
provided, that this subsection shall not apply to any person under age twenty-
one (21) who is accompanied by his parent or guardian or to any licensed
premises which derives its principal business from the sale or service of other
commodities than alcoholic liquor.
   D.   Employment as Bartenders: It shall be unlawful to employ in any
premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor a bartender who is under
twenty-one (21) years of age.
   E.   Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for any parent or
guardian to permit any person under twenty-one (21) years of age, of which he
or she may be parent or guardian, to violate any provision of this Chapter.
(1979 Code §§ 13-22, 13-23, 13-24; amd. Ord. 1948, 1-7-1980; Ord. 2420, 2-18-
1991; 1993 Code; Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-15: ANNEXATION OF ESTABLISHMENTS SELLING LIQUOR:
In the event an establishment selling alcoholic liquor, duly authorized by the
County, is annexed into the corporate limits of the City of Taylorville, said
establishment shall be subject to this Chapter in regard to location
restrictions, classification of licenses, and closing hours. The City will not
prorate the liquor license fee of the difference between what was paid to the
County and the City's fees. (Ord. 3798, 4-3-2017; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-16: LIST OF LICENSES:
The Mayor shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all such licenses
issued by him. (1979 Code §13-11; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-17: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The Mayor may suspend or revoke any liquor license for any violation of any
section of this Chapter or for the violation of any State law pertaining to the
sale of alcoholic liquor. (1979 Code §13-26; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-18: CLOSURE OF LICENSED PREMISES FOR REPEATED FIGHTING DISTURBANCES:
It is hereby declared an immediate threat to the welfare of the community for
the continued operation of any licensed premises where repeated occurrences of
fighting or threat of fighting occurs either inside the licensed premises or
originates from the licensed premises.
In the event the City Police Department responds to more than one fighting
disturbance or call within a consecutive twenty four (24) hour period relating
to any fighting or threat of fighting between or among any persons either
inside or that which originates from the licensed premises, the Mayor, or any
City police officer responding to such disturbance or call, may without notice
or hearing, issue a written order immediately closing the licensed premises for
not more than seven (7) days.
Such written order shall state the reason for such closure, and give the
licensee an opportunity to be heard during the closure period. If such licensee
shall also be engaged in the conduct of another business or businesses on the
licensed premises such written order shall not be applicable to such other
business or businesses. (Ord. 3188, 8-2-2004; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-19: PENALTY:
Any person violating any section of this Chapter shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code; amd. Ord. 3188, 8-2-2004; Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-20: APPEALS:
Any appeal of any order or action of the Mayor as Local Liquor Control
Commissioner pursuant to 235 ILCS 5/7-9 shall be limited to a review of the
official record of the proceedings of such Local Liquor Control Commissioner.
(Ord. 3397, 8-4-2008; amd. Ord. 3943, 2-18-2020)
3-3-21: NUMBER OF LIQUOR LICENSES:
As of and from November 1, 2023, and notwithstanding anything in the
Taylorville City Code to the contrary, the total number of issued and
outstanding City liquor licenses that allow video gaming shall not exceed a
total of forty (40) of said liquor licenses, until and unless the City Council
by an affirmative majority vote from time to time determines to increase or
decrease the aforesaid total number of City issued and outstanding liquor
licenses that allow video gaming at any one time. (Ord. 4207, 11-20-2023)
CHAPTER 4
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Application of Provisions
3-4-2: License Required
3-4-3: Application for License; Fee
3-4-4: Street Shows
3-4-5: Conditions of License
3-4-6: Exit Lights
3-4-7: Inspections
3-4-8: Penalty
3-4-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions hereof, except as to licensing and fees, shall apply to all
public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the City, whether
specifically licensed in another article in this Chapter or not. (1979 Code Ch.
12, Art. I, §1)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the
public and for admittance to which a fee is charged without having first
secured a license therefor; provided, that the provisions of this Section shall
not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed by any
other ordinance of the City. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. I, §2)
3-4-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Applications for such licenses shall be made to the Clerk and shall comply with
all of the general provisions of the ordinances relating to such application. 1
For such licenses there shall be a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per day
paid to the City Clerk. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. I, §2)
 
Notes
1 1. See Chapter 1 of this Title.
3-4-4: STREET SHOWS:
No permit shall be granted or given for any carnival, exhibition, show or other
amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such place that
the only main accommodation for the public or the audience will be in a public
place, except on order of the City Council. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. I, §3)
3-4-5: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Order; Crowding:
      1.   The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly
and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such
amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any
such amusement of show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or
other risks. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. I, §5)
   B.   Indecent Activity: It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise,
promote, sponsor or to show, present, exhibit, conduct or otherwise participate
in the presentation of any obscene show, play, dance, motion picture, still
picture or other electronic reproduction in any place of public accommodation
or before any public assembly or in any forum where the public is invited
within the limits of the City in violation of community standards for decency.
This provision shall not apply to activities not conducted for financial gain,
profit or other commercial purpose if and to the extent such activities are
restricted to personal associates. Further, this provision shall not apply to
persons engaged in artistic, literary, scientific, educational or other
activities possessing merits or justification of redeeming social importance.
The term "obscene" and the admissibility and interpretation of evidence of same
shall have the same meaning, definition and rules as are set forth in chapter
38, section 11-20(b) and (c), Illinois Revised Statutes, which provisions are
hereby incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference as if fully set
forth herein. (Ord. 2038, 2-15-82)
   C.   Riots: It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of
any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or
disturbance. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. I, §9)
   D.   Smoking: It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar,
cigarette or pipe on or beneath the stage or in a dressing room of any building
used as an assembly hall with seating accommodations for more than one hundred
(100) persons or in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other
entertainments are offered, presented, operated or exhibited. (1979 Code Ch.
12, Art. I, §10)
It shall be the duty of the owner of such premises or of the occupant in charge
to provide and place printed signs on which the words "No Smoking" shall appear
in letters at least four inches (4") high, in conspicuous places, at least two
(2) signs being upon the stage or in the wings thereof and one in each dressing
room. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. I, §11)
3-4-6: EXIT LIGHTS:
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building or hall
used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one hundred (100) persons or
more in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures and other entertainment
is offered, operated or presented to provide and place a lighted red sign, on
which the word "EXIT" shall appear in letters at least six inches (6") high,
over every door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress
therefrom; said lighted red sign shall be kept burning during the entire period
that the hall is open to the public and until the audience has left the hall.
(1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. I, §12)
3-4-7: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and the Fire Chief to see that
every exhibition, amusement, theatrical or other public show or amusement is
inspected by a member of the Police and Fire Department and to insure
conformity with the provisions concerning such amusements. (1979 Code Ch. 12,
Art. I, §6)
3-4-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions hereof shall be punished as provided
in Section
 1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE A. RAFFLES
SECTION:
3-4A-1: Definitions
3-4A-2: License Required; Qualifications
3-4A-3: Application for License; Fee; Issuance
3-4A-4: License Limitations and Restrictions
3-4A-5: Conduct of Raffles
3-4A-6: Penalty
3-4A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The City adopts and incorporates herein the definitions of "net proceeds" and
"raffle" as set forth in section 2301 of the "Raffles Act". 1  (Ord. 2247, 5-
18-87)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. ch. 85, ¶2301 et seq.
3-4A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; QUALIFICATIONS:
No person shall conduct raffles or chances without having first obtained a
license in accordance with this Article. Licenses shall be issued to qualified
bona fide religious, charitable, labor, business, fraternal, education or
veteran's organizations that operate without profit to their members and which
have been in existence continuously for a period of five (5) years immediately
before making application for a license and which have had, during that entire
five (5) year period, a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their
objects. The City hereby adopts and incorporates the definitions of such
organization as set forth in section 2302(b) of the "Raffle Act".1 (Ord. 2247,
5-18-87)
3-4A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE; ISSUANCE:
Written application for a raffle license shall be completed and signed in the
form attached to Ordinance 2247 and incorporated herein by reference. A fee of
ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid by the licensee upon issuance of such
license. The City Clerk is hereby authorized to issue such license if such
applications are in accordance with this Article. (Ord. 2247, 5-18-87)
3-4A-4: LICENSE LIMITATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded by a
licensee in a single raffle shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00).
   B.   The maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a
single raffle shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00).
   C.   The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or
sold shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   D.   The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold
shall not exceed three hundred sixty five (365).
   E.   All licenses issued hereunder shall be valid for only one raffle and
may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this Article.
   F.   All licenses issued hereunder shall only authorize the sale of raffle
chances within the corporate limits of the City.
   G.   All licenses issued are further subject to all terms and provisions as
set forth in section 2303 of the "Raffle Act" 1  which are incorporated herein
by reference. (Ord. 2247, 5-18-87)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. ch. 85, ¶2301 et seq.
3-4A-5: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles is subject to all the restrictions and requirements
as are set forth in sections 2304, 2305, 2306 and 2308 of the "Raffles Act"1
which are incorporated herein by reference. A manager's fidelity bond shall be
issued in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or the aggregate
retail value of all prizes and merchandise awarded by a licensee in the raffle,
whichever is greater. This requirement may be waived by unanimous vote of the
members of the licensed organization. (Ord. 2247, 5-18-87)
3-4A-6: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this Article shall, upon
conviction thereof, for each offense, be punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE B. BOWLING ALLEYS
SECTION:
3-4B-1: License Required
3-4B-2: Application for License; Fee
3-4B-3: Hours of Liquor Sales
3-4B-4: Penalty
3-4B-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or maintain a bowling alley open to the public without
having first secured a license therefor as is herein required. (1979 Code Ch.
12, Art. III, §1)
3-4B-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Applications for such licenses shall be made to the Clerk and shall be in
writing and state thereon the intended location of the place of business and
the number of alleys to be used. The annual fee for such licenses shall be
twenty five dollars ($25.00), payable on or before October 31 of each year.
(1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. III, §§1, 2)
3-4B-3: HOURS OF LIQUOR SALES:
It shall be unlawful for any person who conducts a bowling alley 1  operation
to sell alcoholic beverages between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. Sunday through Thursday and two o'clock
(2:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on Friday, Saturday and the evening
before a holiday. 2  (Ord. 2424, 3-4-91)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-3-5 of this Title.
2 2. See Section
  3-3-10 of this Title.
3-4B-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE C. BILLIARD AND POOL HALLS
SECTION:
3-4C-1: License Required
3-4C-2: Application For License; Fee
3-4C-3: Closing Hours
3-4C-4: Minors
3-4C-5: Penalty
3-4C-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard, pool or bagatelle or
pigeon hole table in any place of business, private club, or any public place,
excluding only churches, without having first obtained a license therefor as is
herein required. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-94)
3-4C-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
   A.   All applications for such license shall state thereon the intended
location of the place of business, private club or public place, and the number
of tables to be used therein. This Section includes all such tables that may be
coin operated.
   B.   Each license year shall run from May 1 to April 30 of the following
year. For the license year May 1, 1994 to April 30, 1995, the annual fee for
any such licenses shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each table. Commencing
May 1, 1995, the annual fee for any such license shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00) for each table. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-94)
3-4C-3: CLOSING HOURS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to remain open for business between the
hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.; except, that
with respect to Saturdays, it shall be unlawful for any such entity to remain
open for business between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and one
o'clock (1:00) P.M. of the following Sunday, and except, that with respect to
Sundays, it shall be unlawful for any such entity to remain open for business
between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of
the following Monday. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. II, § 3)
3-4C-4: MINORS 1 :
Minors under the age of sixteen (16) years shall, under no circumstances,
frequent, loiter, go or remain in any hall licensed hereunder at any time
unless it be upon some lawful errand and sent under the direction and the
consent of and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having the
lawful custody of such minor, and it shall be unlawful for the proprietor of
any hall so licensed to allow or permit any such minor to frequent, loiter or
remain within the hall in violation of this Section. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art.
II, § 4)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-4G-5 of this Chapter for required supervision.
3-4C-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE D. SKATING RINKS
SECTION:
3-4D-1: License Required
3-4D-2: Application for License; Fee
3-4D-3: Restrictions on Issuance of License; Investigation
3-4D-4: Premises Requirements
3-4D-5: Conduct of Patrons and Business
3-4D-6: Penalty
3-4D-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain a public skating rink in the City
without first having obtained a license therefor as is herein provided. (1979
Code Ch. 12, Art. VIII, §1)
3-4D-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions
of the ordinances relating to licenses 1  and shall specify the location of the
proposed skating rink and the person or organization sponsoring the same. (1979
Code Ch. 12, Art. VIII, §2)
The fee for such license shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year. (1979
Code Ch. 12, Art. VIII, §3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Chapter 1 of this Title.
3-4D-3: RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
No such license shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character
nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the City by a
person of good moral character.
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to make or cause to be made an
investigation into the character of each applicant and report the results of
such investigation to the Clerk. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VIII, §2)
3-4D-4: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful to conduct a public skating rink in any hall or building
which is not equipped with sufficient and adequate exits, and no hall or
building which is not provided with at least two (2) exits of four feet (4') or
more in width shall be used for such purpose. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VIII, §4)
3-4D-5: CONDUCT OF PATRONS AND BUSINESS:
It shall be unlawful to indulge in any improper conduct or to permit any
improper conduct at any public skating rink, and it shall be unlawful to permit
music at any public skating rink after the hour of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
(1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VIII, §5)
3-4D-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall, for each
offense, be punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE E. MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS
SECTION:
3-4E-1: License Required
3-4E-2: Application for License
3-4E-3: License Fees
3-4E-4: Building Requirements
3-4E-5: Crowding; Order
3-4E-6: Prohibited Pictures
3-4E-7: Inspections
3-4E-8: Penalty
3-4E-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture or
theatrical, for admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances
given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious,
educational or charitable organization, without having first secured a license
therefor as is herein provided. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §1)
3-4E-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the general
provisions relating to such applications 1  and shall state, in addition to
other information required, the place of the intended performance and the
seating capacity thereof. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §2)
 
Notes
1 1. See Chapter 1 of this Title.
3-4E-3: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   Annual License Fee: The annual fee for any such license shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00) for each theater.
Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures or theatricals,
naming a specific place or building where the performances are to be presented,
may present therein any number of performances, including theatricals, during
the year for which the license was secured without having to pay any additional
fee. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §3)
   B.   Motion Pictures and Theatricals on Unlicensed Premises: For motion
pictures or theatricals which are to be presented in premises which are not
covered by such license fees, the fee to be paid shall be ten dollars ($10.00)
per day; provided, that no such motion picture or theatrical shall be presented
in or on any premises or building which does not fully comply with the
requirements of the ordinances for the construction or maintenance of buildings
for this purpose. 1  (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §4)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 9 of this Code.
3-4E-4: BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   General Requirements; Exits:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to present any public motion picture in any
building or structure which does not contain the number of exits required by
the ordinances of the City or by the statutes of the State concerning buildings
or places intended for motion picture performances or on premises in which the
electrical wiring does not fully comply with the ordinances.
      2.   All places used for the exhibition of theatricals must be kept
adequately ventilated during the performance and for so long a time as the
audience remains therein. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §8)
      3.   It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any
aisles, corridors or exits leading from the room or enclosures in which a
motion picture performance or theatrical is being given or in which an audience
for such a performance is gathered. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §9)
   B.   Scenery: It shall be unlawful to use any scenery in any theater other
than nonflammable scenery or such as shall have been rendered nonflammable by
the application of fire preventive coatings. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §7)
3-4E-5: CROWDING; ORDER:
It shall be unlawful to permit any person, excepting ushers or other theater
employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is
presented during the time of such performance, and it shall be unlawful to
admit to any such hall more persons than can be accommodated by the seating
arrangements for the premises. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI, §6)
3-4E-6: PROHIBITED PICTURES:
It shall be unlawful to permit any person to offer or present any motion
picture which has a tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance of the peace
or any immoral, indecent or blasphemous picture or performance. (1979 Code Ch.
12, Art. VI, §5)
3-4E-7: INSPECTIONS:
Premises in or on which motion pictures or theatricals are presented shall be
inspected by the Health and Building Officer, the Fire Chief and the Chief of
Police as often as is necessary to comply with the provisions of this Article
and any other ordinance provisions relating hereto. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. VI,
§10)
3-4E-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE F. CIRCUSES
SECTION:
3-4F-1: License Required
3-4F-2: Application for License
3-4F-3: Parade Permit
3-4F-4: Fees
3-4F-5: Compliance with Provisions
3-4F-6: Inspections
3-4F-7: Penalty
3-4F-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate a circus in the City without having first
obtained a license as is provided in this Article. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. IV,
§1)
3-4F-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The applications for such licenses shall be made to the City Clerk and shall
specify the place in or on which the circus is to be conducted. (1979 Code Ch.
12, Art. IV, §2)
3-4F-3: PARADE PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful to conduct any parade connected with a circus in or on any
public street, alley or other public way or place in the City unless a permit
therefor is first obtained from the City Council. (1979 Code Ch. 12, Art. IV,
§7)
3-4F-4: FEES:
   A.   Circuses and Parades: The fee for circus license shall be fifty dollars
($50.00) per day for each license and an additional fifty dollars ($50.00) per
day for each circus parade. (1979 Code Ch. 12, §3)
   B.   Sideshows and Concessions: The license fee for each sideshow and
concession operated in connection with a circus shall be five dollars ($5.00)
per day. (1979 Code Ch. 12, §4)
3-4F-5: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this Article to obey the
provisions of Sections
 3-4-1 through
3-4-8 of this Chapter and all other ordinances relating to circuses or the
premises occupied. (1979 Code Ch. 12, §5)
3-4F-6: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and the Fire Chief to see that
inspections, as provided for in Section
3-4-7 of this Chapter, shall be made of all circuses, circus performances and
of the premises used. (1979 Code Ch. 12, §6)
3-4F-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE G. COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT OR MUSICAL DEVICES
SECTION:
3-4G-1: Definitions
3-4G-2: Operator's License Required; Fee; Exemptions
3-4G-3: Application For License
3-4G-4: License Fees For Amusement Or Musical Devices
3-4G-5: Supervision
3-4G-6: Penalty
3-4G-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
   COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Includes any mechanical device of any kind,
nature or extent whatsoever and which is capable of being operated by use of
coins or currency and is intended to be operated for fun, recreation,
amusement, or sporting purposes; and shall include, but not be limited to, dart
machines, basketball machines, bowling machines, riding machines, pinball
machines, video game machines, poker machines, slot machines, foosball
machines, shuffleboard, golf, air hockey, children's rides, children's games,
gift chance games and trivia machines.
   COIN OPERATED MUSICAL DEVICE: Includes any mechanical device of any kind,
nature or extent whatsoever, which is capable of being operated by use of coins
or currency; and is intended to be operated for the primary purpose of playing
musical records, discs, or tapes for listening pleasure.
   OPERATOR: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association who sets
up for operation by another, or leases or distributes for the purpose of
operation by another, any coin operated amusement device and/or any coin
operated musical device, whether such setting up for operation, leasing or
distributing be for a fixed charge or rental or on the basis of a division of
the income derived from such coin operated amusement devices, coin operated
musical devices, or otherwise. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-1994)
3-4G-2: OPERATOR'S LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   No person not owning either the business enterprise or the business
location concerned, shall place, locate or otherwise maintain therein any coin
operated amusement device or coin operated musical device for public use and
for which a charge is made without first obtaining an operator's license, which
license shall cost two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) annually. Each license
year shall run from May 1 to April 30 of the following year. The license as
issued, shall not be transferable.
   B.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to owners of business
enterprises and/or business locations. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-1994)
3-4G-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring the license required by this article shall, through a duly
licensed "operator" as herein defined, make application for that purpose to the
city clerk, which application shall set forth the full name and business and
residential addresses and phone numbers of the applicant, the location and
character of the building or place where such coin operated amusement devices
or coin operated musical devices are to be located, maintained and operated,
the number of such devices to be located, maintained and operated in such
building or place and the charge to be made to the customer for operating each
of such devices. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-1994)
3-4G-4: LICENSE FEES FOR AMUSEMENT OR MUSICAL DEVICES:
   A.   Annual License Fee: The annual license fee to be charged for each coin
operated amusement device or coin operated musical device shall be twenty five
dollars ($25.00) payable annually on May 1 of each year, and each license year
shall run from May 1 to April 30 of the following year. The license fee for
each coin operated amusement device or coin operated musical device first
acquired and put in operation between May 2 and the following April 30 of each
license year shall be prorated.
   B.   Issuance Of License: The license shall be issued to the business
enterprise or location as an entity, and the fee thereby due shall be assessed
on the basis of the number of devices specified in its application.
Accordingly, the entity may remove, replace or otherwise change machines at the
business enterprise or location at any time within the pertinent annual license
period without payment of additional licensing fees; however, in no event shall
the entity be permitted to place, locate or otherwise maintain for use more
than the number of devices specified in its application.
   C.   Identification Of License: Such license shall be identified by a
license sticker which the licensee shall affix to and maintain at all times on
each licensed coin operated amusement device or coin operated musical device.
   D.   Nontransferable: Such licenses and license stickers, as issued, shall
not be transferable to any purchaser of such business enterprise or entity but
the license fee to be paid by the purchaser of such business enterprise or
location shall be prorated for the balance of the license year in which such
seller paid such license fee. In no event, however, shall the seller of such
business enterprise be entitled to receive any refund of said license fee
previously paid. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-1994)
   E.   Coin Operated Amusement Device Fees For Civic, Church, And Fraternal
Organizations During Special Events: Any civic, church, or fraternal
organization desiring to have coin operated amusement devices at a special
event(s) shall make application for that purpose to the city clerk, which
application shall set forth the full name of the civic, church, or fraternal
organization, the location and character of the special event, the duration of
the special event, and the number of such devices to be present at the special
event. The fee for such limited license to a civic, church, or fraternal
organization shall be five dollars ($5.00) per coin operated amusement device.
The license shall be issued for periods not to exceed seventy two (72) hours
which limited time period shall be specifically set forth in the permit issued.
No permit pursuant to this subsection shall issue to a civic, church, or
fraternal organization unless the owner of the coin operated amusement devices
is licensed with the city of Taylorville as otherwise set forth in this
chapter. (Ord. 3354, 10-15-2007)
3-4G-5: SUPERVISION:
Any establishment having pinball, pool tables 1  or other coin operated
amusement devices, except coin operated musical devices, shall be at all times
supervised by a person over the age of twenty one (21) years. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-
1994)
 
Notes
1 1. See also article C of this chapter.
3-4G-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-1994)
CHAPTER 5
AUCTIONEERS
SECTION:
3-5-1: License Required
3-5-2: Application For License; Investigation
3-5-3: License Fees
3-5-4: Bond
3-5-5: Conditions Of License
3-5-6: Exemptions From Provisions
3-5-7: Penalty
3-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an auction in the city or to do
business as an auctioneer without having first obtained a license as is herein
required and paying the fee herein set forth. (1979 Code §14-1-1)
3-5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
Application for an auctioneer's license shall be made, in writing, to the city
clerk and shall state thereon the place of business, if any, intended to be
occupied and the names of any employees, not to exceed two (2), who are to be
authorized to conduct auctions under the authority of the license. (1979 Code
§14-1-2)
The chief of police, or any other officer designated by the mayor shall
investigate the character of every applicant for an auctioneer's license, and
no such license shall be issued to any person who is not of good character.
(1979 Code §14-1-3)
3-5-3: LICENSE FEES:
The fees payable for an auctioneer's license shall be one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) for a license for five (5) days and fifty dollars ($50.00) additional
for each additional day over five (5). (1979 Code §14-1-4)
3-5-4: BOND:
No auctioneer's license shall be issued until the applicant has first filed an
indemnity bond, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned to
indemnify the city from any loss or damage resulting to it by such auction;
such bond to have sureties approved by the mayor. (1979 Code §14-1-5)
3-5-5: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Closing Hours: No auction shall be conducted between the hours of nine
o'clock (9:00) P.M. of any day and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. of the following
day nor on Sunday before twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and after six o'clock (6:
00) P.M. (Ord. 2084, 2-21-1983)
   B.   Auctions In Streets: No person shall sell or offer for sale or attempt
to sell at public auction any goods, chattels or real or personal property of
any kind upon the public streets or sidewalks of the city. (1979 Code §14-1-7)
3-5-6: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to public auction sales
described as follows:
   A.   Sale of real estate.
   B.   Sale of farm machinery, equipment and accessories.
   C.   Sale pursuant to judicial or other governmental order.
   D.   Sale pursuant to powers and authorities set forth in security
agreements or other forms of financing statements.
   E.   Sale by legal representative of a decedent in liquidation of an estate.
   F.   Sale by heirs and legatees of a decedent in liquidation of an estate.
   G.   Sale by a party of such party's household properties, provided such
sale is conducted on the party's premises.
   H.   Sale by a party (meaning only residents of the city) of such party's
household properties where such party's living quarters are not located on the
ground level or where inadequate space is not reasonably available to
facilitate sale on the premises. In such event, such party shall be allowed to
move the household properties to another location; provided, that no items not
a part of the household properties of that individual shall be included in the
sale. (Ord. 2084, 2-21-1983)
   I.   Any auctioneer conducting an auction for a person or entity having a
"going out of business sale" is only exempt from the license fee under section
3-5-3 of this chapter, but such auctioneer for such "going out of business
sale" is otherwise subject to all other provisions of this chapter 1 . (Ord.
3743, 3-21-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 13 of this title.
3-5-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, for each
offense, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 6
CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO DEALERS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Definition
3-6-2: License Required
3-6-3: Application For License; Qualifications; Fees; Penalty
3-6-4: Cigarettes, Tobacco, Alternative Nicotine Products, And Vape Pens
Advertisements, Banners, Signage, Etc. Restricted
3-6-5: Sanitary Requirements
3-6-6: Sales Or Gifts To Or Consumption Or Possession By Persons Under Age
Twenty-One Years
 
3-6-7: Penalty
3-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "coin operated cigarette machine" is hereby defined to include any
mechanical device operated by coins or currency for the sale of and which
dispenses any cigarettes or tobacco in any form. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-1994)
3-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   Retail Sale: It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale at retail of
cigarettes or tobacco in any form or in any number without having first
obtained a license therefor.
   B.   Coin Operated Cigarette Machine: It shall be unlawful to engage in the
sale of cigarettes or tobacco in any form or in any number through the use of a
coin operated cigarette machine without having first obtained a license
therefor. (Ord. 2543, 5-2-1994)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; QUALIFICATIONS; FEES; PENALTY:
   A.   Coin Operated Cigarette Machine License:
      1.   Any owner of any coin operated cigarette machine desiring the
license required by this article shall make application for that purpose to the
city clerk, which application shall set forth the full name and business and
residential addresses and phone numbers of the applicant, the serial number of
each such coin operated cigarette machine, and the location and character of
the building or place where such coin operated cigarette machines are to be
located, maintained, and operated, and the number of such coin operated
cigarette machines to be located, maintained and operated in such building or
place. Such licensee shall notify the city clerk's office of any change of the
number of such coin operated cigarette machines, and any change in serial
numbers and any change where any such licensed coin operated cigarette machine
is located, maintained and operated. Such notification shall be made within ten
(10) days of such change in number or location.
      2.   The annual license fee to be charged for each coin operated
cigarette machine shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) payable in advance on
May 1 of each year, and each license year shall run from May 1 to April 30 of
the following year. The license fee for each coin operated cigarette machine
first acquired and put in operation between May 2 and the following April 30 of
each license year shall be prorated.
      3.   The license shall be issued to the owner of such coin operated
cigarette machine and the license fee thereby due shall be assessed on the
basis of the number of coin operated cigarette machines specified in the
owner's application. Such license shall be identified by a license sticker
which the owner shall affix to and maintain at all times on each licensed coin
operated cigarette machine.
      4.   Such licenses and license stickers are not transferable, but in the
event the owner sells any such coin operated cigarette machine the license fee
to be paid by the purchaser thereof shall be prorated for the balance of the
license year in which such seller paid such license fee. In no event, however,
shall the seller of such coin operated cigarette machine be entitled to receive
any refund of such license fee previously paid.
   B.   Cigarette And Tobacco license:
      1.   Any owner of the business enterprise or location where any coin
operated cigarette machine is located, maintained, or operated or where the
retail sale of cigarettes, tobacco, tobacco products, alternative nicotine
products, electronic cigarettes, or nicotine containing products (e.g. Vape
Pens) in any form is sold without the use of any coin operated cigarette
machines, is also required to obtain a Cigarette and Tobacco license therefor.
Such owner shall make application to the City Clerk for that purpose, which
application shall set forth the name and business and residential addresses and
phone numbers of the applicant and the location and character of the building
or place where such sale of cigarettes, tobacco, tobacco products, alternative
nicotine products, electronic cigarettes, or nicotine containing products (e.g.
Vape Pens) in any form is to be sold.
      2.   The annual Cigarette and Tobacco license fee to be charged shall be
five hundred dollars ($500.00) payable in advance on May 1 of each year, and
each license year shall run from May 1 to April 30 of the following year. The
annual Cigarette and Tobacco license fee for a business applying for said
license between May 2 and the following April 30 of each license year shall be
prorated. Such license shall be issued to the owner of the business enterprise
or location as an entity.
      3.   Such Cigarette and Tobacco licenses are not transferable but in the
event the owner sells such business enterprise or entity, the Cigarette and
Tobacco license fee to be paid by the purchaser thereof shall be prorated for
the balance of the license year in which such seller paid such Cigarette and
Tobacco license fee. In no event, however, shall the seller of such business
enterprise or entity be entitled to receive any refund of such Cigarette and
Tobacco license fee previously paid.
      4.   No Cigarette and Tobacco license shall be issued for the retail sale
of cigarettes, tobacco, tobacco products, alternative nicotine products,
electronic cigarettes, or nicotine containing products (e.g. Vape Pens) in any
form within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the nearest property boundary
lines of any church or school; provided, that this prohibition shall not apply
to businesses whose primary retail sales business is not the retail sale of
cigarettes, tobacco, tobacco products, alternative nicotine products,
electronic cigarettes, or nicotine containing products (e.g. Vape Pens) in any
form.
      5.   No Cigarette and Tobacco license shall be held by or issued to or
renewed for any owner or owners who is/are not a resident of Christian County,
Illinois. For purposes hereof, an "owner" includes the individual owner of a
sole proprietorship, all stockholders of a corporation, all partners of a
partnership or limited liability partnership, and all members of a limited
liability company.
   C.   Moral Character: No license required herein shall be issued to any
person or owner who is not a person of good moral character or to any business
enterprise, corporation or entity that is not represented in the municipality
by a person of good moral character.
   D.   Number Of Licenses Limited: The number of licenses issued under
paragraphs A or B of Section
3-6-3 shall be limited to a total of twenty (20) at any one time unless and
until the City Council shall approve, by a favorable majority vote motion, an
increase in the number of such licenses from time to time.
   E.   Penalty: Each owner of a business enterprise who, individually or
through such owner's employee, agent, or representative, sells or gives or
furnishes any cigarette, tobacco, tobacco product, alternative nicotine
product, electronic cigarette, or nicotine containing product (e.g. vape pen)
in any form to any person without having first obtained the requisite cigarette
and tobacco license under this
Chapter 6 shall, for each offense, be fined the sum of seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). Each sale or gift or act of furnishing upon which a
violation occurs or continues shall be deemed to be a separate offense. (Ord.
2543, 5-2-1994; amd. Ord. 3313, 10-16-2006; Ord. 4208, 11-20-2023; Ord. 4239,
4-15-2024; Ord. 4276, 11-4-2024)
3-6-4: CIGARETTES, TOBACCO, ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS, AND VAPE PENS
ADVERTISEMENTS, BANNERS, SIGNAGE, ETC. RESTRICTED:
   A.   A Cigarette and Tobacco Dealer licensee is permitted to locate and
maintain one (1) outdoor advertising banner affixed to a metal pole with a
