service to be incorporated within the Fire Department for the purposes of
providing emergency and nonemergency care and transportation of sick, injured
and disabled citizens within the limits of the City of Taylorville and
Taylorville Fire Protection District (TFPD) and beyond the limits according to
policies.
      2.   Authority: The operation of the ambulance service shall be under the
direction of the Fire Chief.
      3.   Operation And Maintenance Of Emergency Vehicle: The Fire Department,
through appropriately trained personnel, is hereby authorized to operate and
maintain an emergency vehicle for emergency advanced life support rescue
transport services.
      4.   Services Provided: The Fire Department shall provide emergency
advanced life support ambulance rescue services.
      5.   Guidelines: The operations of the TFD ambulance will be subject to
the guidelines under SOG #211 "Ambulance Deployment" adopted herein by
reference. (Ord. 3558, 4-16-2012)
   B.   Ambulance Fees:
      1.   For emergency advanced life support rescue transport services
rendered, which consists of transport from the scene of an incident to any
hospital or medical facility, the following fees shall be assessed and paid:
         a.   If the patient is a resident of the City of Taylorville ("City")
or of the Taylorville Fire Protection District ("TFPD"), the fee shall be eight
hundred fifty dollars ($850.00) plus sixteen dollars fifty cents ($16.50) per
mile from the scene of an incident to any hospital or medical facility.
         b.   If the patient is a nonresident of the City or TFPD, the fee
shall be nine hundred dollars ($900.00) plus sixteen dollars fifty cents
($16.50) per mile from the scene of the incident to any hospital or medical
facility.
      2.   For advanced life support non-transport services rendered, the
following fees shall be assessed and paid:
         a.   If the patient is a resident of the City or TFPD, the fee shall
be seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
         b.   If the patient is a nonresident of the City or TFPD, the fee
shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00).
      3.   For emergency basic life support rescue transport services rendered,
which consists of transport from the scene of an incident to any hospital or
medical facility, the following fees shall be assessed and paid:
         a.   If the patient is a resident of the City of Taylorville ("City")
or of the Taylorville Fire Protection District ("TFPD"), the fee shall be six
hundred dollars ($600.00) plus sixteen dollars fifty cents ($16.50) per mile
from the scene of an incident to any hospital or medical facility.
         b.   If the patient is a nonresident of the City or TFPD, the fee
shall beseven hundred dollars ($700.00) plus sixteen dollars fifty cents
($16.50) per mile from the scene of the incident to any hospital or medical
facility.
      4.   A fee (on a current cost basis as determined by the Fire Chief)
shall be assessed and paid for all disposable medical supplies that are used by
the Municipal ambulance service in treatment of any patient.
      5.   A fee of one-hundred dollars ($100.00) per hour shall be assessed
and paid for nonemergency standby service to any commercial enterprise, with
the exception of special events as may be authorized from time to time by the
Fire Chief in his sole discretion.
      6.   A fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be assessed and paid
for any vehicle accident that requires extrication for a nonresident of the
City or TFPD.
      7.   A fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be assessed and paid
for each TFD apparatus or ambulance response to any call for service that turns
out to be for a non-emergency service that includes, but is not limited to, the
following examples: routine doctor visits, transfers between medical facilities
(including nursing homes) or clinics, general "stretcher van" calls, calls to
locate any handheld electronic device not critical to health or life support,
calls to assist any person with normal daily living activities, or any
ambulance response to any frivolous non-emergency call for service that does
not involve any acute or critical or serious traumatic injury or ailment.
      The TFD can refuse to respond to any further calls for ambulance service
from or for any person that has been involved with one or more ambulance
service in non-emergency situations as aforesaid stated.
      8.   The patient who received the benefit of any TFD ambulance or
personnel services or for whom the ambulance response was made and his/her
spouse, guardian of the person and/or estate, power of attorney agent, trustee,
caretaker, heirs, administrators, executors, legal and/or personal
representatives shall be jointly and severally liable for and shall pay the
aforesaid applicable fees. All such fees shall be due and payable within thirty
(30) days of receipt of a bill from the City.
      9.   Ambulance fees shall be evaluated on an annual basis and adjusted if
deemed necessary by the City of Taylorville Emergency Services Committee.
   C.   Billing: Billing services will be provided by the City of Charleston
under the current intergovernmental agreement.
(Ord. 3558, 4-16-2012; amd. Ord. 3947, 3-16-2020; Ord. 4290, 1-21-2025)
4-1-16: NATIONAL FIRE PROTECTION ASSOCIATION CODE:
   A.   A copy of the NFPA 1, Fire Code - 2018 edition as published by the
National Fire Protection Association is on file with the City Clerk's Office.
Such NFPA 1 Fire Code - 2018 edition advances fire and life safety for the
public and first responders as well as property protection by providing a
comprehensive, integrated approach to Fire Code regulation and hazard
management.
   B.   To the extent not inconsistent with other applicable regulations in
this Code, such NFPA 1, Fire Code - 2018 edition is hereby adopted and
incorporated herein by reference thereto; and the terms and provisions of such
NFPA 1, Fire Code shall apply to and govern Fire Code regulation and hazard
management by the City's Fire Department. (Ord. 3853, 7-16-2018)
4-1-17: NON-MUNICIPAL OWNED ALS AMBULANCE SERVICE:
   A.   Definitions: For the purpose of this Section
4-1-17, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly
indicates or requires a different meaning:
      1.   ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT (ALS): A level of ambulance service also
referred to as Advanced EMT by the Illinois Emergency Medical Services (EMS)
systems under the Illinois Department of Public Health rules and regulations.
      2.   ALS AMBULANCE: A non-municipal owned ambulance that is licensed by
the State of Illinois to provide advanced life support services, but such ALS
ambulance shall not utilize the "In-Field Service Level Upgrade" option under
the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) rules and regulations.
      3.   OWNER/OPERATOR: An owner/operator of a non-municipal owned ambulance
company or entity that provides ALS ambulance services within the city and
within the Taylorville Fire Protection District.
      4.   CITY: The City of Taylorville, Illinois, a municipal corporation.
      5.   LICENSE: Written permission from the city to operate a non-municipal
ALS Ambulance service within the corporate limits of the city and of the
Taylorville Protection District.
   B.   License Required and Additional Requirements:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any owner/operator to operate any non-
municipal owned ambulance service within the city or within the Taylorville
Fire Protection District without having first obtained and operating under a
license issued from the city and which is in effect.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any owner/operator to violate any of the
terms or provisions of this section 4-1-17.
      3.   No license shall be issued to any owner/operator until and unless
the owner/operator meets and satisfies the minimum requirements set forth in
this section 4-1-17.
      4.   The form of the application for the license shall be on such form as
the city may approve from time to time; and the owner/operator shall provide
the city with all information required in such application.
      5.   As a condition of the license, the owner/operator shall comply with
any and all other city code provisions, ordinances, rules and regulations
relating to ambulance services and the operation of vehicles within the city as
are now in effect or as may be in effect from time to time hereafter.
      6.   As a further condition of the license, the owner/operator agrees to
and shall use it best efforts to provide a minimum of a ninety (90) day written
notice to the city prior to terminating its ALS Ambulance service in whole or
in part within the city and/or within the Taylorville Fire Protection District;
but in any event the owner/operator agrees to and shall provide minimum of a
sixty (60) day written notice to the city prior to terminating its ALS
Ambulance service in whole or in part within the city and/or within the
Taylorville Fire Protection District.
      7.   As a further condition of the license, the owner/operator agrees to
and shall provide ALS Ambulance services within the city and within the
Taylorville Fire Protection District.
      8.   As a further condition of the license, the owner/operator shall keep
their ambulance fleet records updated as ambulances are rotated out of ALS
Ambulance service.
      9.   The following additional requirements shall be met by the owner/
operator prior to the issuance of and as conditions for a License:
         a.   The owner/operator shall provide the city with the full legal
name and address of each individual shareholder, member, manager, partner and
person who owns an interest in and to the entity or entities (eq. a
corporation, limited liability company, limited partnership, limited liability
partnership, partnership, sole proprietorship, or other organization) formed by
the owner/operator to provide the ALS Ambulance services; and the trade names
under which the owner/operator intends to conduct the ALS Ambulance service
business.
         b.   The owner/operator shall provide the city with the following
information for each ambulance to operate under the license:
            (1)   Make;
            (2)   Model;
            (3)   Year of manufacture; and
            (4)   Current state license number.
         c.   The owner/operator shall provide the address of each facility
located within the city that will be used by the owner/operator to operate its
ambulance service under such license; and the owner/operator shall headquarter
its ambulance services, crews, and ambulances in a facility located within the
city.
         d.   The owner/operator shall have in effect at all times all licenses
and certifications required by the State of Illinois and the Illinois
Department of Public Health to operate an ALS Ambulance service; and the owner/
operator shall provide a copy of all such licenses and certifications to the
city at the time of application for a License, and within five (5) business
days of the owner/operator's receipt of each renewal license and/or
certification as the case may be from the appropriate licensing and/or
certifying entity or agency.
         e.   The owner/operator shall provide and maintain, twenty-four (24)
hours per day/ seven (7) days week/ three hundred sixty-five (365) days per
year, a minimum of one (1) ambulance in good operating condition at all times
that is fully equipped and licensed as required by the laws and regulations of
the State of Illinois and of the Illinois Department of Public Health for
operation of ambulance services and which is manned by qualified personnel at
all times who, as a minimum, meet the requirements and are duly licensed as
Advanced EMT under the laws and regulations of the State of Illinois and of the
Illinois Department of Public Health to provide Advance Life Support service.
Any additional ambulances that an owner/operator shall determine to immediately
operate 911 emergency calls under a license shall likewise meet the aforesaid
ambulance equipment, licensed manned personnel, and twenty-four/seven (24/7),
seven (7) days/week, three hundred sixty-five (365) days per year time
operational requirements. Each ALS Ambulance is required to be equipped and
staffed by personnel and shall meet the ALS level of ambulance service at all
times under the rules and regulations of the State of Illinois and of the
Illinois Department of Public Health in lieu of utilizing and shall not utilize
the "In-Field Service Level Upgrade" option under the Illinois Department of
Public Health (IDPH).
         f. The owner/operator shall provide such other operational information
that may be requested by the city from time to time. Any owner/operator
providing ALS Ambulance service as of May 1, 2019 will have the first annual
fee waived but shall be required to provide the city all required information
and documentation as set forth in this section 1-4-17 and obtain a license to
continue to operate an ALS Ambulance service within the city.
         g.   The owner/operator shall notify Christian County 911 every time
each of its ambulances goes in service or out of service. The owner/operator
shall maintain accurate records utilizing Christian County 911 dispatch times
for all calls generated through a 911 emergency response. Such records shall
include the calls for service received within the city and within the
Taylorville Fire Protection District, the number of cancelled calls, the
identification of the responding ambulance, and the names of the attendants
responding. Such records that reflect response times shall be available to the
city on a requested basis from time to time either in hard copy or other media.
Upon a five (5) calendar day written notice mailed to the owner/operator at the
address shown on the license, the city shall have the right to inspect, at any
time or times during normal business hours (i.e. between the hours of 9:00 a.m.
and 5:00 p.m. Monday thru Fridays of each week) the aforesaid records of the
owner/operator within the allowable limits of the Health Insurance Portability
and Accountability Act (HIPAA).
      10. The annual fee to apply for and/or for the issuance of the license
shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). Unless sooner revoked or terminated, a
license shall be valid for a period of three hundred sixty-five (365) days
following issuance of the license.
   C.   Rates and Charges:
      1.   The rates and charges for ambulance service under the license shall
be determined and collected by the owner/operator from time to time.
   D.   Penalty:
      1.   Any owner/operator found to have been in violation of any of the
terms and provisions of this section
4-1-17 shall be assessed a fine or penalty in an amount of not less than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense. Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues
shall be deemed to be a separate offense. A violation hereof may be established
by a preponderance of the evidence.
   2.   In addition to the fine and penalty as set forth in the preceding
subparagraph D.1. above, and not in lieu thereof, the Mayor may revoke the
license of an owner/operator or suspend such license for such time as he may
deem appropriate, all as determined from time to time by the Mayor in his sole
discretion. (Ord. 3896, 5-20-2019)
CHAPTER 2
GENERAL HEALTH AND SAFETY PROVISIONS
SECTION:
4-2-1: Contagious Diseases
4-2-2: Prohibited Acts Generally
4-2-3: Dense Smoke
4-2-4: Food Sales and Service
4-2-5: Cemeteries
4-2-6: Spitting
4-2-7: Penalty
4-2-1: CONTAGIOUS DISEASES:
   A.   Report Required: Every physician called in to care for or treat a
person afflicted with a contagious disease or epidemic disease shall make a
report of the same, within twenty four (24) hours after being called in, to the
Health and Building Officer. In case no physician is in attendance, it shall be
the duty of the person in charge of or having the care of such person to make a
report within twenty four (24) hours from the time the disease is recognized.
(1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. I, §1)
   B.   Quarantine:
      1.   The Health and Building Officer shall have charge of the enforcement
of the quarantine rules. 1  He shall have the power and authority to place any
premises within which a contagious or epidemic disease occurs under quarantine,
and the Health and Building Officer shall determine the time when the
quarantine shall end. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. I, §2)
      2.   Premises which have been quarantined in accordance with the terms of
subsection B above shall be thoroughly fumigated or otherwise freed from all
risk of contagious disease, under the supervision of the Health and Building
Officer before the quarantine shall end. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. I, §3)
      3.   No person engaged in the delivery of food or drink intended for
human consumption shall enter any premises which are quarantined because of the
existence of a contagious or epidemic disease. No containers or bottles shall
be removed from any such premises until the termination of the quarantine, and
no such container which has been left at such premises during the quarantine
shall be placed in use for carrying food or drink until it has been thoroughly
sterilized. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. I, §5)
   C.   Spreading Contagion: It shall be unlawful for any person to spread,
wilfully or carelessly, any contagious disease or to so cause the spread of the
same. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. I, §4)
   D.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this Section or
violating any of the reasonable rules of the Health and Building Officer with
regard to quarantined premises or disturbing or disregarding any notice of
quarantine placed by or under the direction of the Health and Building Officer
shall, for each offense, be punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. I, §6; 1991 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  2-10-2C of this Code.
4-2-2: PROHIBITED ACTS GENERALLY:
It shall be unlawful to commit or do any act which endangers the public health
or results in annoyance or discomfort to the public. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art.
III, §8)
4-2-3: DENSE SMOKE:
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from any
fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or any other agency in the City so as to
cause annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof.
For the purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke, the Ringelmann
Smoke Chart, as published and used by the United States Geological Survey,
shall be and is hereby adopted as a standard for such grading, and smoke shall
be and is hereby defined as and declared to be "dense" when it is of a degree
of density of number three (3) of said Chart, or greater, for more than six (6)
minutes in any one hour, whether such period of time is consecutive or not.
(1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. III, §12)
4-2-4: FOOD SALES AND SERVICE:
   A.   Unwholesome Food: It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any
unwholesome or polluted food or drink of any kind in the City. (1979 Code Ch.
16, Art. III, §1)
   B.   Premises: All premises used in the sale or storage of food or drink
intended for human consumption shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
Premises shall be kept free from flies and vermin of all kinds.
   C.   Employees: It shall be unlawful to permit any person who is afflicted
with a contagious disease to handle any food or drink intended for sale. (1979
Code Ch. 16, Art. III, §2)
   D.   Utensils: Utensils for personnel use in all places serving food or
drink to the public shall be thoroughly cleaned and sterilized after such
usage. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. III, §9)
   E.   Nudity in Places Serving Food and/or Beverages Prohibited:
      1.   Intent: The City Council hereby finds that the competitive
commercial exploitation of nudity is adverse to the public health, safety,
morals and welfare and that it is in the best interests of the public health,
safety, morals and welfare to restrict such nudity in places serving food and/
or beverages in an effort to suppress disease.
      2.   Purpose: The purpose of this subsection E is to proscribe conduct
which encourages competitive commercial exploitation of nudity, in places
serving food and/or beverages, where such conduct is not related to any live
artistic performance or entertainment which may be protected by the United
States and Illinois constitutional provisions guaranteeing freedom and
expression.
      3.   Definitions:
   ESTABLISHMENT: Every kind of establishment where members of the public are
served food and/or beverages for consumption on the premises.
   FOOD: Any raw, cooked or processed edible substance, ice, beverage including
liquor or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in whole or in part
for human consumption.
   PERSON: An individual, firm, partnership, corporation, association, joint
stock company, joint venture or any other private legal entity.
   THEATER: A building, playhouse, room, hall or other place having permanently
affixed seats so arranged that a body of spectators can have an unobstructed
view of the stage, upon which theatrical or vaudeville performances or similar
forms of artistic expression are presented, and where such performances are not
incidental to the promoting of the sale of food, drink or other merchandise.
      4.   Conduct Prohibited:
         a.   It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning or
operating an establishment as defined herein to permit, allow, require or
otherwise direct any person, while selling food and/or beverages to any
customer, or while seating or directing customers to seats within any
establishment, to expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic hair region or
buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, where
the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering.
         b.   It shall be unlawful for any person while serving food and/or
beverages, or while seating or directing customers to seats within any
establishment as defined herein to expose his or her genitals, pubic hair,
pubic hair region or buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top
of the areola, where the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque
covering.
         c.   It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning or
operating an establishment as defined herein to suffer, permit, require or
otherwise direct any person, while such person is mingling, coming in contact
with, or likely to come into contact with, or in close proximity to customers
of said establishment, within areas where food and/or beverages is served, to
expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic hair region or buttocks, or any
portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, where the areola and
nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering.
         d.   It shall be unlawful for any person while mingling, coming in
contact with, or likely to come in contact with, or in close proximity to
customers of an establishment within areas where food and/or beverages is
served, to expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic hair region, or
buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, where
the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering.
         e.   The provisions of subsections c and d of subsection E4 herein
shall not apply to persons participating in any live act, exhibition or
performance upon a stage at least eighteen inches (18") above the immediate
floor level and removed at least six feet (6') from the nearest patron.
      5.   Exemption of Theatrical Establishment: The provision of this
subsection E shall not apply to any exhibition, presentation, showing or
performance in any theater which is principally devoted to theatrical
performances.
      6.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any provision of this
subsection E shall be fined in an amount not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 2464, 6-
15-92)
4-2-5: CEMETERIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or enlarge a cemetery or, in
the City, to bury any person within the City limits or within a mile thereof
except in an established cemetery. 1  (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. III, §6)
 
Notes
1 1. See also Section
  7-3-7 of this Code; see Title 8, Chapter 3 of this Code.
4-2-6: SPITTING:
   It shall be unlawful to spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk or street
or other public place or on the floor or walls of any store, theater, hall,
public vehicle or other place frequented by the public or to which the public
is invited. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. III, §11)
4-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall, for each
offense, be punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE AND REFUSE 1
SECTION:
4-3-1: Prohibited Accumulations
4-3-2: Storage Of Garbage And Refuse
4-3-3: Prohibited Deposits
4-3-4: Combustible Refuse
4-3-5: Open Burning Of Refuse
4-3-6: Forbidding Scavenging And Dumping At Roll-Off Box Sites
4-3-7: Regulation Of Deposit Of Garbage And Refuse At Street Department
Facility
4-3-8: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See also Section
  7-3-3 of this Code for Lake Taylorville provisions.
4-3-1: PROHIBITED ACCUMULATIONS:
   A.   Duty Of Occupant: It shall be the duty and obligation of every occupant
of any premises in the City to see to the removal of all garbage and other
refuse from his premises or alleyway either by removing it himself to some
authorized dumping grounds or by having it removed by private scavenger 1 .
   B.   Duty Of Owners: It shall be illegal for owner of real estate to refuse
or neglect to remove trash and other debris on his property. Such trash and
debris is defined to include, but not be limited to, paper cartons, boxes,
barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood or metal
furniture, bedding, metals, tin cans, dirt, rock, pieces of concrete, glass,
crockery, other mineral waste, street rubbish, street sweepings, dirt, leaves,
catch basin dirt, contents of litter receptacles, solid wastes from industrial
operations, food processing wastes, boiler house cinders, unusable or rotting
lumber, scraps or shavings.
   C.   Removal By City; Payment Of Costs And Expenses: If an occupant or owner
refuses or neglects to remove or cause to be removed such garbage, trash,
refuse, debris, grass, leaves, branches, offal, carcasses, or other things
described in subsections
4-3-1A and B, and Sections
4-3-3 and
4-3-4 of this Chapter following a seventy two (72) hour written notice issued
by the City's Health and Building Officer or his representative, then the City
may remove or cause to be removed same at the expense of the occupant and/or
owner. Such occupant and/or owner shall be liable for and immediately pay to
the City the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) or an amount equal to the costs and
expenses incurred by the City to remove same, whichever amount is greater. Such
costs and expenses if not paid may be recovered by the City against such
occupant and/or owner in any civil action or ordinance violation proceedings in
a court of competent jurisdiction. Such occupant and/or owner shall, in
addition thereto and at the election of the City's Health and Building Officer
or his representative, be subject to the penalty provisions as set forth in
Section
 4-3-8 of this Chapter.
   D.   Notice Of Lien:
      1.   If the City removes or causes the removal of such items by virtue of
any owner's refusal or neglect to remove same following such seventy two (72)
hour notice to do so in accordance with subsection C above, then the City,
following a thirty (30) day notice to such owner, may cause a notice of lien of
the unpaid cost and expense thereof incurred by the City to be recorded in the
office of the Recorder of Deeds of Christian County, Illinois against the
owner's property. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting
out: 1) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof,
2) the amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable
for the service, and 3) the date or dates when said cost and expense was
incurred by the City, and such notice of lien shall be filed within sixty (60)
days after the cost and expense are incurred. Such lien may be enforced in
accordance with the Illinois Compiled Statutes in such case made and provided.
      2.   A copy of the notice of lien may be delivered to the owner
personally, or may be mailed to the owner at his last known place of residence,
or may be posted on the owner's property. Service of a copy of said notice of
lien by any of the foregoing methods of service shall constitute notice to the
owner of such lien.
      3.   Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien is filed,
the lien shall be released by the City, and a release shall be filed of record
in the same manner as filing of the notice of said lien. (Ord. 2509, 10-18-93)
 
Notes
1 2. See Title 3, Chapter 11 of this Code.
4-3-2: STORAGE OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE:
   A.   Receptacles:
      1.   It shall be the duty of every owner or his agent or occupant of any
house, building, flat or apartment or tenement in the City where people reside,
board or lodge or where animal or vegetable matter is prepared or served, at
all times, to maintain in good order and repair a separate can for garbage and
a separate receptacle for tin cans, bottles, ashes and similar refuse; it shall
be the duty of every such occupant to deposit nothing but garbage or paper in
the container provided for the same and nothing but tin cans or bottles in the
receptacles provided for the same. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. II, § 1)
      2.   A receptacle for ashes, tin cans and bottles shall be either of
metal, wood or cement, and such receptacle shall have a capacity of not less
than ten (10) gallons. No hot ashes shall be placed in any such receptacle.
(1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. II, § 3)
   B.   Wrapping Garbage: It shall be the duty of every occupant to adequately
wrap all garbage before placing same in a watertight container provided for the
same. All garbage shall be wrapped in a watertight container to prevent any
leakage. (1979 Code Ch. 16, Art. II, § 2)
4-3-3: PROHIBITED DEPOSITS:
   A.   No garbage, refuse, trash, or litter shall be deposited in any street,
roadway, sidewalk, alley, or public way, excepting as is provided in this
chapter. Notwithstanding section
4-3-8 of this chapter, any person found guilty of violating this section shall
be fined an amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first offense, an
amount of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the second offense, and seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for the third offense and any subsequent offenses; and in
addition to said fine and not in lieu thereof, the offending party shall be
ordered to perform some reasonable public service work such as, but not limited
to, the picking up of litter in public parks, along public highways, around the
downtown square area or the maintenance of public facilities. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each time garbage, refuse, trash, or litter
is deposited in violation of this section. (Ord. 3169, 4-19-2004)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or deposit or cause to be
dumped or deposited any grass, leaves, branches or any other things in the
roadway or gutter of any public street in the city. (1979 Code § 24-4-22)
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit anywhere in the city any
uncovered piles of garbage, offal or carcasses of dead animals; such refuse
shall not be burned or buried within the city. (1979 Code § 16-3-5)
4-3-4: COMBUSTIBLE REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful to permit or store any combustible refuse in such a way as
to create a fire hazard or to store or throw away any refuse of any kind in any
alley, street or other public place in the city. (1979 Code § 24-4-11)
4-3-5: OPEN BURNING OF REFUSE 1 :
The outdoor burning of refuse, including, but not limited to, paint, oil,
automobiles, tires, plastics, building materials, debris or any other noxious
combustible material, within the boundaries of the city is hereby prohibited.
(1979 Code § 23-6-1)
 
Notes
  1. See also chapter 7 of this title for open burning regulations; see also
1 section
  7-4-1 of this code.
4-3-6: FORBIDDING SCAVENGING AND DUMPING AT ROLL-OFF BOX SITES:
   A.   Definitions:
   ILLEGAL DUMP OR ILLEGAL DUMPING: The placement of any solid waste (which is
not an approved recyclable) in or around the site of any roll-off container
provided by the county of Christian for recycling activities or any recycling
container approved by the city.
   RECYCLABLE(S): Any of the following: "PETE", "HDPE", aluminum, bimetal cans,
tin/steel cans, newsprint, corrugated cardboard, clear glass and brown glass or
any other recyclable materials approved by the city.
   ROLL-OFF CONTAINER: That container provided by the county of Christian and
the state of Illinois, department of energy and natural resources for the
collection of recyclables and/or any recycling container approved by the city;
and the site upon which it is placed in Taylorville, Illinois.
   SCAVENGE OR SCAVENGING: To collect, obtain, possess or pick up any
recyclable item from within the roll-off containers or from the site of the
roll-off containers.
   SOLID WASTE: All materials other than the recyclables defined herein.
   B.   Enforcement:
      1.   Scavenging: It shall be a violation for any person or persons to
scavenge any recyclable or recyclables from the roll-off containers or from the
site of the roll-off container.
      2.   Illegal Dumping: It shall be a violation for any person or persons
to illegally dump in any roll-off container or on the site of any roll-off
container.
      3.   Notice: Those recyclables which are accepted for deposit shall be
clearly marked on or near the roll-off container and "no dumping" signs shall
also be posted.
   C.   Hours Of Operation: The hours of operation of the roll-off container
and site shall be as determined by the Taylorville city council from time to
time. (Ord. 2539, 3-21-1994)
4-3-7: REGULATION OF DEPOSIT OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE AT STREET DEPARTMENT
FACILITY:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided herein, and subject to the rules and
regulations set forth in this section, any bona fide City resident is permitted
to deposit such City resident's residential household garbage and refuse in the
designated receptacles located at the street department facility at 205 North
Cherokee Street, in Taylorville, Illinois, from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to
three o'clock (3:00) P.M., Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday of each week
during which said street department facility is open for business. Dumping is
not allowed on these days when the trash container is too full as determined by
the attendant on duty or when the trash container has been removed by the
disposal company to empty and return. Contractors shall not be allowed to use
this garbage and refuse service. Any resident wishing to deposit household
garbage and refuse in the designated receptacles located at the street
department facility as otherwise set forth herein, shall pay the following
fees: one dollar ($1.00) for each individual plastic trash bag deposited; and
two dollars ($2.00) for each mattress or box spring or carpet roll deposited;
and five dollars ($5.00) for each item of furniture or large item or large
article deposited.
   B.   Furniture, overstuffed chairs, couches, mattresses, box springs, and
carpet (if rolled and secured) will be accepted for deposit subject to the
aforesaid applicable fee for each such item.
   C.   The following items shall not be accepted for deposit in the dumpsters
and not accepted at the street department facility: televisions, lumber,
drywall, pallets, shingles, bricks, concrete or any other construction or
building materials or waste, paint, used oil, gasoline, petroleum products,
hazardous wastes, tires, or railroad ties.
   D.   Shrubs, vegetation, trees, bushes, large and small twigs, limbs, grass,
leaves, weeds, and small garden or flower plants will be accepted in the yard
waste bin at no charge.
   E.   Scrap metal will be accepted in the scrap metal bin at no charge.
However, no appliances containing or having contained freon, including, but not
limited to, refrigerators, freezers, air conditioners, etc., will be accepted.
   F.   All residential household garbage and refuse acceptable for deposit
shall be contained within plastic trash bags (securely closed) and no such
loose garbage and refuse shall be accepted.
   G.   Such permitted garbage and refuse shall be deposited by such city
resident in the appropriate designated receptacles at such street department
facility.
   H.   Any person desiring to deposit such permitted garbage and refuse shall
submit proof to the city's attendant at such street department facility that
such person is a city resident. Such proof shall consist of a current driver's
license exhibiting a current city residence, or a current city residential real
estate tax bill.
   I.   There shall be no refunds given to any persons who previously purchased
any garbage and refuse stickers from the city.
   J.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, for
each offense, be punished and fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
(Ord. 3484, 8-30-2010; amd. Ord. 4020, 2-16-2021)
4-3-8: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided, any person violating any of the provisions of this
chapter shall, for each offense, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2539, 3-21-1994)
CHAPTER 4
NUISANCES
SECTION:
4-4-1: Nuisances Declared Unlawful
4-4-2: Nuisances Defined, Generally
4-4-3: General Enforcement
4-4-4: Enumeration Not Exclusive
4-4-5: Duty Of City Officers To Investigate; Power Of Entry
4-4-6: Notice To Proper Officials
4-4-7: Foul Odors, Filth
4-4-8: Rubbish, Dry Grass
4-4-9: Petroleum Products, Explosives
4-4-10: Unsafe Buildings
4-4-11: Abandoned Refrigerators
4-4-12: Dust, Cinders
4-4-13: Scaffolding, Ladders
4-4-13-1: Neglected Property
4-4-14: Notice To Abate Nuisance
4-4-15: Duty To Abate; Time Limits
4-4-16: Failure To Abate; Separate And Recurring Offense; Penalty
4-4-17: Abatement By City
4-4-18: Summary Abatement By City; Emergency; Public Property
4-4-19: Costs Of Abatement; Debt Of Owner
4-4-1: NUISANCES DECLARED UNLAWFUL 1 :
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to wilfully
or negligently create, erect, maintain or permit a nuisance to exist anywhere
within the city. (1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2.
4-4-2: NUISANCES DEFINED, GENERALLY:
Any thing, act, omission, occupation or condition which shall exist or continue
for such a length of time as to:
   A.   Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the health, safety, peace or
welfare of the public; or
   B.   In any way render the public insecure in life or property; or
   C.   Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or
   D.   Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or render
dangerous for passage any street, sidewalk, alley, navigable body or other
public way or place;
is hereby declared a nuisance. (1993 Code)
4-4-3: GENERAL ENFORCEMENT:
Any nuisance declared by statute, this chapter or other provisions of this code
or ordinances of the city shall be enforceable under the provisions of this
chapter as if enumerated specifically herein. (1993 Code)
4-4-4: ENUMERATION NOT EXCLUSIVE:
Nuisances enumerated in this chapter shall not be deemed exclusive, but are in
addition to and shall be construed in conjunction with any other nuisances
enumerated in statutes or other provisions of this code or ordinances of the
city. (1993 Code)
4-4-5: DUTY OF CITY OFFICERS TO INVESTIGATE; POWER OF ENTRY:
   A.   For the purpose of discovering nuisances, it shall be the duty of the
police, fire, health and building officers and inspectors to investigate,
confirm and report any nuisances coming to their attention.
   B.   In order to investigate, confirm and report nuisances, said officers
and inspectors shall, upon proper identification, be permitted at any
reasonable hour and in a reasonable manner, to visit and enter into or upon any
premises or property within the city to make an examination thereof, if they
shall have reasonable grounds to believe that a nuisance exists. (1993 Code)
4-4-6: NOTICE TO PROPER OFFICIALS:
Whenever any nuisance shall be reported to or investigated and determined by
the police, fire, health or building officers or inspectors, notice shall be
given to the owner or person in control of the property or premises involved,
and to the appropriate city officials whose functions include the abatement of
such nuisances. (1993 Code)
4-4-7: FOUL ODORS, FILTH 1 :
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a danger to the health, safety,
welfare, peace and comfort of the city and its residents for any person:
   A.   Businesses: To conduct any business or to use any premises so as to
create an offensive or foul odor which taints the air and renders it nauseous
to persons in the vicinity; or
   B.   Animals 2 : To keep or maintain any animals in an unclean or filthy
manner or surroundings, or to keep or maintain any animals from which emit any
particularly foul or offensive odors; or
   C.   Animal Carcasses, Offal: To cause or permit to be collected or to
remain upon any premises or place any animal carcass or any offal, filth,
excretion or other noisome or noxious animal matter of any kind which is, or is
likely to become, putrid, foul or offensive; or
   D.   Vegetable Matter: To cause or permit to be collected or to remain upon
any premises or place any slop or other vegetable matter of any kind which is
or is likely to become putrid, foul or offensive; or
   E.   Cellars, Vaults, Privies: To cause or permit any cellar, vault,
cistern, drain, privy, yard or other premises whatsoever to become, from any
cause, foul or offensive or injurious to the public health; or
   F.   Stagnant Water: To permit to be collected or to stand upon any premises
any foul or stagnant water of any kind; or
   G.   Pigsties: To locate or maintain, or permit to exist or remain anywhere
within the city any pigsty; or
   H.   Foul Or Noxious Substances: To use, deposit or keep any property,
substance or thing emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous
or noxious odor, effluvia or stench particularly repulsive to the physical
senses and which annoys, discomforts or endangers the welfare, health or safety
of any person. (1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2.
2 1. See title 5, chapter 3 of this code for animal regulations.
4-4-8: RUBBISH, DRY GRASS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and health and a nuisance
for any person to cause or permit:
   A.   Rubbish, Rags: The deposit or accumulation of any refuse, oily rags,
rubbish or other materials or substances of any kind, so as to constitute a
fire hazard; or
   B.   Dry Grass, Vegetation: The deposit, accumulation, existence or growth
upon any property of any dry or dead weeds, grass, vegetation or other like
substances of any kind, so as to constitute a fire hazard. (1993 Code)
4-4-9: PETROLEUM PRODUCTS, EXPLOSIVES:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit:
   A.   Petroleum Products: The accumulation or storage, within one hundred
(100) yards of any building occupied as a residence or business, other than a
licensed gasoline service station, of any petroleum, naphtha, benzine, coal
oil, gasoline, kerosene, turpentine or other petroleum products or inflammable
substances of any kind, in quantities greater than fifty (50) gallons, except
for heating oil or propane; or
   B.   Explosives: The deposit, accumulation, storage or presence, within one
hundred (100) yards of any building occupied as a residence or business, of any
powder magazine, nitroglycerin, dynamite or other explosive substance of any
kind. (1993 Code)
4-4-10: UNSAFE BUILDINGS 1 :
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit the existence of any unsafe, dilapidated or otherwise
insecure building, wall, stack, chimney, cornice, sign, awning or other like
structure of any kind which, from manner of construction, age, condition or
other circumstances, is or may become a menace to the safety of persons or
property. (1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1.
4-4-11: ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS 1 :
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to permit the existence or storage in any place accessible to children
of any abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox, ice chest, deep freeze or
other airtight appliance or container of any kind, of a capacity of one and
one- half (11/2) cubic feet or more, from which the lids, doors or other covers
have not been removed, or which cannot be easily opened by a child, by means of
pushing only, from the inside thereof. (1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 2. 430 ILCS 150/1.
4-4-12: DUST, CINDERS:
   A.   It is hereby declared a menace to the public health and a nuisance for
any person to cause or permit any operations that allow any dirt, sand, gravel,
cinders, ashes, earth or other similar materials to be hauled, moved, rolled,
compacted, scraped, dragged or otherwise disturbed, so as to cause or permit
dust to be raised, blown or stirred through the operation of machinery or
otherwise, to the detriment of any person or property.
   B.   Every person engaged in the hauling of any sand, dirt, cinders, ashes,
earth or other similar materials or substances, or engaged in the moving,
rolling, compacting, scraping, dragging or other disturbance of soil, and the
like, shall make adequate provision as often as is required to arrest and
prevent such dust through the use of salts, oil, chemicals and other materials
used and recommended for retarding or eliminating such dust, subject to the
supervision and approval of the city. (1993 Code)
4-4-13: SCAFFOLDING, LADDERS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person:
   A.   To erect or use, or to cause or permit to be erected or used, any
insecure or unsafe scaffold or ladder whereby the safety of persons working
thereon or passing thereunder may in any way be endangered.
   B.   To place or leave, or to cause or permit to be placed or left, any
tools or articles on any such scaffold or ladder in such manner that the same
may fall into any street, sidewalk or other public way, whereby the safety of
persons passing thereunder may in any way be endangered. (1993 Code)
4-4-13-1: NEGLECTED PROPERTY:
   A.   It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for
any person to own or occupy or possess or maintain any "neglected" property as
that term is defined under the international property maintenance code (2009
edition).
   B.   Each violation of the international property maintenance code (2009
edition) is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance. (Ord.
3702, 4-6-2015)
4-4-14: NOTICE TO ABATE NUISANCE 1 :
   A.   Whenever any health or building official or inspector, or any police or
fire officer determines that a nuisance exists on any private property or
premises, the proper city official shall cause a written notice to be served
personally upon the owner or person in control of the property or premises who
is causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance, which notice shall give
the person served five (5) days from the date of service of the notice to abate
the nuisance. Such notice shall be by means of personal service of a copy of
the complaint or by certified or registered mail of a copy of the complaint.
Personal service shall be by the zoning officer, animal control officer or by
any police officer of the police department or any person authorized by law to
make personal service. (1993 Code)
   B.   Such notice shall fairly apprise such person of the nature of the
nuisance, his duty to abate or remove the nuisance within the time provided
therein, the penalty for failure to abate the same, and shall state that, if
said nuisance is abated by the city, liability for necessary expenses to be
incurred shall accrue as provided for in section
4-4-16 of this chapter. (1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2.
4-4-15: DUTY TO ABATE; TIME LIMITS:
It is hereby declared the duty of any person determined to have created,
caused, erected, maintained or permitted a nuisance to exist within the city to
discontinue and abate such nuisance within five (5) days, or such other time
period as may be specified in the notice, from the time he receives written
notice thereof. (1993 Code)
4-4-16: FAILURE TO ABATE; SEPARATE AND RECURRING OFFENSE; PENALTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to
neglect, refuse or otherwise fail to remove or abate any nuisance after
expiration of the five (5) days or other specified time period provided by
notice thereof; and each twenty four (24) hours, or fraction thereof, during
which such nuisance continues or exists shall be deemed a separate offense.
   B.   Any person who shall cause, permit or allow a nuisance to continue or
exist as provided for in subsection A of this section shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to a penalty of not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each such offense. (1993 Code)
4-4-17: ABATEMENT BY CITY:
Whenever any nuisance is not abated by the owner, lessee or person in control
of the premises or property affected within the time provided by notice, the
proper city officer shall cause the abatement or removal of such nuisance.
(1993 Code)
4-4-18: SUMMARY ABATEMENT BY CITY; EMERGENCY; PUBLIC PROPERTY:
Whenever any nuisance: a) constitutes or is deemed to be an imminent or
immediate danger to the public health or safety, or b) exists on public
property, the proper city officer shall cause such nuisance to be summarily and
immediately abated and removed, regardless of any five (5) days or other time
period specified by notice to the person responsible therefor; provided,
however, that in situation a) in this paragraph, such officer shall have first
applied for and obtained the written permission of the mayor for such summary
abatement. (1993 Code)
4-4-19: COSTS OF ABATEMENT; DEBT OF OWNER:
   A.   Any costs or expenses of abatement reasonably incurred by the city
pursuant to the provisions of sections
4-4-17 and
4-4-18 of this chapter shall be deemed a debt to the city by the owner, lessee
or person in control of premises upon which such nuisance existed; provided,
that where specifically provided in this code or by statute 1 , such costs and
expenses shall become a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all
other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the city attorney to enforce by civil action
any and all such debts or liens as provided in subsection A of this section.
(1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7, 5/11-20-8, 5/11-20-12, 5/11-31-1.
CHAPTER 4A
ABANDONED BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-4A-1: Purpose
4-4A-2: Definitions
4-4A-3: Registration Permit Required
4-4A-4: Registration Permit; Expiration And Fees
4-4A-5: Information Required For Registration Permit
4-4A-6: Enclosure Permit For Abandoned Buildings; Enclosure Permit Fee;
Enclosure Requirements; And Remedies
4-4A-7: Building Plan
4-4A-8: Approval Or Modification Of Building Plan
4-4A-9: Failure To Comply With Building Plan
4-4A-10: Change Of Ownership
4-4A-11: Compliance With Other City Code Provisions Or Applicable Law
4-4A-12: Penalty
4-4A-1: PURPOSE:
   A.   The purpose of this Chapter is to protect the public health, safety,
and welfare by establishing a process for the registration and abatement of
certain abandoned buildings that are hereby declared public nuisances.
   B.   Abandoned buildings are hereby declared a public nuisance that
adversely affects surrounding property values and the public health, safety and
welfare.
   C.   Owners of abandoned buildings are required to register and enclose such
buildings and to implement a building plan for the maintenance of such
buildings and to remedy any Taylorville City Code violations and to prevent
deterioration, unsightly blight, and consequent adverse impact on the value of
nearby property. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
   ABANDONED BUILDING:
   A.   Vacant: Any building that is vacant or not occupied by any individual
for at least ninety (90) days in any one hundred eighty (180) consecutive day
period; or
   B.   Tax Delinquent: Any property upon which the building is situated that
has been tax delinquent for two (2) or more years; or
   C.   Water Bill Outstanding: The bills for water service for the property
upon which the building is situated have been outstanding for two (2) or more
years; or
   D.   Open To Trespass: Any building open to trespass.
   E.   Exceptions: The following building descriptions are exceptions to the
definition of an "abandoned building" and shall not be considered an "abandoned
building" for purposes of this Chapter:
      1.   A building under construction, repair, alteration, or a remodeling
project and which has a valid City building permit for such construction,
repair, alteration, or remodeling work.
      2.   A building owned (and not leased to any other person) by the City or
by the Taylorville community school district or by the State of Illinois or by
any taxing entity or by any political subdivision thereof of any such entity.
      3.   A building that is temporarily or permanently vacant or not occupied
by any individual but is otherwise properly maintained in accordance with and
not in violation of any applicable provisions of this Code relating to
buildings, including, but not limited to, Titles 3, 4, 9, and 10 thereof.
   BUILDING: A structure of any kind, nature or extent whatsoever and used or
not used for any purpose whatsoever, including, but not limited to, for
residential, commercial or industrial purposes.
   BUILDING OFFICIAL: The Health and Building Officer and Animal Control
Officer or his or her designated representative or designee.
   BUILDING OPEN TO TRESPASS: Any building or part thereof which is unoccupied
by any individual and/or that is in such a condition so as to allow entry
without the use of keys or special tools by an unauthorized person, or by
animals or fowl.
   CITY: The City of Taylorville, Illinois, a municipal corporation.
   COMPOSTED: A controlled biological reduction or composting of organic wastes
to humus.
   GARBAGE: Any organic waste material including, but not limited to, unused
food and food residue.
   INFESTATION: The presence, within or contiguous to, a structure or premises
of insects, rats, vermin, or other pests.
   LITTER: Any discarded, used or unused substance or waste. "Litter" may
include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish,
yard waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers, or
other packaging material, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, carcass of a
dead animal, any nauseous or offensive matter of any kind, any object likely to
injure any person or create a traffic hazard, or anything else of an unsightly
or unsanitary nature, which has been discarded, abandoned, or otherwise
disposed of improperly.
   MANTRAP: Existing conditions that unreasonably endanger the life or well
being of a firefighter or other authorized personnel in the event he/she is
called on to extinguish a fire or to respond to any other emergency.
   OCCUPANT: Any person legally occupying, living or sleeping in a building or
having possession of a space within a building.
   OWNER: Each and every person, mortgagee, lienholder of record (except the
City), agent, operator, firm, entity or corporation of any kind, nature, or
extent whatsoever having a legal or equitable interest in a property; or
recorded in the official records of the State, County, or City as holding title
to a property; or otherwise having control or possession of the property,
including the guardian of an estate of any such person, and the executor or
administrator or legal representative of the estate of a deceased person if
ordered to take possession of real property by a court, and a mortgagee of the
property. All such persons and entities shall be jointly and severally deemed
an "owner" for purposes of this Chapter.
   PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, financial institution, mortgagee, lienholder,
association, joint stock company, trust, estate, or any other legal entity,
guardian of the person and/or estate of a minor or of a disabled person, an
executor, administrator, independent representative of the estate of a deceased
person, the heirs of law of an intestate or testate decedent, or their
respective legal representatives, agents or assigns.
   PREMISES OR PROPERTY: A lot, plot or parcel of land including the building
or structures thereon.
   RUBBISH: Inorganic waste material including, but not limited to, metal and
glass.
   SOLID WASTE OR REFUSE: Putrescible and nonputrescible wastes including, but
not limited to, garbage, rubbish, dead animals, animal offal, animal feces,
human wastes, abandoned vehicles, machinery components, construction or
demolition debris, and yard wastes unless composted.
   WEEDS OR GRASS: Weeds, grass, brush, wildings, second growth, or vegetation
that is not cultivated, growing upon property to a height of eight inches (8")
or greater.
   YARD WASTE: Leaves, grass, clippings, garden debris, and brush. (Ord. 3667,
5-5-2014; amd. Ord. 3797, 3-6-2017)
4-4A-3: REGISTRATION PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   An owner of an abandoned building shall apply for in writing, obtain
and pay for a registration permit and an enclosure permit from the City within
fifteen (15) days after a notice to register is sent by the Building Official
to an owner of the abandoned building.
   B.   The notice to register shall contain at least the following
information:
      1.   The street address of the abandoned building or a description
sufficient for identification.
      2.   A statement requiring an owner to register such abandoned building
with the City within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of the notice to register
and to obtain an enclosure permit and enclose the abandoned building and to
submit a building plan all in compliance with this Chapter.
      3.   A statement requiring an owner to contact the Building Official
prior to the completion of the enclosure in order to schedule an inspection.
      4.   A statement whereby an owner's building plan shall include an
agreement that an owner shall be responsible and liable for maintaining the
property free of any garbage, infestation, litter, refuse, rubbish, solid
waste, brush, weeds and grass that exceed eight inches (8") in height, yard
waste, stumps, roots, or dead or dying trees.
   C.   Service of the notice to register shall be sent by mail to an owner at
an owner's last known address, or to the name of the person(s) in whose name
the real estate was last assessed at the address to which said assessment was
last forwarded. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-4: REGISTRATION PERMIT; EXPIRATION AND FEES:
   A.   The fees for the registration permit for each abandoned building shall
be as follows:
      1.   For the first ninety (90) consecutive days following issuance of the
registration permit, the registration fee shall be three hundred dollars
($300.00) for an abandoned building consisting of less than twenty thousand
(20,000) square feet and six hundred dollars ($600.00) for an abandoned
building consisting of more than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet.
      2.   For each subsequent ninety (90) consecutive day period, the
registration fee for the same abandoned building shall be seven hundred dollars
($700.00) for an abandoned building consisting of less than twenty thousand
(20,000) square feet and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for an abandoned
building consisting of more than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet.
   B.   The initial registration and each subsequent registration shall be
valid for a period of ninety (90) consecutive days provided the applicable
registration fee has been fully paid by an owner.
   C.   The initial registration fee is due and payable by an owner at the time
of the application for the registration permit; and each subsequent
registration fee is due and payable by an owner prior to the expiration of the
previous ninety (90) consecutive day registration period.
   D.   If at the end of any ninety (90) consecutive day registration period
the Building Official determines that such building is no longer an abandoned
building, then an owner will not be required to pay the next registration fee
for such building.
   E.   Before a registration permit or an enclosure permit is issued and from
time to time after a registration permit or an enclosure permit is issued an
inspection or inspections may be conducted by the Building Official and by any
other City official deemed necessary by the Building Official to determine
whether any violations of this Code exist concerning the abandoned building or
the property where it is located. If an owner or occupant of an abandoned
building refuses to allow any inspection or reinspection to be conducted, an
administrative search warrant may be requested from a circuit court of
competent jurisdiction upon a showing of probable cause that a City Code
violation exists concerning the abandoned building or the property where it is
located.
   F.   Once such building has been registered, an owner shall obtain a
certificate of occupancy in the manner set forth in Section
10-9-3 of this Code prior to any occupancy of the registered building.
   G.   After a building has been registered, or required to be registered
hereunder, an owner shall be required to either demolish the abandoned building
or obtain a city permit sufficient to obtain a certificate of occupancy within
one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days following issuance of the notice to
register.
   H.   Any owner who does not obtain such certificate of occupancy permit or
fails to demolish such building within said one hundred eighty (180)
consecutive day period shall be subject to fines and penalties as stated in
section
4-4A-12 of this chapter.
   I.   Each abandoned building that has been registered, or is required to be
registered hereunder, under this chapter shall be listed on the city's website,
which listing shall include the address of such building and the name of the
record owner of the property on which such building is located.
   J.   All registration fees are nonrefundable. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-5: INFORMATION REQUIRED FOR REGISTRATION PERMIT:
The registration permit application shall contain the following information:
   A.   Name, address, and telephone number of owner.
   B.   If an owner resides outside of Christian County, Illinois, then as a
condition for issuance of the registration permit, an owner shall provide the
name, address, and telephone number of an authorized agent who shall be a
natural person, twenty one (21) years of age or older, who resides in Christian
County, Illinois, and who has the written authority by the owner to receive all
notices of code violations and service of process of court or administrative
enforcement proceedings on behalf of an owner.
   C.   Name, address, and telephone number of all persons with any legal
interest in the property, building and premises.
   D.   Legal description from the deed of conveyance and the tax parcel
identification number of the premises on which such building is situated.
   E.   The common address of such building.
   F.   Date on which such building became abandoned.
   G.   The building plan proposed by an owner of the abandoned building. (Ord.
3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-6: ENCLOSURE PERMIT FOR ABANDONED BUILDINGS; ENCLOSURE PERMIT FEE;
ENCLOSURE REQUIREMENTS; AND REMEDIES:
   A.   Subject to subsection
4-4A-8B of this chapter, each abandoned building shall be enclosed by an owner
thereof within thirty (30) days after issuance of the enclosure permit for that
abandoned building; and no person shall enclose any building without first
obtaining an enclosure permit from the city.
   B.   All applications for enclosure permits and any renewals or extensions
of enclosure permits are subject to approval by the building official.
   C.   The fee for an enclosure permit shall be three hundred dollars
($300.00).
   D.   An owner shall enclose an abandoned building in accordance with the
following requirements:
      1.   Unless otherwise approved in writing by the building official or by
his designee in their sole discretion, all windows and doors shall be covered
with minimum of one-half inch (1/2") exterior grade plywood or other similar
material. The covering shall be a single sheet cut to fit each opening and
nailed and screwed from the exterior so that the covering cannot easily be
removed.
      2.   All other exterior openings allowing entry of fowl or animals shall
be covered from the exterior with a minimum of one-half inch (1/2") exterior
grade plywood or a maximum of one-half inch (1/2") mesh screening or other
similar material.
      3.   Unless otherwise approved in writing by the building official or his
designee in their sole discretion, water and gas service to the building shall
be disconnected; and electrical service to the building shall be disconnected
at the pole, transformer, or distribution can.
      4.   Any and all garbage, rubbish, litter, solid waste, and infestation
shall be removed from the interior and exterior of the property.
      5.   All mantraps existing within the building shall be covered or
repaired.
      6.   The storage of any other materials in or on the interior or exterior
of the property shall be in accordance with any and all written specifications
as determined by the building official in his or her sole discretion.
      7.   The property owner shall call the building official prior to
completion of enclosure in order to schedule a compliance inspection.
   E.   If an owner of an abandoned building fails to obtain a registration
permit or fails to obtain an enclosure permit in accordance with this chapter
within fifteen (15) days after the date of mailing of the notice to register as
provided in section
4-4A-3 of this chapter, or if the owner of an abandoned building fails to
enclose such abandoned building in accordance with this chapter within thirty
(30) days after issuance of the enclosure permit, then in any such event the
city may file an action with the 4th judicial circuit court in Taylorville,
Illinois, and pursue any and all available remedies as may be provided to the
city under 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31-1 and/or 5/11-31-1.01 and/or
5/11-20-15.1 and/or proceed to take action as authorized without court
intervention under subparagraph (e) of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31-
1 and/or subject that owner to the penalty provisions of section
4-4A-12 of this chapter and/or to pursue any and all other applicable remedies
under law. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-7: BUILDING PLAN:
   A.   The building plan shall contain the following information:
      1.   A plan of action to maintain the abandoned building and premises
thereof in conformance with the city code.
      2.   A plan of action to remedy any city code violations.
      3.   A time schedule identifying a date of commencement of repair and
date of completion of repair for each city code violation.
      4.   If an owner proposes to demolish the abandoned building, then an
owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition.
      5.   A statement whereby an owner agrees to and shall be responsible and
liable for maintaining the property free of any garbage, infestation, litter,
refuse, rubbish, solid waste, brush, weeds and grass that exceed eight inches
(8") in height, yard waste, stumps, roots, or dead or dying trees.
   B.   An owner shall arrange for an inspection of the building by the
building official upon each date of completion listed in such building plan.
(Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-8: APPROVAL OR MODIFICATION OF BUILDING PLAN:
   A.   The building official shall have the discretion to approve the proposed
building plan. The building official shall have the right to modify the
building plan by altering the dates of performance or the proposed methods of
action. If the building official approves or modifies the building plan, notice
shall be sent to an owner of such abandoned building.
   B.   A building under construction or repair pursuant to such building plan
or any modification thereof each approved in writing by the building official
shall be exempt from such enclosure requirements set forth in the preceding
section
4-4A-6 of this chapter as the building official deems appropriate during the
time period the abandoned building is under construction or during the approved
time period as set forth in such approved building plan or approved
modification thereof. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-9: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH BUILDING PLAN:
Failure of an owner to comply with the approved building plan shall constitute
a violation of this chapter subjecting an owner of such building to the
penalties as provided in section
4-4A-12 of this chapter. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-10: CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP:
   A.   The building plan shall remain in effect notwithstanding a change in
ownership. The new owner shall file a new registration with the building
official and supply the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner
(s).
   B.   The new registration shall be in the same form as the original
registration; provided, however, an additional registration filing fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid by a new owner. The new registration
shall be for the same ninety (90) consecutive day period as then in existence
or remaining for the previous owner. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-11: COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER CITY CODE PROVISIONS OR APPLICABLE LAW:
   A.   Compliance with this chapter shall not preclude action by the city to
demolish or force rehabilitation or remediation or enclosure of an abandoned
building pursuant to any other provisions of this code or other applicable law.
   B.   All owners of abandoned buildings shall also be subject to and comply
with all other applicable requirements of the city code and with any and all
other applicable law. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-2014)
4-4A-12: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person in violation of any one or more provisions of this chapter
shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine of not less than three
hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) and no more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day during or on which a violation of this chapter occurs or continues. In
addition to this penalty, the city may utilize any other statutory or common
law remedies.
   B.   In addition, if an owner of an abandoned building fails to comply with
the notice to register within fifteen (15) days after the date of mailing of
the notice to register, the city may file an action with a circuit court in
Taylorville, Illinois, requesting an order ordering the registration of such
abandoned building by an owner.
   C.   In lieu of or in addition to assessing or collecting any penalties
under this section or under other applicable city code provisions or statutory
violations, the city in its sole discretion may, but is under no obligation to,
accept a deed of conveyance from an owner of the abandoned building and upon
such terms and conditions that are acceptable to the city. (Ord. 3667, 5-5-
2014)
CHAPTER 4B
PORTABLE STORAGE CONTAINERS
SECTION:
4-4B-1: Public Nuisance
4-4B-2: Removal; Exemption
4-4B-3: Notice Of Violation; Remedy
4-4B-4: Penalty
4-4B-1: PUBLIC NUISANCE:
It is hereby declared a public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person
to place, maintain, store, or use any "portable storage container" as defined
in section
10-14-2 of this code on any private property or public right of way within the
city in any manner not authorized or permitted by the city under
title 10, chapter 14 of this code. (Ord. 3734, 11-2-2015)
4-4B-2: REMOVAL; EXEMPTION:
Any portable storage container which existed lawfully on a parcel or tract of
land at the time of the adoption of an ordinance enacting this chapter shall be
removed by the owner or occupant of the property where such portable storage
container is located, within sixty (60) consecutive calendar days after
adoption of such ordinance, unless such portable storage container is
authorized or permitted under
title 10, chapter 14 of this code. (Ord. 3734, 11-2-2015)
4-4B-3: NOTICE OF VIOLATION; REMEDY:
Any portable storage container placed, maintained, stored or used in violation
of this chapter may be removed by the city or its delegates if such owner or
occupant fails to remove such portable storage container(s) within fourteen
(14) consecutive calendar days immediately following the receipt of a notice of
such violation and order to remove such public nuisance issued by the city's
health, building, and zoning enforcement officer. Such notice of violation and
order to remove shall be deemed received by such owner and/or occupant on: a)
the date of personal service of such notice and order; or b) within three (3)
business days of depositing a copy of such notice and order in a United States
post office or post office box in Taylorville, Illinois, in an envelope
addressed to "Owner and/or Occupant" with proper postage for regular mail
prepaid at the address of the property where such portable storage container(s)
are located; or c) if such address is unknown, then the date when a copy of
such notice of violation and order is posted near the main entrance of the
property where any of such portable storage containers are located or on one of
such portable storage containers. Each owner and occupant, jointly and
severally, shall be liable for and pay the city for all costs and expenses
including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney fees and court and
collection costs, incurred and related to the removal and disposition of such
portable storage container(s) and the collection of such indebtedness; and such
indebtedness shall be recordable as a lien upon the property where such
portable storage container(s) are or were located before such removal. (Ord.
3734, 11-2-2015)
4-4B-4: PENALTY:
In addition to and not in lieu of the remedy provided in section
 4-4B-3 of this chapter, any "person" (as defined under section
1-3-2 of this code) found to have been in violation of any of the terms and
provisions of this chapter shall be assessed a fine or penalty for each offense
in accordance with the general penalty provisions set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall
be deemed to be a separate offense. (Ord. 3734, 11-2-2015)
CHAPTER 5
WEEDS, GRASS, PLANTS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: Nuisances Declared
4-5-3: Height
4-5-4: Abatement Procedures
4-5-5: Lien
4-5-6: Penalty
4-5-7: No City Utilities If Delinquent Bill
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
   OWNER, OWNERS, OR OWNER'S: Such term or terms shall be deemed to include any
sole owner, any part owner, any joint owner, any tenant in common, any joint
tenant, any tenant by entirety, any contract purchaser, or any lessee or tenant
or occupant of the whole or of any part of any land, lot, or tract of real
estate located within the corporate limits of the city of Taylorville,
Illinois, or any person or entity of any kind, nature or extent whatsoever or
his/her/its assignee who holds a certificate of sale or other appropriate
instrument or document by virtue of the payment, in whole or in part, of
delinquent real estate taxes, or any real estate mortgagee or judgment creditor
or other lienor or their respective assignees who has taken or has actual or
consecutive possession or control of the subject real estate under the terms
and provisions of any mortgage instrument or document or by virtue of any real
estate mortgage foreclosure proceeding or by virtue of any court proceeding
concerning any judgment lien or other lienholder or who is the holder of a
certificate of sale or other appropriate instrument or document by virtue of
any public or private sale of the subject real estate; provided, however and
notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the term or terms owner,
owners, or owner's shall not mean or include the city of Taylorville, Illinois,
a municipal corporation and the city of Taylorville, Illinois, a municipal
corporation is specifically exempt from complying with any regulations as are
otherwise applicable to the term or terms owner, owners, or owner's as defined
herein and as set forth in this chapter.
   PLANTS: Does not include trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental plants.
   PROPERTY: Includes the land, lot, or tract of real estate owned, leased,
occupied or being purchased by the "owner" (as that word is defined herein).
   RIGHT OF WAY OR BOULEVARD: Includes the space between any sidewalk adjacent
to the "owner's" property and the adjacent street pavement, and shall include
the space between the owner's property line and the adjacent street pavement if
there is no sidewalk adjacent to the owner's property line.
   WEEDS: Includes, but is not limited to, the following: burdock, ragweed
(giant), ragweed (common), thistle, cocklebur, jimson, blue vervain, common
milkweed, wild carrot, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lamb's
quarters, wild lettuce, curled dock, smartweeds (all varieties), poison
hemlock, wild hemp and Johnson grass and all other "noxious weeds" as defined
by the statutes of the state of Illinois; and the word "weeds" shall also
include any grass of a variety exceeding eight inches (8") in height. (Ord.
2511, 10-18-1993; amd. Ord. 3079, 7-15-2002; Ord. 3626, 7-1-2013)
4-5-2: NUISANCES DECLARED:
   A.   Weeds: Any weeds found growing in any land, lot or tract of real estate
in the city are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to
permit any such weeds to grow or remain in any such place.
   B.   Barberry Bushes: It shall be a nuisance and unlawful to plant or permit
the growth of the bush of the species of tall, common or European barberry,
further known as Berberis vulgaris or its horticultural varieties within the
city. (Ord. 2511, 10-18-1993)
4-5-3: HEIGHT:
It shall be unlawful for any owner to permit any weeds, grass, or plants to
grow to a height exceeding eight inches (8") upon any property or upon any
right of way or boulevard within the corporate limits of the city. Any such
weeds, grass or plants exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a
nuisance. (Ord. 2511, 10-18-1993)
4-5-4: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Notice To Abate: The city's health and building officer, or his
authorized representative, may serve or cause to be served a written notice to
abate such nuisance upon an owner of any premises on which such weeds, grass or
plants are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this chapter in
