accordance with the following procedures:
      1.   The first notice to abate issued to each such owner during each
calendar year shall give such owner five (5) days from service of such notice
to abate to mow, cut, or trim such weeds, grass or plants to the permissible
height as provided in this chapter. Such weeds, grass or plants shall be mowed,
cut or trimmed by the owner to a height not to exceed eight inches (8") within
five (5) days after such notice has been duly served.
      2.   The second and all subsequent notices to abate issued to each such
owner during each calendar year shall give such owner forty eight (48) hours
from the time service of such notice to abate to mow, cut, or trim such weeds,
grass or plants to the permissible height as provided in this chapter. Such
weeds, grass, or plants shall be mowed, cut or trimmed to a height not to
exceed eight inches (8") within forty eight (48) hours after such notice has
been duly served.
   B.   Service Of Notice: Service of the notice provided for herein may be
effected by handing the same to any owner, or to any member of his or her
household of the age of fifteen (15) years or older found on the premises or by
mailing such notice to the last known residence address of the owner; provided
that if the premises is unoccupied and the owner's address cannot be obtained,
then the notice may be served by posting the same upon the premises.
   C.   Abatement By City:
      1.   If the owner so served does not abate the nuisance or fails or
neglects to mow, cut or trim such weeds, grass or plants to the aforesaid
permissible eight inch (8") height within the aforesaid five (5) day or forty
eight (48) hour time period, as the case may be, then, at the expense of the
owner, the city may abate or cause the abatement by others of such nuisance or
may mow, cut or trim such weeds, grass or plants to such permissible eight inch
(8") height or may authorize others to mow, cut, or trim such weeds, grass or
plants on behalf of the city. (Ord. 2511, 10-18-1993)
      2.   In such event and for each such occurrence, the owner shall be
liable for and shall pay the city a sum equal to two dollars ($2.00) per
frontage foot of owner's property or two hundred dollars ($200.00), whichever
amount is greater, plus an amount equal to the cost and expense to repair or
replace any city equipment damaged during such abatement of such nuisance or
mowing, trimming, or cutting of weeds, grass, or plants, plus all postage costs
for any and all certified mail and/or regular mail incurred to collect the
amount due, plus an amount equal to the fee charged by the recorder for
Christian County, Illinois, for the city to record any notice of lien under
section
4-5-5 of this chapter and/or 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7, 5/11-20-
15 or 5/11-20-15.1.
Such costs and expenses, if not timely paid, may be recovered by the city
against such owner in any civil action or ordinance violation proceedings in a
court of competent jurisdiction and/or through a collection agency selected by
the city.
In addition thereto or in lieu thereof, and at the election of the city's
health and building officer or his representative, such owner shall be subject
to the penalty provisions as set forth in section
4-5-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 3626, 7-1-2013)
4-5-5: LIEN:
   A.   Lien: All costs and expenses incurred for the abatement of any nuisance
or for the mowing, cutting or trimming of such weeds, grass or plants ("removal
activity") shall be a lien upon the owner's property. A bill representing the
removal cost and expense incurred ("removal cost") for the removal activity
shall be presented to the owner. If this bill is not paid within thirty (30)
calendar days of submission of the bill, a notice of lien consisting of a sworn
statement setting out the removal cost incurred by the city for the removal
activity may be recorded in the following manner:
      1.   A description of the real estate (or a description of the abandoned
residential property as applicable) that sufficiently identifies the parcel;
      2.   The amount of the removal cost for the removal activity;
      3.   The date or dates when the removal cost was incurred by the city;
and
      4.   In the case of abandoned residential property, a statement that the
lien has been filed pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7(d).
The notice of lien shall be filed in the recorder's office for Christian
County, Illinois, within one year after the removal cost is incurred. (Ord.
3626, 7-1-2013)
   B.   Payment: Notice of such lien claim shall be mailed to the owner of the
property if the owner's address is known or to the person to whom was sent the
tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the last preceding year.
Upon payment of the cost and expense after the notice of lien has been filed,
the lien shall be released by the city or owner in whose name the lien has been
filed and the release may be filed of record in the same manner as filing
notice of the lien. All lien and release filing fees shall be paid by the owner
of the property. (Ord. 3132, 7-21-2003)
   C.   Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for said unpaid costs
and expenses may be foreclosed upon and enforced in accordance with the
Illinois Compiled Statutes in such case made and provided.
   D.   Liability Of Owner: The liability of the owner as set forth in this
chapter shall be joint and several; and the city may proceed against any one or
all owners, but the city shall not be required to proceed against more than one
owner. (Ord. 2511, 10-18-1993)
4-5-6: PENALTY:
Regardless of whether the owner or the city or its representative abates such
nuisance or mows, cuts, or trims such weeds, grass, or plants to the
permissible height as set forth in this chapter, any owner violating any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine for each offense which
occurs during each calendar year in accordance with the following schedule:
   A.   Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first offense;
   B.   Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the second offense; and
   C.   Three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for the third offense and for
each subsequent offense thereafter.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
such nuisance or weeds, grass, or plants continues unabated after the aforesaid
five (5) day or forty eight (48) hour notice to abate as applicable has been
served or mailed in accordance with section
4-5-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 3626, 7-1-2013)
4-5-7: NO CITY UTILITIES IF DELINQUENT BILL:
   A.   City utilities (i.e., water and/or sanitary sewer service) shall not be
provided or turned on to any premises where there remains any unpaid bill or
lien concerning any removal cost incurred for any removal activity under this
chapter.
   B.   The city may turn off or disconnect any water and/or sanitary sewer
service to any premises where there remains any unpaid bill or lien concerning
any removal cost incurred for any removal activity under this chapter. (Ord.
3626, 7-1-2013)
CHAPTER 6
NOISE CONTROL
SECTION:
4-6-1: Restrictions On Certain Sound Devices
4-6-2: Whistles
4-6-3: Penalty
4-6-1: RESTRICTIONS ON CERTAIN SOUND DEVICES:
   A.   Definitions: The following definitions of terms used in this Section
shall apply. In addition, all definitions of acoustical terminology as
contained in American National Standards Institute (ANSI) section 1.1-1960
"Acoustical Terminology" are incorporated herein by reference thereto and shall
apply to this Section.
   ANSI: American National Standards Institute or its successor bodies.
A-WEIGHTED SOUND LEVEL: dB(A), in decibels, a frequency weighted sound pressure
level, determined by the use of the metering characteristics and A-weighted
network specified in ANSI section 1.4-1971 (R.1976) "Specification for Sound
Level Meters" and the latest revisions thereof.
   CLASS A LAND: All land with a Residential 1 (R-1) or Residential 2 (R-2)
zoning classification as determined by the "Zoning Ordinance of the City of
Taylorville, Illinois".
   CLASS B LAND: All land with a Commercial 1 (C-1) or Commercial 2 (C-2)
zoning classification as determined by the "Zoning Ordinance of the City of
Taylorville, Illinois".
   CLASS C LAND: All land with an Industrial 1 (I-1) or Industrial 2 (I-2)
zoning classification as determined by the "Zoning Ordinance of the City of
Taylorville, Illinois".
dB(A): See definition of A-Weighted Sound Level.
   PERSON: Any individual, corporation, partnership, joint venture, firm,
entity, association, or group, or any legal representative, agent, or employee
of any of the foregoing.
   PROPERTY-LINE NOISE SOURCE: Any musical instrument or device, radio,
phonograph, stereo receiving unit, microphone, loudspeaker, amplifier, or any
other similar sound device or equipment, which emits any sound.
   SLOW DYNAMIC CHARACTERISTIC: The dynamic characteristic specified as "Slow"
in ANSI document section 1.4-1971 (R. 1976) "Specification for Sound Level
Meters".
   SOUND: An oscillation in pressure in air.
   SOUND LEVEL: In decibels, a weighted sound pressure level, determined by the
use of metering characteristics and frequency weightings in ANSI section 1.4-
1971 "Specification for Sound Level Meters".
   B.   Sound Emitted To Class A Land:
      1.   Except as otherwise provided in this Section, no person shall cause,
permit, or allow the emission of sound during daytime hours (i.e., 7:00 A.M. to
10:00 P.M., local time) from any property-line noise source located on any
Class A, B, or C land to any receiving Class A land, which exceeds, for any
continuous period of thirty (30) seconds or more measured on Slow Dynamic
Characteristic, any allowable dB(A) sound level specified below, when measured
at any point within such receiving Class A land:
 
Class C Land Class B Land Class A Land
61dB(A)      55dB(A)      55dB(A)
 
      2.   Except as otherwise provided in this Section, no person shall cause,
permit, or allow the emission of sound during nighttime hours (i.e., 10:00 P.M.
to 7:00 A.M., local time) from any property-line noise source located on any
Class A, B, or C land to any receiving Class A land, which exceeds, for any
continuous period of thirty (30) seconds or more measured on Slow Dynamic
Characteristic, any allowable dB(A) sound level specified below, when measured
at any point within such receiving Class A land:
 
Class C Land Class B Land Class A Land
51dB(A)      44dB(A)      44dB(A)
 
   C.   Measurement Of Sound: The measurement of sound shall be made with a
sound level meter meeting the standards prescribed by the American National
Standards Institute (ANSI S1.4 Type 2 and IEC 651 Standards).
   D.   Exemptions:
      1.   The following situations shall be exempt from the provisions of
subsection B of this Section:
         a.   During any performance of the Taylorville Municipal Band;
         b.   The playing of music during the hours of eight o'clock (8:00)
A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on the Taylorville Square when the same is
requested by the Taylorville Area Merchants' Association or the Greater
Taylorville Chamber of Commerce, and the same is approved by the Mayor upon
written request therefor;
         c.   For auctions performed by any auctioneer who is licensed
according to the applicable provisions of this Code and conducts such auction
pursuant to the applicable provisions of this Code; provided, however, such
auction is completed by eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.;
         d.   Public parades or processions, circuses, or wedding processions;
         e.   Sporting events sponsored or authorized by any public or private
school, the Taylorville Park District, Young Men's Christian Association
(YMCA), the Christian County Fair Association or any other duly organized
sporting association, firm, or corporation;
         f.   Special public events sponsored or authorized by the City or the
Taylorville Association of Commerce or the Taylorville Area Merchants'
Association or by any service club or fraternal organization organized and
operating in accordance with the laws of the state of Illinois such as the
Sertoma Club, the Kiwanis Club, the Optimist Club, the Lions Club, the Jaycees,
the Moose Club, the Eagles Club, the Knights Of Columbus, VFW, and the American
Legion;
         g.   Any activity performed by or authorized by employees or agents or
contractors of the city when such activity is performed incident to official
public business for the city;
         h.   Any fundraising event sponsored by or authorized by any publicly
recognized charitable, religious, educational, or healthcare provider entity
duly organized and operating in accordance with the laws of the state of
Illinois;
         i.   Any police, fire, ambulance, or emergency rescue activity
performed in the ordinary course of business or for the purpose(s) intended for
such services provided; or
         j.   Special events sponsored or authorized by a private club or
organization on its premises; and such club or organization was duly organized
and is operating in accordance with the laws of the state of Illinois; and such
club or organization has an active membership of at least seventy five (75)
members. (Ord. 2853, 6-15-1998)
      2.   Notwithstanding such exemption, no person shall cause, permit, or
allow the emission of any sound(s) during any of such situations which is
unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing, or a nuisance to any
reasonable person or persons of ordinary sensibilities within the area of
audibility of such sound(s), and such sound(s) shall not extend past ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M., of any day.
   E.   Permits For Special Social Events Or Occasions:
      1.   Any adult owner or adult tenant of any class A land may be allowed
to obtain a permit for an exemption from the provisions of subsection B of this
section for a designated time not to exceed a ten (10) hour continuous period
for the date such permit is permitted; provided, however, no more than two (2)
such permits within a twelve (12) month consecutive calendar period may be
issued for the same class A land; and provided further, such exemptions shall
not extend past ten o'clock (10:00) P.M., during any designated time period;
and provided further, no person shall cause, permit, or allow the emission of
any sound(s) which is unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing, or a
nuisance to any reasonable person or persons of ordinary sensibilities within
the area of audibility of such sound(s).
      2.   Written applications for such permits shall be filed with the city
clerk's office at least twenty one (21) days prior to the event, and said
application shall be upon forms provided by the city, setting forth the name
and address of the applicant, the date and designated time period requested for
such permit, the precise location where the property line noise source(s) will
be used, the zoning classification of such location, and such other information
as may be requested on such form.
      3.   If an applicant applies for a sound amplified sound devices permit
and requests to have city of Taylorville streets blocked for the event, the
person filling out the application shall obtain and maintain a one million
dollar ($1,000,000.00) general liability insurance policy to cover the event.
Such general liability insurance coverage shall be an "occurrence" type policy
and not a "claims made" type policy. Furthermore, the insurance policy shall
name as an additional insured the "city of Taylorville, Illinois, municipal
corporation, and its elected and or appointed mayor, city council, officials,
officers, employees, and agents". Such requests to block city of Taylorville
streets shall be approved by the street and sewer committee.
      4.   The fee for the permit as set forth in this section shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00).
      5.   The provisions of subsections C and D of this section shall apply to
all persons for any such prohibited sound outside of the designated time period
set forth in such permit.
      6.   Notwithstanding the above, the city clerk shall refuse to issue any
permit for any such class A land if the city clerk determines that any of the
then existing owners or tenants of such class A land were in violation of any
of the provisions of this section within the twelve (12) months prior to the
date of a pending application for such permit. (Ord. 3481, 8-2-2010)
   F.   City Owned Property Adjacent To Lake Taylorville: Notwithstanding
subsection E of this section, no permit shall be issued to any person for
application at any location on any city owned property adjoining Lake
Taylorville or at any location on any other property adjoining Lake
Taylorville. (Ord. 3109, 1-21-2003)
4-6-2: WHISTLES:
It shall be unlawful to blow or cause to be blown any whistle in the city
except as a signal for starting or stopping work or in emergencies to avoid
injury to persons or property. (1979 Code § 24-4-26)
4-6-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 7
OPEN BURNING 1 , 2
SECTION:
4-7-1: Permitted Fires
4-7-2: Burning Leaves, Vegetation, Weeds, Grass Clippings, And Tree Limbs
4-7-3: Hazardous Fires
4-7-4: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  7-4-1 of this code for Lake Taylorville provisions.
2 2. See also section
  4-3-5 of this title for prohibited materials.
4-7-1: PERMITTED FIRES:
The following listed types of fires are permitted so long as same are not
situated upon a street or parkway within the city:
   A.   Fires for the purpose of burning leaves, grass clippings and small tree
limbs.
   B.   Burning of wood, charcoal, gasoline and other clean fuels in a
fireplace, grill or the like for cooking and social heating purposes.
   C.   Fires in conjunction with holidays and festive celebrations and for
other special purposes if set and attended by personnel qualified in fire
lighting techniques, fire containment and the use of firefighting equipment.
This type of fire shall be allowed only by special permit issued by the mayor
of the city. (1979 Code Ch. 23, Art. VI, § 2)
4-7-2: BURNING LEAVES, VEGETATION, WEEDS, GRASS CLIPPINGS, AND TREE LIMBS:
   A.   Restricted Burning: During the months of October, November, December,
January, February, and March of each year, it shall be unlawful to burn leaves,
vegetation, weeds, grass clippings or tree limbs anywhere in the city except
from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. until sunset during the first full week and the
third full week of each such month; and for purposes hereof, a "full week"
shall be defined as a Monday through the immediate following Sunday.
   B.   Open Burning: During the months of April, May, June, July, August, and
September of each year, it shall be unlawful to burn leaves, vegetation, weeds,
grass clippings or tree limbs anywhere in the city except between seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. and sunset. (Ord. 3142, 9-15-2003)
   C.   Free Disposal: Any resident within the corporate limits of the city may
dispose of leaves, vegetation, weeds and grass clippings at no charge by
hauling them, in yard waste containers or bags, to and depositing them into the
designated receptacle(s) at the city street and sewer department; provided,
however, said yard waste containers or bags shall not be deposited into said
designated receptacle(s) or left at the city street and sewer department
facility.
   D.   "Burning Off" Is Prohibited Generally: It shall be unlawful to "burn
off" leaves, vegetation, weeds, grass, or tree limbs anywhere in the city.
   E.   Burning On City Property: Notwithstanding anything in this section to
the contrary, the city may dispose of and/or burn leaves, vegetation, weeds,
grass clippings, and tree limbs on city owned property at any time(s) and on
any date(s) the city may determine. (Ord. 3071, 4-15-2002)
   F.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be
fined fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense upon conviction thereof, plus
court costs and fees. Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall
be deemed to be a separate offense. Any person issued a citation for an offense
pursuant to this section may pay the fifty dollar ($50.00) fine for such
offense at the city clerk's office within ten (10) days from the date of such
citation. If not so paid within such ten (10) days, then an ordinance violation
complaint may be filed with a court of competent jurisdiction.
   G.   Enforcement: This section shall be enforced by the Taylorville police
department. (Ord. 3213, 12-20-2004)
4-7-3: HAZARDOUS FIRES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to light or maintain any hazardous fire near any
building, structure or flammable material. (1979 Code Ch. 23, Art. VI, § 3)
   B.   It shall be unlawful to build or light any bonfire on any street or
sidewalk pavement or so near to any building or other structure as to endanger
such building or structure. (1979 Code Ch. 24, Art. IV, § 12)
4-7-4: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided, any person who violates the provisions of this
chapter shall, for each offense, be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1979 Code Ch. 23, Art. VI, § 6; amd. 1993 Code)
CHAPTER 8
FIREWORKS AND EXPLOSIVES
SECTION:
4-8-1: Fireworks Defined
4-8-2: Sale, Use Or Explosion Of Fireworks Prohibited; Public Displays; Permits
4-8-3: Protected Areas; Fireworks Showers; Transportation Signals Or Fuses
4-8-4: Nitroglycerin And TNT; Storage Of Explosives
4-8-5: Searches And Seizures; Forfeiture; Destruction
4-8-6: Penalty
4-8-1: FIREWORKS DEFINED:
   A.   The term "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive composition,
or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the
purpose of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional
nature by explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include
blank cartridges, toy cannons in which explosives are used, the type of
balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers,
torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, bombs, or other fireworks of like
construction and any fireworks containing any explosive compound, or any
tablets or other device containing any explosive substance, or containing
combustible substances producing visual effects; provided, however, that the
term "fireworks" shall not include snake or glow worm pellets; smoke devices;
trick noisemakers known as "party poppers", "booby traps", "snappers", "trick
matches", "cigarette loads" and "auto burglar alarms"; sparklers; toy pistols,
toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing
twenty five hundredths grain or less of explosive compound are used, providing
they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when
in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper or plastic caps which contain
less than twenty hundredths grain of explosive mixture; the sale and use of
which shall be permitted at all times. (Ord. 3122, 5-5-2003)
4-8-2: SALE, USE OR EXPLOSION OF FIREWORKS PROHIBITED; PUBLIC DISPLAYS; PERMITS
1 :
   A.   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person,
firm, copartnership, or corporation to knowingly possess, offer for sale,
expose for sale, sell at retail, or use or explode any fireworks within the
city at any time.
   B.   Provided a permit is first obtained from the city, supervised public
displays of fireworks are permitted. Permits may be granted hereunder to any
groups of three (3) or more adult individuals. Applications for such permits
shall be made in writing to the city's fire chief at least fifteen (15) days in
advance of the date of the display and action shall be taken on such
application within forty eight (48) hours after such application is made. Such
applications shall be accompanied by a bond signed by the applicants in the
amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned on compliance with the
provisions of this chapter, 425 Illinois Compiled Statutes 35/1 et seq., (state
bar edition) and the regulations of the state fire marshal adopted under such
statute; except that the city shall not be required to file such bond.
   C.   Forms for such application and permit may be obtained from the office
of the state fire marshal. One copy of such permit shall be on file with the
city fire chief, and one copy forwarded to the office of the state fire
marshal.
   D.   After such privilege shall have been granted, sales, possession, use,
and distribution of fireworks for such display shall be lawful for that purpose
only.
   E.   No permit granted hereunder shall be transferable; and no permit shall
be required for supervised public displays by state or county fair
associations.
   F.   Every such display shall be handled by a competent individual
designated and shall be of such character and so located, discharged or fired,
as not to be hazardous to property or endanger any person or persons.
   G.   Such permit shall be issued only after inspection of the display site
by the fire chief or a full time regular member of the city's fire department,
to determine that such display shall not be hazardous to property or endanger
any person or persons.
   H.   Possession by any party holding a certificate of registration under
"the fireworks regulation act of Illinois", filed July 20, 1935 2 , or by any
employee or agent of such party, shall not be a violation, provided such
possession is within the scope of business of the fireworks plant registered
under that act. (Ord. 3122, 5-5-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  7-4-1 of this code.
2 1. 425 ILCS 30/1 et seq., state bar edition.
4-8-3: PROTECTED AREAS; FIREWORKS SHOWERS; TRANSPORTATION SIGNALS OR FUSES:
   A.   No fireworks shall be discharged, ignited or exploded within six
hundred feet (600') of any hospital, asylum or infirmary in the city.
   B.   The use of what are technically known as fireworks showers or any
mixture containing potassium chlorate, and sulphur in theaters or public halls
is prohibited.
   C.   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the
manufacture, storage or use of signals or fuses necessary for the safe
operation of railroads, trucks, aircraft, or other instrumentalities of
transportation. (Ord. 3122, 5-5-2003)
4-8-4: NITROGLYCERIN AND TNT; STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to keep or store nitroglycerin or the explosive
commonly known as TNT in the city in any quantities, except for medicinal or
laboratory purposes, and for such purposes, no more than one-quarter (1/4)
ounce shall be stored in any one building or premises.
   B.   All such permitted explosives shall be stored or kept in accordance
with the rules and regulations of the office of the state fire marshal, subject
to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 3122, 5-5-2003)
4-8-5: SEARCHES AND SEIZURES; FORFEITURE; DESTRUCTION:
   A.   The city hereby adopts and incorporates herein 425 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 35/1 (state bar edition) as it relates to the rights, procedures, and
remedies afforded the city for searches and seizures, forfeitures, and
destruction of fireworks or combustibles in violation of this chapter and/or in
violation of 425 Illinois Compiled Statutes 35/1 et seq., (state bar edition);
provided, however, the adoption of such statute shall not prohibit arrest
without warrant or searches without warrant for violations of this chapter.
(Ord. 3122, 5-5-2003)
4-8-6: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person, firm, copartnership, or corporation violating any of the
terms or provisions of this chapter shall be fined, upon conviction, an amount
of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day upon which a
violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a separate offense. A violation
hereof may be established by a preponderance of the evidence.
   B.   A penalty imposed for each violation may include, or consist of, a
requirement that the offending party perform some reasonable public service
work such as, but not limited to, the picking up of litter in public parks or
along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities. (Ord. 3122, 5-5-
2003)
CHAPTER 9
LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definition
4-9-2: Storage and Utilization
4-9-3: Containers
4-9-4: Licensing Provisions for Production
4-9-5: Inspections; Enforcement
4-9-6: Copies of NFPA Pamphlets (Rep. by Ord. 3948, 3-16-2020)
4-9-7: Penalty
4-9-1: DEFINITION:
The term "liquefied petroleum gas", as used in this Chapter, shall be construed
to include any material composed predominantly of propane, propylene, butane
(normal butane iso-butane) and butylene or a mixture of them. (1979 Code Ch.
22, §1)
4-9-2: STORAGE AND UTILIZATION:
It shall be unlawful to produce, store or use liquefied petroleum gas or to
install or maintain any equipment for such production or use, unless such
production, storage and utilization equipment is constructed and maintained in
compliance with the provisions of article 24 of the Fire Prevention Code (1976
Edition) recommended by the American Insurance Association, Engineering and
Safety Service, 85 John Street, New York, New York 10038 and as may hereafter
be revised or supplemented. Three (3) copies of said article 24 of the Fire
Prevention Code shall be and remain on file in the office of the City Clerk.
(1979 Code Ch. 22, §2; 1993 Code)
4-9-3: CONTAINERS:
   A.   Specifications: All containers used for liquefied petroleum gases shall
be constructed to the standards prescribed therefor in the "Standards of the
National Fire Protection Association, for the Storage and Handling of Liquefied
Petroleum Gases", as published in pamphlet form by the National Fire Protection
Association, 2020 Edition (also referred to in this Chapter 9 as “NFPA Pamphlet
No. 58"). One (1) copy of the NFPA Pamphlet No. 58 shall be remain on file in
the office of the Fire Chief.
   B.   Location and Installation: No such container for use in connection with
any building shall be located between the building and the street upon which
the building abuts nor within such building. The installation of such
containers and the location with reference to buildings shall be in accordance
with the standards prescribed in NFPA Pamphlet No. 58. (1979 Code Ch. 22, §4;
1993 Code; amd. Ord. 3948, 3-16-2020)
4-9-4: LICENSE PROVISIONS FOR PRODUCTION:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to operate a plant for the
production of liquefied petroleum gases or for filling containers with such
gases in the Municipality without first having secured a license therefor.
   B.   Application for License; Fee: Applications for such licenses shall be
made, in writing, to the Clerk and shall conform to the general provisions of
the ordinances relating to business licenses. 1  The annual fee for such
licenses shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
   C.   Premises and Equipment: No such license shall be issued unless the
premises and equipment thereon to be used in such activity is in full
compliance with the standards prescribed in NFPA Pamphlet No. 58, and it shall
be unlawful to conduct or operate such activity unless all buildings and
equipment used in connection therewith comply with the standards prescribed in
that bulletin. (1979 Code Ch. 22, §5)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code.
4-9-5: INSPECTIONS; ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief or such other officer or employee as may
be designated by the Mayor to enforce the provisions of this Chapter and to
make such inspections or tests as may be necessary in connection therewith.
Whenever a test is necessary to determine whether any equipment or method
complies with the standards prescribed or referred to in this Chapter, the
enforcing official may accept the results of a test conducted by the State of
Illinois Department of Transportation. (1979 Code Ch. 22, §3)
4-9-6: COPIES OF NFPA PAMPHLETS:
(Rep. by Ord. 3948, 3-16-2020)
4-9-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 10
ADVERTISEMENTS 1
SECTION:
4-10-1: Handbills
4-10-2: Posting Bills
4-10-3: Prohibited Acts
4-10-4: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  7-4-3 of this Code for Lake Taylorville provisions.
4-10-1: HANDBILLS:
It shall be unlawful to distribute handbills and advertising literature of any
kind, unless tied, wrapped or folded, by placing the same in or upon any
residential building or any part thereof, and it shall be unlawful to
distribute any handbills and advertising literature of any kind by placing the
same in or upon any motor vehicle or any part thereof within the City limits of
Taylorville. (1979 Code Ch. 23, Art. VIII, §1)
4-10-2: POSTING BILLS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to post any bills or advertisements on any
public property without the authority of the City Council, and it shall be
unlawful to post any bill or advertisement on any property without the written
consent of the owner thereof. (1979 Code Ch. 24, Art. IV, §20)
4-10-3: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful:
   A.   Political Advertisements: To fasten any political poster, sticker, card
or other political advertisement to any utility pole, street sign, curb,
sidewalk or on any public property in the City. (1979 Code Ch. 24, Art. IV,
§21)
   B.   Unlawful Advertisements: To advertise any unlawful business or articles
in the City.
   C.   Damaging Advertisements: To injure or deface any lawful advertisement
or notice. (1979 Code Ch. 24, Art. IV, §14)
4-10-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 11
LICENSING OF CHILDREN'S HOSPITALS
SECTION:
4-11-1: License Required
4-11-2: Definitions
4-11-3: Regulations
4-11-4: Application For License
4-11-5: License Fees
4-11-6: Denial, Suspension Or Revocation Of License
4-11-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall establish, open, conduct, operate or maintain a children's
hospital without first obtaining a license. (Ord. 2866, 8-3-1998)
4-11-2: DEFINITIONS:
   CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL: A hospital devoted exclusively to caring for children
or any facility within a hospital devoted exclusively to caring for children.
   HOSPITAL: A health care facility as defined in section 3(A) of the Illinois
Hospital Licensing Act 1 . (Ord. 2866, 8-3-1998)
 
Notes
1 1. 210 ILCS 5/3.
4-11-3: REGULATIONS:
Any children's hospital licensed under this Chapter shall substantially comply
with all applicable standards and regulations of the Illinois Department of
Public Health as provided in the Illinois Hospital Licensing Act and the
Illinois Department of Public Aid as provided in 305 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/5-5.02 including title 9, chapter 1, section 148.120 and section 148.295 of
the Illinois Administrative Code, which are hereby adopted and incorporated
herein as the applicable standards and regulations of the City. (Ord. 2866, 8-
3-1998)
4-11-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for issuance or renewal of a City children's hospital license shall
be made to the City in the same manner as provided in the Illinois Hospital
Licensing Act for issuance and renewal of a hospital license by the Illinois
Department of Public Health and shall specifically identify any facility within
a hospital devoted exclusively to caring for children for which licensing is
sought pursuant to this Chapter. Said license, if issued, shall run for a term
of one year, to run continuous with the Illinois Department of Public Health's
license, or in the case of facilities within a hospital devoted exclusively to
caring for children, to run continuous with the Illinois Department of Public
Health's license for the hospital. (Ord. 2866, 8-3-1998)
4-11-5: LICENSE FEES:
The fee for issuance or renewal of a children's hospital license shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 2866, 8-3-1998)
4-11-6: DENIAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Denial, suspension or revocation of a hospital license by the Illinois
Department of Public Health shall be grounds for denial, suspension or
revocation of a children's hospital license by the City.
   B.   The children's hospital shall immediately report to the Clerk of the
City any notice by the Illinois Department of Public Health of substantial
failure to comply with applicable standards, rules or regulations. (Ord. 2866,
8-3-1998)
CHAPTER 12
SOLICITING
SECTION:
4-12-1: Definitions
4-12-2: Solicitations
4-12-3: Exceptions To Solicitations
4-12-4: Permit And Insurance Required
4-12-5: Age And Vest Requirements
4-12-6: Liability
4-12-7: Penalty
4-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, as used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section:
   HIGHWAY: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly
maintained within the city when any part thereof is open to the use of the
public for purposes of vehicular traffic.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any property or premises of any kind, nature or extent
whatsoever within the city that is available to or frequented by members of the
general public.
   SOLICITING AGENCY: An organization which has a permit from the city as
provided in section
 4-12-4 of this chapter and is engaged in a statewide fundraising activity and
is registered with the Illinois attorney general as a charitable organization
as provided by "an act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for
charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an
appropriation therefor", approved July 26, 1963, as amended 1 . (Ord. 2891, 1-
4-1999; amd. Ord. 3633, 8-19-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 460/1.
4-12-2: SOLICITATIONS:
No person shall be on any city highway, street, roadway or public place within
the city for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant or
occupants of any vehicle or from any person or persons except as may be
permitted in section
4-12-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 3633, 8-19-2013)
4-12-3: EXCEPTIONS TO SOLICITATIONS:
Any person wearing a high visibility vest and who is at least sixteen (16)
years of age and who is a member of a "soliciting agency" may solicit
contributions, on behalf of a "soliciting agency", from vehicles at the
intersection of West Main Cross Street and Webster Street between the hours of
eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M. on the date or
dates set forth in a permit issued by the city, by standing in the middle of
either of such streets immediately adjacent to such intersection. (Ord. 2891,
1-4-1999)
4-12-4: PERMIT AND INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Any "soliciting agency" who shall desire to solicit contributions from
occupants of vehicles at the intersection of West Main Cross Street with
Webster Street shall first secure a permit from the city clerk's office.
Applications for such permit shall be in such form as the city clerk's office
shall determine from time to time. Such application shall be accompanied by a
certificate of insurance evidencing that the "soliciting agency" has liability
insurance in an amount of at least five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00)
per occurrence and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) aggregate and that such
soliciting agency is engaged in a statewide fundraising activity. No such
permit shall be issued without such certificate of insurance and evidence that
the "soliciting agency" is properly registered with the Illinois attorney
general's office as a charitable organization under 225 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 460/1 and is engaged in a statewide fundraising activity. Such permit
shall identify the dates and times as to when such solicitation shall be
permitted. The fee for such permit shall be one dollar ($1.00) per day of
solicitation set forth in such permit. No permit will be issued when the city
square is totally blocked for another event or on days of parades. (Ord. 3381,
5-5-2008)
4-12-5: AGE AND VEST REQUIREMENTS:
Any person soliciting contributions on behalf of such "soliciting agency" shall
be sixteen (16) years of age or more and shall be wearing a high visibility
vest at the time of such solicitation. No "soliciting agency" shall permit any
person under the age of sixteen (16) years to solicit contributions on its
behalf. No "soliciting agency" shall permit any person to solicit contributions
on its behalf who is not wearing a high visibility vest at the time of such
solicitation. (Ord. 2891, 1-4-1999)
4-12-6: LIABILITY:
The "soliciting agency" shall be liable for any injuries to any person or
property during the solicitation which is causally related to an act of
ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent. (Ord. 2891, 1-4-1999)
4-12-7: PENALTY:
Any person and/or "soliciting agency" violating any provision of this chapter
shall, upon conviction, be fined and/or punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each separate offense, and a separate offense shall be
deemed to occur on each day on or during which a violation is deemed to exist
or continues. (Ord. 2891, 1-4-1999)
CHAPTER 13
FAIR HOUSING
SECTION:
4-13-1: Declaration Of Policy
4-13-2: Definitions
4-13-3: Prohibited Acts
4-13-4: Penalty
4-13-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
   A.   In furthering the policy of the state of Illinois as expressed in its
constitution and other laws; in order that the safety and general welfare,
peace and health of all the inhabitants of the city may be ensured, it is
hereby declared the policy of the city of Taylorville, Illinois, to assure
equal opportunity to all residents, regardless of race, color, religion,
national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or physical disability to live in
decent, sanitary, healthful, standard living quarters.
   B.   It is the policy of the city of Taylorville that no owner, lessee,
sublessee, assignee, managing agent, or other person, firm or corporation
having the right to sell, rent, lease (or otherwise control) any housing
accommodation and/or real property within the city, or any agent of these shall
refuse to sell, rent, lease, or otherwise deny to or withhold from any person
or group of persons such housing accommodations and/or real property because of
race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability
of such person or persons or discriminate against any person or persons because
of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed or disability
in the conditions, terms, privileges of the sale, rental or lease of any
housing accommodation and/or real property or in the furnishing of facilities
and/or services in connection therewith.
   C.   Relocation shall be carried out in a manner that will promote maximum
choice within the community's total housing supply; lessen racial, ethnic, and
economic concentrations; and facilitate desegregation and racially inclusive
patterns of occupancy and use of public and private facilities. (Ord. 3362, 12-
17-2007)
4-13-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context, the following
terms shall have the meanings as described in this section and as used in this
chapter:
   DECENT, SANITARY, HEALTHFUL, STANDARD LIVING QUARTERS: Housing which is in
sound, clean, and weathertight condition in conformance with applicable local,
state, and national codes.
   DISCRIMINATE OR DISCRIMINATION: Any difference expressed in any way toward a
person or persons in the terms of the sale, exchange, lease, rental or
financing for housing accommodation and/or real property in regard to such
sale, exchange, rental, lease or finance because of race, color, religion,
national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability of such person.
   FINANCIAL INSTITUTION: Any person, institution or business entity of any
kind which loans money to persons and receives as security for said loans a
secured interest of any kind in the property of the borrower.
   HOUSING ACCOMMODATION: Includes any building, structure, or portion thereof
which is used or occupied, maintained, arranged or designed to be used or
occupied as a home, residence or sleeping place of one or more human beings, or
any real estate so used, designed or intended for such use.
   OWNER: Any person/persons who hold legal or equitable title to, or owns any
beneficial interest in any real property or who hold legal or equitable title
to shares of, or hold any beneficial interest in any real estate cooperative
which owns any real property and/or housing accommodations.
   REAL ESTATE BROKER: Any person, partnership, association, corporation and/or
agent thereof, who for a fee or other valuable consideration offers, sells,
purchases, exchanges or rents, or negotiates for the sale, purchase, exchange
or rental of a housing accommodation and/or real property of another, or
collects rental for the use of housing accommodation and/or real property of
another.
   REAL PROPERTY: Any real estate, vacant land, building, structure or housing
accommodations within the corporate limits of the city of Taylorville,
Illinois. (Ord. 3362, 12-17-2007)
4-13-3: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any owner of real estate, lessee, sublessee, real
estate broker or salesman, financial institution or employee of the financial
institution, advertiser, or agent of any or all of the foregoing, to
discriminate against any person or persons because of their race, color,
religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability with regard to
the sale, exchange or rental, or any dealing concerning any housing
accommodation and/or real property.
In addition to the foregoing, it shall also be unlawful for any real estate
broker or employee thereof, owner or other persons, or financial institution
dealing with housing or real property in the city of Taylorville, Illinois:
   A.   To discriminate against any person in the availability of or the price,
terms, conditions, or privileges of any kind relating to the sale, rental,
lease, or occupancy of any housing accommodation or real property in the city
or in furnishing of any facilities or services in connection therewith.
   B.   To publish or circulate, or cause to be published or circulated, any
notice, statement or advertisement, or to announce a policy, or to use any form
of application, for the purchase, lease, rental or financing of real property,
or to make any record of inquiry in connection with the prospective purchase,
rental or lease of such real estate, which expresses directly or indirectly any
discrimination as to race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex,
creed or disability of any person.
   C.   To discriminate in connection with lending money, guaranteeing loans,
accepting mortgages or otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the
purchase, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of
any housing accommodation and/or real property.
   D.   To solicit for sale, lease, or listing for the sale or lease, of any
housing accommodation and/or real property on the grounds of loss of value
because of the present or prospective entry into any neighborhood of any person
or persons of any particular race, color, religion, national origin or
ancestry, sex, creed, or disability.
   E.   To distribute or cause to be distributed, written material or
statements designed to induce any owner or any housing accommodation and/or
real property to sell or lease his or her property because of any present or
prospective change in the race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry,
sex, creed, or disability of persons in the neighborhood.
   F.   To make any misrepresentations concerning the listing for sale or the
anticipated listing for sale or the sale of any housing accommodation and/or
real property for the purpose of inducing or attempting to induce the sale or
listing for sale of any housing accommodation and/or real property by
representing that the presence or anticipated presence of persons of any
particular race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or
disability in the area will or may result in the lowering of property values in
the block, neighborhood or area in which the property is located.
   G.   For any owner to solicit any real estate broker to sell, rent or
otherwise deal with such owner's housing accommodations and/or real property
with any limitation on its sale based on race, color, religion, national origin
or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability of the proposed buyer or tenant. (Ord.
3362, 12-17-2007)
4-13-4: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall
be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). Each day a violation
continues shall constitute a separate violation. This section shall in no way
abrogate or impair the right of the city of Taylorville, Christian County,
Illinois, to specifically enforce, by any legal means, any of the provisions of
this chapter. (Ord. 3362, 12-17-2007)
CHAPTER 14
SOUND AMPLIFICATION SYSTEMS 1
SECTION:
4-14-1: Restricted
4-14-2: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See also chapter 6 of this title.
4-14-1: RESTRICTED:
   A.   No driver of any motor vehicle within the city of Taylorville,
Illinois, shall play, use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated
any radio, stereo receiving or playing system, sound amplifier, tape recorder,
cassette player, CD player, or any other similar sound amplification system or
device for receiving broadcast sound or reproducing recorded sound which sound
can be heard outside the motor vehicle from seventy five (75) or more feet when
the motor vehicle is located on or is being operated on any public way in the
city of Taylorville, Illinois.
   B.   This section shall not apply if the sound amplification system or
device is being played, used, or operated to request emergency assistance or
warn of a hazardous situation. In addition, this section shall not apply to
authorized emergency vehicles. (Ord. 3120, 4-21-2003)
   C.   No person shall play, use, operate or permit to be played, used or
operated any radio, tape recorder, cassette player, device for receiving
broadcast sound or reproducing recorded sound, or any other sound amplification
system if the device is located:
      1.   On the public way; or
      2.   In any motor vehicle on the public way; and the sound can be heard
from seventy five feet (75') or more.
"Public way" means any and all streets, alleys, sidewalks, boulevards and
rights of way. (Ord. 3323, 2-5-2007)
4-14-2: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, for each
offense, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 3120, 4-21-2003)
TITLE 5
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
5-1-1: Department Created
5-1-2: Chief Of Police
5-1-2-1: Deputy Police Chief
5-1-3: Lieutenant Of Police
5-1-3-1: Police Sergeant
5-1-3-2: Police Investigator/Detective
5-1-4: Appointments And Promotions
5-1-5: Duties Of Department Members
5-1-6: Conduct Of Members
5-1-7: Serving Processes
5-1-8: Serve As Witness
5-1-9: Rules And Regulations

5-1-11: Unauthorized Persons
5-1-12: Police K9 Officer
5-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a Police Department, an executive department of the
City. The Police Department shall consist of the Chief of Police and such other
members as may be provided, from time to time, by the City Council. (1979 Code
§6-1)
5-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the Office of
Chief of Police. The Chief shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the approval
of the Council, and he shall be ex officio City Marshal and Superintendent of
Police. (1979 Code §6-2)
   B.   Duties: The Chief of Police shall:
      1.   Keeper Of City Jail 1 : Be the keeper of the City Jail and shall
have custody of all persons incarcerated therein.
      2.   Records And Reports: Keep such records and make such reports
concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or by
the City Council.
      3.   Supervision Of Department: Be responsible for the performance by the
Police Department of all its functions, and all persons who are members of the
department shall serve subject to the orders of the Chief of Police. (1979 Code
§6-3)
      4.   Custody Of Stolen Property: Be the custodian of all lost, abandoned
or stolen property in the City. (1979 Code §6-12)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
   1-4-4B of this Code.
5-1-2-1: DEPUTY POLICE CHIEF:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the Office of
Deputy Police Chief. As may be requested by the City Council from time to time,
the Deputy Police Chief shall be appointed by the Chief of Police, with the
approval of the City Council (i.e., the City's Corporate Authorities), and such
Deputy Police Chief shall serve at the discretion of the Chief of Police.
   B.   Duties: The Deputy Police Chief shall perform such duties and have such
responsibilities as the City Council and the Chief of Police may assign and/or
designate from time to time. (Ord. 3203, 11-15-2004)
5-1-3: LIEUTENANT OF POLICE:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment And Number: There is hereby created the
Office of Lieutenant of Police. There may be two (2) Lieutenants of Police to
be appointed by the Board of Police and Fire Commissioners. (Ord. 2852, 6-1-
1998)
   B.   Qualifications: No policeman will be eligible for Lieutenant until he
or she has served a minimum of three (3) years with the Taylorville Police
Department.
   C.   Shifts: There shall be no more than one Lieutenant of Police assigned
to each work shift and the Lieutenants shall be in charge of their shifts and
all members of the department serving under them. (Ord. 2456, 3-2-1992)
   D.   Salary: The salary for each such Lieutenant of Police shall be as
established by the City Council from time to time. (Ord. 2786, 4-7-1997)
5-1-3-1: POLICE SERGEANT:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment And Number: There is hereby created the
Office of Police Sergeant. There shall be three (3) Police Sergeants who shall
be appointed by the Board of Police and Fire Commissioners. (Ord. 2786, 4-7-
1997)
   B.   Minimum Prior Experience Required: No policeman shall be eligible for
Sergeant until he or she has served a minimum of four (4) years as a police
patrolman/patrolwoman with the Taylorville Police Department. (Ord. 3859, 8-20-
2018)
   C.   Shifts: There shall be no more than one Police Sergeant assigned to
each work shift and the Sergeants shall be under the general supervision of the
Chief of Police and the Lieutenant of Police assigned to his or her work shift;
and the Police Sergeant shall exercise functional supervision over all police
personnel under them who are assigned to his or her respective work shifts of
the Police Department.
   D.   Job Description, Qualifications, Duties And Responsibilities, Etc.: The
job description, qualifications, duties and responsibilities, etc., for such
Police Sergeants shall be as the City Council may determine from time to time,
either prior to or subsequent to such appointment(s) as Police Sergeant. The
current job description, qualifications, duties and responsibilities, etc., for
such Police Sergeants shall be as set forth on exhibit A attached to ordinance
2786 on file in the Clerk's Office and incorporated herein by reference
thereto. (Ord. 2786, 4-7-1997)
   E.   Salary: The salary for such Police Sergeant shall be based on the
amount determined by the collective bargaining agreement. (Ord. 3526, 7-18-
2011)
5-1-3-2: POLICE INVESTIGATOR/DETECTIVE:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment And Number: There is hereby created the
Office of Police Investigator/Detective which shall be a special assignment
position rather than a promotion position as of and from January 1, 2018.
Thereafter, there may be at least one Police Investigator/Detective who shall
be appointed by special assignment from time to time by majority vote of the
Aldermen; and the persons so appointed shall not be required to be tested by
the Police and Fire Commissioners. The persons who have been appointed prior to
January 1, 2018 and serve as Police Investigators/Detectives shall maintain
their rank. (Ord. 3860, 8-20-2018)
   B.   Minimum Prior Experience Required: No policeman shall be eligible for
Police Investigator/Detective until he or she has served a minimum of ten (10)
years as a police officer with any entity. The Police Investigator/Detective
"rank" shall be equivalent to that of Police Sergeant.
   C.   Job Description, Qualifications, Duties, And Responsibilities, Etc.:
The job description, qualifications, duties and responsibilities, etc., for
such Police Investigator/Detective shall be as the City Council may determine
from time to time, either prior to or subsequent to such appointment as Police
Investigator/Detective. The current job description, qualifications, duties and
responsibilities, etc., for such Police Investigator/Detective shall be as set
forth on exhibit B on file in the Clerk's Office and incorporated herein by
reference thereto. (Ord. 2786, 4-7-1997; amd. Ord. 3860, 8-20-2018)
   D.   Salary: The salary for such Police Investigator/Detective shall be
based on the amount determined by the collective bargaining agreement. (Ord.
3526, 7-18-2011; amd. Ord. 3860, 8-20-2018)
5-1-4: APPOINTMENTS AND PROMOTIONS:
   A.   Appointments to and promotions within the City's Police Department,
except for the Chief of Police, shall be based on ability and qualifications
and made from a list of eligibles certified by the Board of Police and Fire
Commissioners of the City of Taylorville, State of Illinois, in accordance with
such board's rules and regulations. (Ord. 3103, 11-18-2002)
5-1-5: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
It shall be the duty of the members of the Police Department to see to the
enforcement of all of the ordinances of the City and all statutes applicable
herein and to preserve the order and prevent infractions of the law and arrest
violators thereof. (1979 Code §6-6)
5-1-6: CONDUCT OF MEMBERS:
It shall be the duty of every member of the Police Department to conduct
himself or herself in a proper and law abiding manner, at all times, and to
avoid the use of unnecessary force. Each member of the department shall obey
the orders and directions of his superior. (1979 Code §6-8)
5-1-7: SERVING PROCESSES:
No member of the Police Department except the Chief shall serve any process
except on command of the Chief of the Police Department. (1979 Code §6-7)
5-1-8: SERVE AS WITNESS:
Any member of the Police Department shall appear as witness whenever this is
necessary in a prosecution for a violation of an ordinance or of any State or
Federal law. No such member shall retain any witness fee for service as witness
in any action or suit to which the City is a party, and fees paid for such
services shall be turned over to the Chief of Police, who shall deposit the
same with the City Treasurer. (1979 Code §6-9)
5-1-9: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Chief of Police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the
conduct and guidance of the members of the Police Department as he shall deem
advisable, and such rules, when approved by the Council, shall be binding on
such members. (1979 Code §6-10)
5-1-10: SPECIAL POLICEMEN:
The Mayor may appoint such special policemen as may be necessary for special
duties, and the employment of any such special policemen may be terminated by
the Mayor at any time. Such special policemen shall obey all the rules of the
Police Department. (1979 Code §6-11)
5-1-11: UNAUTHORIZED PERSONS:
It shall be and it is hereby declared unlawful for any unauthorized person to
enter into or remain in the Office of the Police Department at any time except
for purposes of official business with the Police Department or concerning
other City business. The penalty for violation of this Section shall be as
provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1979 Code §6-13; amd. 1993 Code)
5-1-12 :POLICE K9 OFFICER:
Upon motion approved by a majority of the alderman holding office from time to
time, the police officer who is assigned duties as a K9 officer may be allowed
from time to time to have the assigned police squad car with him/her at the K9
Officer’s residence for use in emergency call-outs for the services of the K9
dog. (Ord. 3906, 8-5-2019)
CHAPTER 2
AUXILIARY POLICE
SECTION:
5-2-1: Auxiliary Police Force Created; Appointment; Number
5-2-2: Qualifications; Fingerprints
5-2-3: Duties; Supervision
5-2-4: Conservators of the Peace
5-2-5: Identification; Carrying Firearms
5-2-6: Training
5-2-7: Death in the Line of Duty
5-2-1: AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE CREATED; APPOINTMENT; NUMBER:
The City does hereby establish an auxiliary police force for the City. The
Mayor may, with the advice and consent of the City Council, appoint up to four
(4) auxiliary policemen. At this time, the City Council deems a maximum of four
(4) auxiliary policemen to be necessary.
Such auxiliary policemen shall not be members of the regular Police Department
of the City and shall not supplement members of the regular Police Department
of the City in the performance of their assigned and normal duties, except as
provided for in Section
5-2-3 of this Chapter. (Ord. 2361, 10-16-89)
5-2-2: QUALIFICATIONS; FINGERPRINTS:
All auxiliary policemen shall be residents of the City.
Prior to the appointment of any auxiliary policeman, his fingerprints shall be
taken, and no person shall be appointed as such auxiliary policeman if he has
been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. (Ord.
2361, 10-16-89)
5-2-3: DUTIES; SUPERVISION:
Auxiliary police members shall only be assigned to perform the following duties
in the City:
   A.   To aid or direct traffic within the City.
   B.   To aid in control of natural or man-made disasters.
   C.   To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the Chief of Police.
Provided, that in cases which render it impractical for members of the regular
Police Department to perform the normal and regular police duties, the Chief of
Police of the City is hereby authorized to assign auxiliary policemen to
perform such normal and regular police duties.
Such auxiliary policemen shall, at all times during the performance of their
duties, be subject to the direction and control of the Chief of Police of the
City. (Ord. 2361, 10-16-89)
5-2-4: CONSERVATORS OF THE PEACE:
Auxiliary police, when on duty, shall also be conservators of the peace and
shall have the powers as specified in section
3-9-4 of chapter 24 of the Illinois Revised Statutes. (Ord. 2361, 10-16-89)
5-2-5: IDENTIFICATION; CARRYING FIREARMS:
   A.   Identification: Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary policemen
shall be different and distinct from those used by members of the regular
Police Department.
   B.   Carrying Firearms: Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms
except with the permission of the Chief of Police and while in uniform and in
the performance of their duties and following completion of the required
training. (Ord. 2361, 10-16-89)
5-2-6: TRAINING:
Auxiliary policemen, prior to entering upon any of their duties, shall receive
a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures as shall
be appropriate in the exercise of the powers conferred upon them under chapter
24 of the Illinois Revised Statutes, which training and course of study shall
be determined and provided by the City. The City, at this time, deems it
appropriate that auxiliary members be required to complete the same hiring
process as required for full-time officers. The screening process would include
1) background information, 2) oral interview, 3) psychological examination, and
4) medical examination. (Ord. 2361, 10-16-89)
5-2-7: DEATH IN THE LINE OF DUTY:
The "Law Enforcement Officers, Civil Defense Workers, Civil Air Patrol Members,
Paramedics and Firemen Compensation Act", as now or hereafter amended, 1  shall
be applicable to auxiliary policemen upon their death in the line of duty
described herein. (Ord. 2361, 10-16-89)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. ch. 48, ¶281 et seq.
CHAPTER 3
ANIMALS AND ANIMAL CONTROL 1
SECTION:
5-3-1: Livestock
5-3-2: Dangerous or Vicious Animals
5-3-3: Diseased Animals
5-3-4: Prohibited Acts and Conditions
5-3-5: Penalty
 
Notes
