5-3-1: LIVESTOCK:
   A.   Running at Large Prohibited; Impoundment and Redemption: It shall be
unlawful to permit any cattle, horse, swine, sheep, goats or poultry to run at
large in the City. Any such animal running at large in any public place in the
City shall be impounded in the manner provided for dogs in this Chapter. 2
(1979 Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §4)
The owner of any impounded animal may redeem it from the pound upon payment of
the fee as provided in subsection
5-3A-4C of his Chapter for dogs. (1979 Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §5)
   B.   Tying for Grazing: It shall be unlawful to picket or tie any animal
enumerated in subsection A of this Section in the streets of the City for the
purpose of grazing or feeding. (1979 Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §4)
 
Notes
2 2. See Section
  5-3A-4 of this Chapter.
5-3-2: DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous or vicious animal of any kind to
run at large in the City; exhibitions or parades of animals which are ferae
naturae in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a permit
from the City Council. (1979 Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §2)
The members of the Police Department and any other person in the City are
authorized to kill any dangerous animal when it is necessary for the protection
of any person or property. (1979 Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §6)
5-3-3: DISEASED ANIMALS:
No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious disease or an infectious disease
shall be allowed to run at large or to be exposed in any public place whereby
the health of man or beast may be affected nor shall such diseased animal be
shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof except under the
supervision of the Health and Building Officer. 1
The Health and Building Officer shall secure such disposition of any diseased
animal and such treatment of affected premises as to prevent the communication
or spread of contagion or infection except in cases where the State
Veterinarian is empowered to act. (1979 Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §7)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  5-3A-7B of this Chapter.
5-3-4: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Cruelty to Animals: No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the
City in any way. Any person who inhumanely beats, overloads, underfeeds or
abandons any animal shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this subsection.
(1979 Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §1)
   B.   Noisy Animals: It shall be unlawful to harbor a dog1 or keep any animal
which disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. (1979
Code Ch. 17, Art. I, §3)
   C.   Unclean Houses: No person shall cause or allow any stable or place
where any animal is or may be kept to become unclean or unwholesome. (1979 Code
Ch. 17, Art. I, §8)
   D.   Hunting: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in killing any
animal, other than as prescribed by law, 2  in the City. (1979 Code Ch. 24,
Art. IV, §8)
 
Notes
  2. S.H.A. ch. 61, ¶1.1 et seq.; see also Sections
2 5-5-2 and
  7-5-6 of this Code.
5-3-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
ARTICLE A. DOGS 1 /CATS
SECTION:
5-3A-1: Definitions
5-3A-2: Vicious Dogs
5-3A-3: Dangerous Dogs
5-3A-4: Dogs/Cats At Large Prohibited; Impoundment And Redemption
5-3A-5: Maximum Number Of Dogs And/Or Cats Permitted
5-3A-6: Rabies Control
5-3A-7: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
5-3A-8: Exemptions From Provisions
5-3A-9: Violations
5-3A-10: Penalties
5-3A-11: Prohibited Animals
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  7-5-5 of this code for Lake Taylorville provisions.
5-3A-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the following
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein:
   ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: The city's health and building officer and any
police officer employed in the police department of the city, any of whom shall
be authorized to take all actions to carry out the provisions of this chapter.
AT LARGE: Any dog/cat shall be deemed to be at large when it is off the
premises of its owner and is not securely leashed and under the restraint of a
responsible person.
   CAT: All members of the family Feline.
   DANGEROUS DOG: Any individual dog which, when either unmuzzled, unleashed or
unattended by its owner or a member of its owner's family, in a vicious or
terrorizing manner, approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack
upon streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places or upon any private
property other than the property of the owner.
   DOG: All members of the family Canidae.
   ENCLOSURE: A fence or structure of at least six feet (6') in height, forming
or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children, and
suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other measures which may
be taken by the owner or keeper, such as tethering of a vicious dog within the
enclosure. Such enclosure shall be securely enclosed and locked and designed
with secure sides, top and bottom and shall be designed to prevent the animal
from escaping from the enclosure.
   IMPOUNDED: Taken into custody of the public pound used by the city.
   LEASH: A cord, rope, strap, or chain not over six feet (6') in length which
shall be securely fastened to the collar or harness of a dog/cat and shall be
of sufficient strength to keep such dog/cat under control.
   OWNER: Any person having a right of property in a dog/cat, or who keeps or
harbors a dog/cat, or who has it in his or her care, or acts as its custodian,
or who knowingly permits a dog/cat to remain on or about any premises occupied
by him or her.
   PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, society, association or
other legal entity, any public or private institution, the state of Illinois,
municipal corporation or political subdivision of the state, or any other
business unit.
   PET OR COMPANION ANIMAL: Any animal kept for the pleasure rather than
utility; an animal of a species that has been bred and raised to live in or
about the habitation of humans and is dependent on people for food and shelter.
   RESTRAINT: The securing of an animal by leash or lead.
   RUN LINE: A system of tying a dog in place with either a cord, strap, rope,
or chain having a tensile strength of at least three hundred (300) pounds.
   VICIOUS DOG:
   A.   Any individual dog that, when unprovoked, inflicts, bites or attacks a
human being or other animal either on public or private property.
   B.   Any individual dog with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to
attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety
of human beings or domestic animals.
   C.   Any individual dog that has a trait or characteristic and a generally
known reputation for viciousness, dangerousness or unprovoked attacks upon
human beings or other animals, unless handled in a particular manner or with
special equipment.
   D.   Any individual dog which attacks a human being or domestic animal
without provocation.
   E.   Any individual dog which has been found to be a dangerous dog upon
three (3) separate occasions.
No dog shall be deemed "vicious" if it bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser
on the property of its owner or harms or menaces anyone who has tormented or
abused it or is a professionally trained dog for law enforcement or guard
duties. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-2: VICIOUS DOGS:
   A.   Confinement Required; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any person
to keep or maintain any dog which has been found by the animal control officer
or by any city police officer to be a vicious dog unless such dog is, at all
times, kept in an enclosure or on a run line. The only times that a vicious dog
may be allowed out of the enclosure or off the run line are: 1) if it is
necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary care for the vicious
dog, or 2) to comply with any order of a court of competent jurisdiction;
provided, that said vicious dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a chain
having a tensile strength of three hundred (300) pounds and not exceeding three
feet (3') in length and shall be under the direct control and supervision of
the owner or keeper of the vicious dog.
Any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog and which is not confined to
an enclosure or on a run line shall be impounded by the animal control officer,
any city police officer, or by any law enforcement authority having
jurisdiction in such area and shall be turned over to a licensed veterinarian
for destruction by lethal injection. The vicious dog shall be killed if seizure
or impoundment are not possible without risk of serious physical harm or death
to any person.
   B.   Sale Prohibited: No owner or keeper of a vicious dog shall sell or give
away any vicious dog. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-3: DANGEROUS DOGS:
It is unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog which has been found
by the animal control officer or by any city police officer to be a dangerous
dog unless such dog is at all times kept in an enclosure or on a run line. The
dangerous dog shall not be permitted to leave the premises of its owner unless
securely muzzled and under control by leash. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-4: DOGS/CATS AT LARGE PROHIBITED; IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION:
   A.   Running At Large Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for a dog/cat to run
at large in any part of the city, at any time.
   B.   Leash Required: It is unlawful for any dog/cat to leave the premises of
its owner when not under control by leash or other recognized control methods.
   C.   Impoundment And Redemption: Such dogs/cats may be apprehended and
impounded by any police officer or the animal control officer and placed in the
pound used by the city. The owner of an impounded dog/cat shall claim the dog/
cat within seven (7) days, and the dog/cat shall be released upon payment to
the city clerk of an impound fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) and showing
evidence the dog/cat has a current rabies tag.
   D.   Disposal Of Unclaimed Dogs/Cats: Dogs/cats not so claimed within seven
(7) days may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of as the animal control
officer shall determine.
   E.   Violation: Regardless of whether the dog/cat is apprehended and
impounded, the police officer or animal control officer may cite the owner of
such dog/cat to answer an ordinance violation charge for violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-5: MAXIMUM NUMBER OF DOGS AND/OR CATS PERMITTED:
No household shall keep or harbor at any time within the city more than the
maximum number of four (4) dogs/cats with no more than three (3) of one species
over four (4) months of age in any residentially zoned district.
Example: Three (3) dogs, one cat - total of four (4).
Example: Three (3) cats, one dog - total of four (4). (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-6: RABIES CONTROL:
   A.   Inoculation And Tag Required: Each calendar year, or at such intervals
as may hereafter be promulgated by the Illinois department of agriculture,
every owner or keeper of a dog/cat four (4) months or more of age shall cause
such dog/cat to be inoculated against rabies. Such owner or keeper of such dog/
cat shall cause a serially numbered tag evidencing such inoculation to be
attached to a collar or harness which shall be worn by each dog/cat.
   B.   Quarantine Of Rabies Suspects:
      1.   Inoculated Dogs/Cats: All dogs/cats that have bitten a human being
shall be confined by the owner for a period of ten (10) days in an escape proof
enclosure; provided however, that the dog/cat has a current rabies inoculation.
At the end of ten (10) days, the owner shall have the dog/cat examined by a
licensed veterinarian.
      2.   Dogs/Cats That Have Not Been Inoculated: If a dog/cat does not have
a current rabies tag, the owner shall have such dog/cat confined under the
observation of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten (10) days.
Immediately upon examination by a veterinarian, the owner shall forward a
clinical report to the police chief or animal control officer.
      3.   Responsibility For Costs: All expenses shall be the responsibility
of the owner of the dog/cat. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-7: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Injury To Property: It shall be unlawful for any person owning or
possessing a dog/cat to permit such dog/cat to go upon any sidewalk, parkway,
boulevard or private lands or premises without the permission of the owner of
such premises and break, bruise, tear up, crush or injure any lawn, flowerbed,
plant, shrub, tree or garden in any manner whatsoever or to defecate or urinate
thereon. This subsection shall not apply to a person who is visually or
physically handicapped.
   B.   Feces Accumulations: No person shall allow dog/cat feces to accumulate
in any yard, pen or premises in or upon which a dog/cat shall be confined or
kept so that it becomes offensive to those residing in the vicinity or health
hazard to the residing dog/cat.
   C.   Unlawful Removal Of Muzzles: It shall be unlawful for any person to
remove a muzzle, collar, identification tag, leash, or other restraint from a
dog/cat without the consent of the owner of the dog/cat.
   D.   Dog/Cat Excrement: It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog/cat to
allow the dog/cat to defecate or urinate upon any public sidewalk,
thoroughfare, public place, or private property other than the premises owned
and occupied by the owner of the dog/cat; provided, however, no such violation
shall occur if such owner immediately thereafter removes said defecation from
such public sidewalk, thoroughfare, public place, or private property after
same is deposited thereon.
   E.   Confining Dogs/Cats In Heat: The owner of every female dog/cat in heat
shall confine the dog/cat in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner
that the female dog/cat cannot come into contact with another animal except for
planned breeding.
   F.   Interfering With Officer: No person shall resist or molest the police
officer or animal control officer while engaged in the enforcement of any of
the provisions of this chapter.
   G.   Noisy Dogs Prohibited:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any owner to keep or harbor any dog which
by habitually bawling, barking, howling, crowing, or by other annoying noises
shall unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of any person. Such dog(s) is/
are declared to be a public nuisance and noisy dog(s).
      2.   Whenever any person shall complain to the animal control officer or
the police department that a dog which habitually bawls, barks, cries, howls,
crows, or makes other annoying noises is being kept by any person in the city,
the animal control officer or the police department shall notify the owner of
the dog that a complaint has been received. Within twenty four (24) hours of
receiving said notice of such complaint, the owner shall take whatever actions
or measures necessary to alleviate such habitual bawling, barking, crying,
howling, crowing, or other annoying noise; provided, however, if the offense
occurs while such dog is on any Lake Taylorville lot or Lake Taylorville
campsite or Lake Taylorville overnight campsite or upon any Lake Taylorville
property then the owner shall immediately take whatever actions or measures
necessary to alleviate such habitual bawling, barking, crying, howling,
crowing, or other annoying noise.
      3.   If the warning given to the person alleged to be keeping such a dog,
as set forth above, is ineffective, then a verified complaint signed by the
complaining person may be presented to the animal control officer or to the
police department alleging that such dog is being kept within the city and by
habitually bawling, barking, crying, howling, crowing, or making any other
annoying noise is unreasonably disturbing the peace and quiet of the
complaining person. The animal control officer or the police department shall
inform the owner of the dog that a complaint has been received and shall cite
the owner of the dog for the violation alleged in the complaint.
      4.   Only one warning shall be given to an owner of a noisy dog; and any
subsequent offenses following the issuance of a citation for a noisy dog shall
result, without further warning, in the issuance of a citation upon the
presentation of such verified complaint by a person complaining of such noisy
dog.
   H.   Restraints Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any owner to restrain
any dog on any Lake Taylorville lot or Lake Taylorville campsite or Lake
Taylorville overnight campsite or upon any Lake Taylorville property by use of
a cord, strap, rope, or chain or other restraining device when such restraint
is attached to any tree, shrubbery, brush or utility pole located on such lake
lot, campsite, overnight campsite or other Lake Taylorville property or when
such restraint is attached to any structure, building, improvement, or any
other property owned by the city and located on any such lake lot, campsite,
overnight campsite or Lake Taylorville property, or when such restraint is
situated so that any such dog by movement while under such restraint causes
damages to any such tree, shrubbery, brush, utility pole, structure, building,
improvement or other city owned property.
   I.   Digging Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any owner of any dog to
permit or allow such dog to dig holes more than six inches (6") wide and more
than two inches (2") deep or to make bare spots upon any ground on any Lake
Taylorville lot or Lake Taylorville campsite or Lake Taylorville overnight
campsite or upon any Lake Taylorville property or upon any city owned property.
(Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-8: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
Guide dogs for the blind and hearing impaired and support dogs for the
physically handicapped are exempt from section
 5-3A-3 and subsection
5-3A-4B of this article; and police owned dogs are exempt from sections
5-3A-2,
5-3A-3,
5-3A-4,
5-3A-5, and subsections
5-3A-7A, B, C, D, and G of this article; provided, any such dog is performing
duties as expected. To qualify for exemption under this section, each such
guide dog or support dog shall be currently inoculated against rabies in
accordance with subsection
 5-3A-6A of this article. It shall be the duty of the owner of such exempted
dog to notify the animal control officer of changes of address. The animal
control officer shall provide police and fire departments with a categorized
list of such exempted dogs and shall promptly notify such departments of any
address changes reported to him. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-9: VIOLATIONS:
The animal control officer or the police department may refuse to issue any
citation for any alleged violation of this chapter if a person who witnessed
such alleged violation refuses to sign a verified complaint as to such alleged
violation and refuses to agree to testify in court as to such alleged violation
and such animal control officer or the police department determines that such
testimony would be necessary in the prosecution of such violation. Except as is
otherwise provided in subsection
5-3A-7G of this article, the animal control officer or the police department,
in their discretion, may issue oral or written warnings for any other violation
of this chapter but in no event shall oral or written warnings be given for
second or subsequent violations of a similar nature and citations shall be
issued for such second or subsequent violations. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-10: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined in accordance with the following schedule:
 
First offense                           $ 75.00
Second similar offense                  100.00
Third similar offense                   125.00
Fourth similar offense and each similar A sum not less than $125.00 nor more
offense thereafter                      than $750.00
 
A separate violation shall be deemed committed on each day which a violation
for the same offense occurs or continues.
The police officer or animal control officer may issue citations for violations
of this article. Any person issued a citation for a first, second, or third
offense pursuant to this article may pay the amount of the aforesaid designated
penalty for such offense at the city clerk's office within ten (10) days from
the date of such citation. If not so paid within such ten (10) days, then an
ordinance violation complaint shall be filed with the appropriate court. (Ord.
3535, 10-3-2011)
5-3A-11: PROHIBITED ANIMALS:
It is unlawful to harbor, keep, or permit to be kept or harbored any poultry,
cattle, swine, sheep, goats, horses, or similar animals within the city
corporate limits.
Exceptions:
   A.   The above listed animals may be allowed on property zoned AG-1 or AG-
2 within the corporate city limits.
   B.   The above named animals may be allowed on property within the city
corporate limits used for zoological parks, animal exhibitions, educational
institutions, veterinarian hospitals, animal shelters, or pounds.
Any person violating this section shall be subject to the penalties noted in
section
5-3A-10 of this article. (Ord. 3535, 10-3-2011)

5-4-1: OFFENSES INVOLVING THE PERSON:
5-4-1-1: DISORDERLY CONDUCT 1 :
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit disorderly conduct, as provided
for in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/26-1. (1993 Code)
   A.   Yelling, Shouting, Singing On Streets, Etc.: No person shall yell,
shout, hoot, whistle or sing on the public streets, particularly between the
hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. or at any
time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons
in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any
persons in the vicinity.
      1.   Any person who violates the provisions of this subsection A shall,
for each offense, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 3325, 2-5-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
   7-3-8C of this code.
5-4-1-2: FIGHTING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly start a fight or to fight or
to commit any assault or battery while in or within or at or on or about: a)
any city street, highway, roadway, easement, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, right
of way; or b) Lake Taylorville; or c) any city property; or d) any public place
within the city.
For purposes hereof, "public place" shall mean and include any property or
premises of any kind, nature or extent whatsoever within the city that is
available to or frequented by members of the general public either in person or
while wholly or partly in or within or at or on or about any vehicle or
property of any kind, nature, or extent whatsoever. (Ord. 3673, 7-7-2014)
5-4-1-3: DISTURBING ASSEMBLAGES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any lawful assemblage or
gathering in the city. (1979 Code §24-4-7)
5-4-1-4: LOAFING OR LOITERING:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to be found loafing or
loitering at the corners of streets or in the vicinity of any place of
amusement, hotel or other business place or private premises and to refuse to
disperse or vacate such place when requested to do so by any person in
possession of any portion of the premises who is annoyed or aggrieved thereby
or by any police officer. (1979 Code §24-4-15)
5-4-2: OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY:
5-4-2-1: THEFT AND RELATED OFFENSES:
No person shall commit theft. A person commits theft when such person
knowingly:
   A.   Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; or
   B.   Obtains, by deception, control over property of the owner; or
   C.   Obtains, by threat, control over property of the owner; or
   D.   Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have been
stolen by another or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce such
person to believe that the property was stolen; and
      1.   Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of
the property; or
      2.   Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such manner as
to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or
      3.   Uses, conceals or abandons the property knowing such use,
concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such
use or benefit.
A person convicted of a first offense under this section, without regard to the
value of the property stolen, shall be fined in an amount not less than ten
dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). A person
convicted of a second or subsequent offense under this section, without regard
to the value of the property stolen, shall be fined in an amount not less than
fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord.
1974, 7-21-1980)
5-4-2-2: RETAIL THEFT:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section the words and phrases
defined in this subsection have the meanings ascribed to them herein unless a
contrary meaning is clear from the context:
   CONCEAL: To "conceal" merchandise means that, although there may be some
notice of its presence, merchandise is not visible through ordinary
observation.
   FULL RETAIL VALUE: The merchant's stated or advertised price of the
merchandise.
   MERCHANDISE: Any item of tangible personal property.
   MERCHANT: An owner or operator of any retail mercantile establishment or any
agent, employee, lessee, consignee, officer, director, franchisee or
independent contractor of such owner or operator.
   MINOR: A person who is less than nineteen (19) years of age, is
unemancipated and resides with such person's parents or legal guardian.
   PEACE OFFICER: The meaning ascribed to that term in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/2-13.
   PERSON: Any natural person or individual.
   PREMISES OF A RETAIL MERCANTILE ESTABLISHMENT: Includes, but is not limited
to, the retail mercantile establishment and common use areas in shopping
centers and all parking areas set aside by a merchant or on behalf of a
merchant for the parking of vehicles for the convenience of the patrons of such
retail mercantile establishment.
   RETAIL MERCANTILE ESTABLISHMENT: Any place where merchandise is displayed,
held, stored or offered for sale to the public.
   SHOPPING CART: Pushcarts of the type or types which are commonly provided by
grocery stores, drugstores or other retail mercantile establishments for the
use of the public in transporting commodities in stores and markets and from
such stores to a place outside the store.
   UNDER RING: To cause the cash register or other sales recording device to
reflect less than the full retail value of the merchandise.
   B.   Retail Theft Prohibited And Defined: No person shall commit retail
theft. A person commits the offense of retail theft when such person knowingly:
      1.   Takes possession of, carries away, transfers or causes to be carried
away or transferred any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale
in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such
merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail
value of such merchandise; or
      2.   Alters, transfers or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia
of value or other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any
merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile
establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or in
consort with another at less than full retail value with the intention of
depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
      3.   Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for
sale in a retail mercantile establishment from the container or place in or on
which such merchandise is displayed to any other container or place with the
intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such
merchandise; or
      4.   Under rings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full
retail value of the merchandise; or
      5.   Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile
establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such
removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such cart.
   C.   Presumptions: If any person conceals upon such person or among such
person's belongings unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered
for sale in a retail mercantile establishment and removes that merchandise
beyond the last known station for receiving payments for merchandise in that
retail mercantile establishment without paying the full retail value of such
merchandise, such person shall be presumed to have possessed, carried away or
transferred such merchandise with the intention of retaining it or with the
intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or
benefit of such merchandise.
   D.   Detention: Any merchant who has reasonable grounds to believe that a
person has committed retail theft may detain such person, on or off the
premises of a retail mercantile establishment, in a reasonable manner and for a
reasonable length of time for all or any of the following purposes:
      1.   To request identification.
      2.   To verify such identification.
      3.   To make reasonable inquiry as to whether such person has in such
person's possession unpurchased merchandise and to make reasonable
investigation of the ownership of such merchandise.
      4.   To inform a peace officer of the detention of the person and
surrender that person to the custody of a peace officer.
      5.   In the case of a minor, to inform a peace officer, the parents,
guardian or other private person interested in the welfare of that minor of
this detention and to surrender custody of such minor to such person.
   E.   Affirmative Defense: A detention, as permitted in this section, does
not constitute an arrest or an unlawful restraint, as defined in 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/10-3, nor shall it render the merchant liable to the person
so detained. (Ord. 1974, 7-21-1980)
   F.   Penalties: A person convicted of a first offense under this section,
without regard to the retail value thereof, shall be fined in an amount not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). A person convicted of a second or subsequent offense under this
section, without regard to the retail value thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). (Ord. 1974, 7-21-1980)
5-4-2-3: LARCENY:
   A.   Larceny Prohibited: No person shall take personal property, either by
fraud or by stealth, with the intent to deprive another of such property.
   B.   Larceny By False Pretense: No person shall induce or attempt to induce
any person to give up or pay over any money or other thing of value by any
false representation or pretense or in exchange for any false or bogus coin or
check, draft or other false evidence of value or in consideration of refraining
from a lawful or unlawful arrest or in consideration of refraining from
reporting any unlawful act to any public official. (Ord. 1974, 7-21-1980)
5-4-2-4: INJURY TO PUBLIC PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful to injure, deface or interfere with any property belonging
to the city without proper authority from the council. (1979 Code Ch. 9, Art.
VI, § 3)
5-4-2-5: VANDALISM:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following
definitions shall apply:
   LEGAL GUARDIAN: Shall include a person appointed guardian of the person or
given custody of a minor by a circuit court of this state or any other state
but does not include a person appointed guardian only of the estate of a minor
or appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the Illinois juvenile
act 1 .
   MINOR: Shall include a person who is above the age of eleven (11) years but
not yet eighteen (18) years of age.
   PARENT: Shall include the lawful father or mother of a minor child, whether
by birth or adoption.
   PERSON: Shall include any individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   PROPERTY: Shall include any real estate, including improvements thereon, and
tangible personalty.
   SUFFERANCE OF AN ACT OF VANDALISM: The failure to interfere, prohibit and
prevent the commission of an act of vandalism by a minor.
   VANDALISM: Shall include any of the following acts:
      1.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly damage, deface or destroy any
property of another person without his consent; or
      2.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly, by means of fire or explosive
device, damage, deface or destroy any property of another person; or
      3.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly start a fire on the land of
another person without his consent; or
      4.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly deposit on the land or in a
building of another person, without his consent, any stink bomb, or any
offensive smelling compound and thereby interfere with the use and occupancy by
another of the land or building; or
      5.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly and without authority enter
into any building, housetrailer, motor vehicle, aircraft or any part thereof of
another person without his consent. (Ord. 1882, 9-19-1978; amd. 1993 Code)
   B.   Vandalism Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any
act of vandalism upon either public or private property within the city. Each
separate act of vandalism shall be considered as a separate violation of this
subsection. (Ord. 1882, 9-19-1978)
   C.   Acts Of Vandalism By Minors Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
minors to commit any act of vandalism upon either public or private property
within the city. Each separate act of vandalism shall be considered as a
separate violation of this subsection. (Ord. 1882, 9-19-1978; amd. 1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.
5-4-2-6: FALSE ALARMS:
   A.   A "false alarm" is defined as follows: A false alarm occurs when a
security system is activated where there is no emergency, whether it is
activated wilfully, intentionally, negligently, or inadvertently. It also
includes a system activated due to mechanical or electrical malfunction.
A false alarm does not occur when an alarm system is activated by an attempted
or actual illegal entry, theft, or robbery; an observable act of vandalism;
unusually violent conditions of nature; and testing or repairing of telephone
or electrical line or equipment outside the premises, so long as prior notice
of the testing or repair is given to the Taylorville police department.
   B.   Commercial/business alarms and residential alarms shall both be allowed
two (2) false alarms in a quarter at no charge. Commercial/business alarms and
residential alarms shall be charged a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a third
and fourth false alarm in a quarter notwithstanding the fees imposed in
subsection C of this section.
   C.   Notwithstanding the fees charged for false alarms of commercial/
business alarms and residential alarms set forth in subsection B of this
section, fees shall also be imposed for false alarms of commercial/business
alarms and residential alarms based on the number of false alarms in a year in
the amounts as set forth as follows:
 
Number Of False Alarms Fee Imposed (For Each
In A Year              False Alarm)
                       No fee (with the exception that the fees imposed on a
First 4                quarterly basis as set forth in subsection B of this
                       section shall still apply)
5th through 10th       $ 50.00
11th through 15th      100.00
16th and over          175.00
 
(Ord. 3380, 4-21-2008)
5-4-3: OFFENSES RELATED TO MORALS AND DECENCY:
5-4-3-1: GAMBLING:
It shall be unlawful:
   A.   Gambling Prohibited: To gamble or attend any gambling house or to make
any bet, lottery or gambling hazard or to buy or sell any chances or tickets in
gambling game, arrangement or device unless allowed by the laws of the state.
(1979 Code §24-3-1)
   B.   Gambling Devices: To possess any gambling device or paraphernalia with
the intent to use the same for an unlawful purpose, and any such device or
paraphernalia kept with such intent may be confiscated by any member of the
police department. (1979 Code §24-3-2)
   C.   Gambling Houses: To maintain or patronize any establishment maintained
for a gambling house.
   D.   Advertising Gambling: To advertise any gambling house on any street,
alley or other public place in the city. (1979 Code §24-3-4)
   E.   Gambling Activities Allowed: Nothing in this section shall be deemed to
prohibit or make unlawful the following activities or forms of gambling: 1) the
keeping, possession, ownership, use or playing of a video gaming terminal in a
licensed establishment, licensed truck stop establishment, licensed fraternal
establishment or licensed veterans' establishment, which is licensed by the
Illinois gaming board to conduct or allow such specific activities under the
video gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., and such
establishment has a current and valid city of Taylorville class A-1, class C-1,
class D-1, class I-1, or class J-1 liquor license; 2) a licensee, licensed by
the city, to conduct a raffle in accordance with the raffles act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 15/0.01 et seq.; 3) a licensee, licensed by the Illinois
department of revenue, to conduct or allow bingo play in accordance with the
bingo license and tax act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 25/1 et seq.; or a
licensee, licensed by the Illinois department of revenue, to conduct or allow
gambling in accordance with the charitable games act, 230 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 30/1 et seq. (Ord. 3713, 5-18-2015)
5-4-3-2: INDECENT PUBLICATIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale or to circulate, pass
from one person to another or expose in any public place or anywhere in view of
a store or place frequented by the public any immoral, indecent or obscene
publication, printed or written matter or picture or other representation.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to keep any such publication, printed or written
matter, picture or other representation in any place frequented by or where it
may come into the possession of minors or to disclose or expose any such
material to a minor. (1979 Code §24-4-23)
5-4-3-3: NUDE BATHING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to bathe at any public place or in any
place open to the public view unless such persons are adequately garbed in a
bathing suit. (1979 Code §24-4-19)
5-4-3-4: PUBLIC URINATION:
   A.   No person shall urinate or defecate or expose a person's private body
parts on any street, alley, sidewalk, parking lot, floor of any public building
or any building where the public gathers, or in any other place commonly open
to the public except in such public place that has been designated as a
restroom.
   B.   Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be fined seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 3078, 6-17-2002)
5-4-3-5: PUBLIC INDECENCY:
   A.   Offense Committed: A person commits the offense of public indecency if
they knowingly or intentionally, in a public place:
      1.   Engage in sexual intercourse;
      2.   Engage in deviate sexual conduct;
      3.   Appear in a state of nudity;
      4.   Make a lewd exposure of the body done with the intent to arouse or
to satisfy the sexual desire of the person; or
      5.   Fondle their own genitals or those of another person.
   B.   Definitions:
   NUDITY: The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, female
breasts with less than a full opaque covering below a point immediately above
the top of the areola, human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even
if completely and opaquely covered, or that portion of the buttocks which would
be covered by a properly worn "thong" type bikini bottom.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any location frequented by the public, or where the public is
present or likely to be present, or where a person may reasonably be expected
to be observed by members of the public. Public places include, but are not
limited to, streets, sidewalks, parks, beaches, business and commercial
establishments (whether for profit or not for profit and whether open to the
public at large or where entrance is limited by a coverage charge or membership
requirement), hotels, motels, restaurants, nightclubs, country clubs, cabarets,
and meeting facilities utilized by social, fraternal or similar organizations.
Premises used solely as a private residence, whether permanent or temporary in
nature, shall not be deemed a public place. Public places shall not include
enclosed single sex public restrooms; enclosed single sex functional showers,
locker and/or dressing room facilities; enclosed motel rooms and hotel rooms
designed and intended for sleeping accommodations; doctors' offices; churches,
synagogues or similar places when used for circumcisions, baptisms or similar
religious ceremonies; portions of hospitals; and similar places in which nudity
or exposure is necessarily and customarily expected outside of the home; nor
shall it include a person appearing in a state of nudity in a modeling class
operated by a proprietary school licensed by the state or by a college, junior
college or university supported entirely or partly by taxation or by a private
college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in
which credits are transferable to a college, junior college or a university
supported entirely or partly by taxation or an accredited private college.
(Ord. 3204, 11-15-2004)
5-4-4: OFFENSES RELATED TO PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY:
5-4-4-1: THROWING MISSILES:
It shall be unlawful to cast, throw or propel any missile on any street, alley
or other public place, and it shall be unlawful to throw or deposit any glass,
nails, tacks or other similar articles on any street, sidewalk, alley or other
public place in the city. (1979 Code Ch. 24, Art. IV, § 13)
5-4-4-2: OPEN WELLS OR EXCAVATIONS 1 :
It shall be unlawful to permit any well or any other similar excavation to
remain uncovered excepting on premises secured by a fence of at least six feet
(6') in height with all doors on entrances to such premises locked. (1979 Code
Ch. 24, Art. IV, § 28)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 8, chapter 1, article A of this code.
5-4-4-3: OVERHEAD TANKS FOR STORAGE OF PETROLEUM PRODUCTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or maintain any
overhead tanks for petroleum products of a capacity of over fifty (50) gallons
except in the case of fuel oil, which tanks may be of a capacity not to exceed
six hundred (600) gallons. (1979 Code Ch. 24, Art. IV, § 18)
5-4-4-4: SKATEBOARDING, ROLLERSKATING, AND ROLLERBLADING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN
AREAS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to travel on or use or operate or stand
on or sit on or ride on any skateboard or to travel on or use or operate or
stand on or wear any roller skates or rollerblades at the following locations
within the city:
      1.   On the city public library property or any public sidewalk located
immediately adjacent to the city public library property or on such portion of
Washington Street which is located between Poplar Street and Vine Street;
      2.   On any public street or on any public sidewalk or on any city
property located on or within the Taylorville public square;
      3.   On any public street or alleyway or on any public sidewalk or on any
city property located within the following described square block area: the
square block area bounded on the north by Vine Street, bounded on the south by
Franklin Street, bounded on the east by Walnut Street, and bounded on the west
by Webster Street.
   B.   Any person or persons found to have been in violation of any of the
terms or provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined or
punished in accordance with section
1-4-1 of this code; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day that a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2765, 9-3-1996)
5-4-4-5: TRAFFIC NOT TO BE OBSTRUCTED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate or allow any vehicle to remain upon any
street in such a manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic
thereon.
   B.   No person shall unnecessarily hinder, obstruct or delay or
unnecessarily attempt to delay, hinder or obstruct any other person in lawfully
driving or traveling along or upon any street, highway or road within this city
so as to interfere with the effective movement of traffic.
   C.   Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be fined an
amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first offense, an amount of not less
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for the second offense, and seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
the third offense and any subsequent offenses. (Ord. 3169, 4-19-2004)
5-4-4-6: EXCESSIVE NOISE:
It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle that makes an unreasonably loud
or excessive noise in any of the following ways:
   A.   When the motor vehicle is stopped, the operator accelerates the engine
thereof with the gears of the vehicle in neutral, thereby causing an
unreasonably loud or excessive noise; or
   B.   When the motor vehicle is stopped, the operator accelerates the engine
with the gears of said vehicle in neutral and while so accelerating the engine,
shifts the gears of the vehicle into a forward or reverse movement, thereby
causing an unreasonably loud or excessive noise with the wheels or tires of the
vehicle; or
   C.   The operator of a motor vehicle accelerates the engine thereof when
shifting the gears of such vehicle in such a manner as to cause the wheels or
tires of such vehicle to spin rapidly, thereby causing an unreasonably loud or
excessive noise; or
   D.   The operator of a motor vehicle accelerates the vehicle or rapidly
stops the vehicle causing an unreasonably loud or excessive noise. (Ord. 2888,
12-21-1998)
5-4-4-7: HORNS:
The driver of a motor vehicle shall when reasonably necessary to ensure safe
operation give audible warning with his or her horn, but shall not otherwise
use such horn when upon a highway. For purposes hereof, the word "highway"
shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly
maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes
of vehicular traffic or located on public school property. (Ord. 3157, 12-15-
2003)
5-4-4-8: DISORDERLY HOUSE:
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions
shall apply:
   DISORDERLY HOUSE: Shall mean and include any residential dwelling unit that
experiences an unlawful activity in, at, on or about the dwelling unit more
than three (3) times within a twelve (12) month period.
   DWELLING UNIT: Shall mean and include a room or a group of rooms which are
arranged, designed, used or intended for use as living quarters for any person
or persons and shall include, but is not limited to, an attached or detached
single-family or multiple-family house, building, structure, apartment,
condominium, townhouse, duplex, or rooming house. A dwelling unit may be leased
or owner-occupied, and includes the land that is affixed, incidental to or
appurtenant to it.
   OCCUPANT: Shall mean and include any person who has the right to the use of
or to possess, or who is in charge or control or keeper of a dwelling unit,
including, but not limited to, any tenant of the dwelling unit.
   OWNER: Shall mean and include any person who is a landlord or lessor of the
dwelling unit or who is a titleholder, contract purchaser or seller, or
mortgage holder of a dwelling unit or who owns a whole or partial interest in
and to or of a dwelling unit.
   PERSON: Shall mean and include any and all persons, firms, corporations,
limited liability companies, trustees, partnerships, or entities of any kind,
nature, or extent whatsoever.
   UNLAWFUL ACTIVITY: Shall mean and include:
      1.   Any behavior or conduct which is documented by arrest or the
issuance of a city ordinance violation complaint or citation, or the issuance
of a criminal charge, citation, complaint, information or indictment under any
Illinois statute that occurred in, at, on or about the dwelling unit; or
      2.   A residential incident meaning that any law enforcement personnel
(from the Taylorville police department and/or from the Christian County
sheriff's department and/or from the Illinois state police) have arrived at a
dwelling unit in response to any complaint from any person of an alleged
unlawful activity at any dwelling unit; or
      3.   Any boisterous, loud or raucous noise (clearly audible from 20 feet
or more from a dwelling unit) or behavior or disorderly conduct of any kind,
nature, or extent whatsoever by any person in, at, on or about the dwelling
unit that disturbs the peace of any person within the neighborhood of a
dwelling unit; or
      4.   Any behavior or conduct by any person in, at, on or about the
dwelling unit that alarms or disturbs another so as to create a breach of the
peace; or
      5.   Any behavior or conduct by any person in, at, on or about the
dwelling unit that is dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or
welfare of any person.
   B.   Declaration Of Public Nuisance: Every disorderly house is hereby
declared a public nuisance.
   C.   Violation: It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, or occupant to
own or possess or occupy or cause or permit or allow or fail to prohibit any
disorderly house. The liability of an owner is conditioned upon the owner
having received a written notice from a representative of the city's police
department of the dates of the two (2) prior unlawful activities that occurred
at the dwelling unit owned by the owner. A representative of the city's police
department shall mail or deliver an owner a written notice within thirty (30)
days following each such unlawful activity if such owner's residence or
business address is then known to the city's police department.
   D.   Penalty: Any person found guilty of violating this section shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and
shall be assessed the applicable court costs and court assessed fees for each
offense. (Ord. 3633, 8-19-2013)
5-4-4-9: PRESENCE ON PREMISES WHERE PEOPLE UNDER TWENTY ONE ARE POSSESSING OR
CONSUMING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES:
   A.   A person who knowingly enters or remains in any house, building, yard
or other premises, other than premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor, under
circumstances where the person knows or reasonably should know that alcoholic
liquor is being illegally possessed or consumed by persons under the age of
twenty one (21) years shall be guilty of a petty offense and, upon conviction,
shall be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   B.   It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian, or other person, to
knowingly permit a person under the age of twenty one (21) years old in his or
her custody to violate the provisions of subsection A of this section. Any
person convicted of a violation of this subsection shall be fined not less than
five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   C.   Nothing in this section shall prohibit the possession and dispensing,
or consumption of alcoholic liquor by a person under twenty one (21) years of
age in the performance of a religious service or ceremony, or the consumption
by a person under twenty one (21) years of age under the direct supervision and
approval of the parents or parent or those persons standing in loco parentis of
such person under twenty one (21) years of age in the privacy of a home as
allowed by the Illinois liquor control act 1 . (Ord. 3324, 2-5-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 235 ILCS 5/6-20.
5-4-5: OFFENSES INVOLVING LIQUOR:
5-4-5-1: OPEN CONTAINERS:
It shall be unlawful to possess alcoholic or intoxicating beverages in opened
containers in any public park, on any public street or sidewalk or in any place
of amusement or area or other place open to the public other than in a public
place licensed to sell such beverages for consumption on the premises or other
than at or within a designated site or location for a specific event for a
specific date or dates as authorized under a class L "special use permit"
license issued under section
3-3-5 of this code. (Ord. 3730, 9-21-2015)
5-4-5-2: CONSUMPTION IN PUBLIC:
It shall be unlawful to serve or consume alcoholic or intoxicating beverages in
any public park, on any public street or sidewalk or in any place of amusement
or area or other place open to the public other than in a public place licensed
to sell such beverages for consumption on the premises or other than at or
within a designated site or location for a specific event for a specific date
or dates as authorized under a class L "special use permit" license issued
under section
3-3-5 of this code. (Ord. 3730, 9-21-2015)
5-4-5-3: PUBLIC INTOXICATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be intoxicated from alcoholic beverages
and/or from any illegal drugs or contraband in, at, on, or about any city
street, highway, roadway, easement, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, right of way,
or any other public place within the city. For purposes hereof, "public place"
shall mean and include any premises of any kind, nature or extent whatsoever
within the city that is regularly available to or frequented by members of the
general public, except for any premises where alcoholic liquor is served for
consumption on such premises pursuant to a liquor license issued by the city.
(Ord. 3709, 4-20-2015)
5-4-5-4: ILLEGAL POSSESSION AND CONSUMPTION OF LIQUOR:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty one (21) years of age
to purchase, accept delivery, possess and/or consume alcoholic liquor.
   B.   The possession and dispensing, or consumption by a person under twenty
one (21) years of age of alcoholic liquor in the performance of a religious
service or ceremony, or the consumption by a person under twenty one (21) years
of age under the direct supervision and approval of the parents or parent or
those persons standing in loco parentis of such person under twenty one (21)
years of age in the privacy of a home, is not prohibited by this section. (Ord.
3040, 8-20-2001)
   C.   Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be fined an
amount of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first offense, an amount of not less
than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for the second offense, and an amount of not less than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for the third offense and any subsequent offenses. (Ord. 3169, 4-19-2004)
5-4-5-5: TRANSPORTATION OR POSSESSION OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR IN A MOTOR VEHICLE:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection C of this section, no driver may
transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor within the passenger
area of any motor vehicle upon a highway in this state except in the original
container and with the seal unbroken.
   B.   Except as provided in subsection C of this section, no passenger may
carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any
motor vehicle upon a highway in this state except in the original container and
with the seal unbroken.
   C.   This section shall not apply to the passengers twenty one (21) years of
age or older in a limousine when it is being used for purposes for which a
limousine is ordinarily used, the passengers twenty one (21) years of age or
older on a chartered bus when it is being used for purposes for which chartered
buses are ordinarily used or on a motor home or mini-motor home as defined in
section 1-145.01 of the Illinois vehicle code. However, the driver of any such
vehicle is prohibited from consuming or having any alcoholic liquor in or about
the driver's area. Any evidence of alcoholic consumption by the driver shall be
prima facie evidence of such driver's failure to obey this section. For the
purposes of this section, a "limousine" is a motor vehicle of the first
division with the passenger compartment enclosed by a partition or dividing
window used in the for hire transportation of passengers and operated by an
individual in possession of a valid Illinois driver's license of the
appropriate classification pursuant to section 6-104 of the Illinois vehicle
code.
   D.   The exemption applicable to chartered buses under subsection C of this
section does not apply to any chartered bus being used for school purposes.
   E.   Any driver who is convicted of violating subsection A of this section
for a second or subsequent time within one year of a similar conviction shall
be subject to suspension of driving privileges as provided in paragraph 23 of
subsection (a) of section 6-206 of the Illinois vehicle code.
   F.   Any driver, who is less than twenty one (21) years of age at the date
of the offense and who is convicted of violating subsection A of this section
or a similar provision of a local ordinance, shall be subject to the loss of
driving privileges as provided in paragraph 13 of subsection (a) of section 6-
205 and paragraph 33 of subsection (a) of section 6-206 of the Illinois vehicle
code. (Ord. 3040, 8-20-2001)
   G.   Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be fined an
amount of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first offense, an amount of not less
than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for the second offense, and an amount of not less than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for the third offense and any subsequent offenses. (Ord. 3169, 4-19-2004)
5-4-6: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating any of the following sections of this
chapter shall be fined an amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first
offense, an amount of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the second offense, and an
amount of not less than six hundred fifty dollars ($650.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the third offense and any subsequent
offenses. Any person found guilty of violating any other provision of this
chapter shall, for each offense, be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.

5-4-7: CANNABIS:
   A.   Unless authorized by or legal under the Compassionate Use of Medical
Cannabis Program Act (410 ILCS 130/1 et seq.), or under the Cannabis Regulation
and Tax Act (410 ILCS 705/1-1 et seq.), it is unlawful for any person knowingly
to possess ten grams (10 g) or less of any substance containing cannabis within
the City of Taylorville.
   B.   Any person violating subsection A of this Section shall be fined, upon
conviction thereof, in accordance with the following schedule:
      1.   Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($250.00) for the first offense;
      2.   Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) for the second subsequent offense;
      3.   Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00) for the third subsequent
offense and each subsequent offense thereafter.
   C.   Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed to
be a separate offense.
   D.   As used in this Section, unless the context otherwise requires:
CANNABIS: Includes marihuana, marijuana, hashish and other substances which are
identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis Sativa, whether growing
or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and
any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such
plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other
cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically
produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or
independently by means of chemical synthesis or by a combination of extraction
and chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant,
fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant,
any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of
such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil or cake,
or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, government or governmental subdivision or
agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership or association, or any other
entity.
SUBSEQUENT OFFENSE: An offense under this Section, the offender of which, prior
to his conviction of the offense, has at any time been convicted under this
Section, or under any laws of the United States, or of any state relating to
cannabis, or any controlled substance as defined in the Illinois Controlled
Substances Act 1 . (Ord. 3784, 11-21-2016; amd. Ord. 4106, 5-16-2022)

ARTICLE A. PROHIBITION OF "BYOB PREMISES"
SECTION:
5-4A-1: Definitions
5-4A-2: Alcoholic Beverages In BYOB Premises
5-4A-3: Prohibited
5-4A-4: Responsible Persons
5-4A-5: Penalty
5-4A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
   BYOB PREMISES: Any licensed premises (including, but not limited to, any
premises licensed under
title 3, chapter 3 of this code) and any unlicensed premises (including, but
not limited to, restaurants, food establishments, clubs, reception halls, but
not including any residential premises of the host) of any kind, nature or
extent whatsoever where members of the public or members or patrons or invitees
or licensees or guests bring or provide their own alcoholic liquor or alcoholic
beverages for consumption on such premises with or without any fees or charges
imposed by any person owning or leasing or managing or in charge of or employed
at such premises for admission to such premises or for a "corking fee" or for
setups, i.e., liquid mixers, cups, glasses, beverage containers, ice, and/or
any other items associated with the consumption of alcoholic liquor or
alcoholic beverages or for any other reason.
   PERSON: Any individual, partnership, firm, company, association,
organization, club, limited liability company, corporation, trust, or legal
entity of any kind, nature or extent whatsoever. (Ord. 3657, 1-21-2014)
5-4A-2: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN BYOB PREMISES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or bring or deliver any
alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage into any BYOB premises or to consume any
alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage within any BYOB premises. (Ord. 3657, 1-
21-2014)
5-4A-3: PROHIBITED:
   BYOB premises are prohibited, illegal, and not allowed within the city. It
shall be unlawful for any person to own, lease, operate, manage, or possess any
BYOB premises. (Ord. 3657, 1-21-2014)
5-4A-4: RESPONSIBLE PERSONS:
It shall be unlawful for any owner, tenant, operator, manager, or employee of
any BYOB premises to allow or permit any person to possess or bring or deliver
any alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage into any BYOB premises or to allow
any person to consume any alcoholic liquor or alcoholic beverage within or on
any BYOB premises. (Ord. 3657, 1-21-2014)
5-4A-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating this article shall, for each offense, be punished as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 3657, 1-21-2014)
CHAPTER 5
WEAPONS
SECTION:
5-5-1: Right To Bear Arms
5-5-2: Discharge Of Firearms
5-5-3: Concealed Weapons
5-5-4: Penalty
5-5-1: RIGHT TO BEAR ARMS:
Except as otherwise prohibited by law, every adult person, as defined by
Illinois statute, residing within the limits of the city shall possess the
absolute right to own, possess and maintain a firearm together with necessary
ammunition for the use of such firearm. (Ord. 2059, 8-2-1982)
5-5-2: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearm or air gun in the city except in
an indoor firing range that is maintained and operated as a special use
approved by the city council to be located in a C-1 or C-2 zoning district
under section
10-5-6 of this code or to be located in an I-1, I-2, or I-3 zoning district
under section
10-6-2 of this code; and this section shall not be construed to prohibit any
officer of the law to discharge a firearm in the performance of his duty nor to
any citizen to discharge a firearm when lawfully defending his person or
property or to drive away obnoxious birds, with the permission of the mayor and
chief of police. This section shall not apply to Lake Taylorville should there
be a special ordinance for hunting 1 . (Ord. 3741, 3-7-2016)

CHAPTER 6
DOWNTOWN AREA
SECTION:
5-6-1: Trespass On Parking Lots
5-6-2: Curfew For Minors
5-6-3: Penalty
5-6-1: TRESPASS ON PARKING LOTS:
It shall be unlawful as a trespass for any person to enter upon any part of any
city owned parking lot, whether in a vehicle or otherwise, which is located in
the downtown fire district or any other city owned parking lot located within
two (2) blocks in any direction from the Taylorville public square, including
the parking lot across the street in a westerly direction from Harrison's
Motors and the two (2) parking lots across the street in an easterly direction
and southerly direction from the Frisina Hotel at any time when the main
entrance to said parking lots are closed or when a notice is posted or
exhibited at the main entrance of the parking lots stating that the parking
lots are closed to the public. (Ord. 2410, 9-4-1990)
5-6-2: CURFEW FOR MINORS:
   A.   Age And Hour Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for any person less
than seventeen (17) years of age to be present at or upon any public assembly,
building, place, street, or highway at the following times within the corporate
limits of the city, unless accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal
guardian, or other responsible companion at least eighteen (18) years of age
approved by a parent or legal guardian or unless said person less than
seventeen (17) years of age is engaged in a business or occupation which the
laws of the state authorize a person less than seventeen (17) years of age to
perform:
Between 11:00 P.M. and 6:00 A.M. Saturday,
Between 11:00 P.M. and 6:00 A.M. Sunday,
Between 10:00 P.M. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and 6:00 A.M. on the
following day. (Ord. 3524, 7-18-2011)
   B.   Responsibility For Minors: It shall be unlawful for a parent, legal
guardian or other person to knowingly permit a person in his custody or control
to violate subsection A of this section. (Ord. 3157, 12-15-2003)
5-6-3: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person violating any of the provisions of section
5-6-1 of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code. A notice to appear may be issued by the arresting officer
for an appearance day in court, and the violator may pay his fine on or before
said appearance date at the office of the circuit clerk of Christian County,
Illinois.
   B.   Any person violating any of the provisions of section
5-6-2 of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code, except that neither a person who has been made a ward of
the court under the juvenile court act of 1987 1 , nor that person's legal
guardian, shall be subject to any fine. In addition to or instead of the fine
imposed by this subsection, the court may order a parent, legal guardian, or
other person convicted of a violation of subsection
5-6-2B of this chapter to perform community service as determined by the court,
except that the legal guardian of a person who has been made a ward of the
court under said juvenile court act of 1987 may not be ordered to perform
community service. The dates and times established for the performance of
community service by the parent, legal guardian, or other person convicted of a
violation of subsection 5-6-2B of this chapter shall not conflict with the
dates and times that the person is employed in his or her regular occupation.
(Ord. 3157, 12-15-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.
CHAPTER 7
HALLOWEEN TRICK-OR-TREATING
SECTION:
5-7-1: Definition
5-7-2: Restrictions
5-7-3: Violation; Penalty
5-7-1: DEFINITION:
"Halloween trick-or-treating" means the solicitation by any person, in costume
or not, on another person's private property for candy, treats, food, or other
tangible items of personal property which solicitation is traditionally engaged
in during the month of October of each year. (Ord. 2737, 1-2-1996)
5-7-2: RESTRICTIONS:
No person shall engage, within the corporate limits of the City, in what is
traditionally known as "Halloween trick-or- treating" unless such person is
younger than the age of thirteen (13) years and engages in "Halloween trick-or-
treating" between the hours of five o'clock (5:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:
00) P.M. Central Standard Time on October 30 and/or October 31 of each year and
such "Halloween trick-or- treating" is limited to such residences where an
exterior light is on. (Ord. 3857, 8-20-2018)
5-7-3: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this Chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined in an amount of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each separate offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2737, 1-2-1996)
TITLE 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
TRAFFIC CODE; GENERAL PROVISIONS 1
SECTION:
6-1-1: Incorporation Of State Law Provisions
6-1-2: Vehicle Size, Weight And Load
6-1-3: Signs Posted
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/15-101 et seq.
6-1-1: INCORPORATION OF STATE LAW PROVISIONS:
All the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, entitled "Motor
Vehicles", are incorporated herein as part of this title. Three (3) copies of
said provisions shall be and remain on file in the office of the city clerk.
(1979 Code Ch. 15, Art. IX, § 1; amd. 1993 Code)
6-1-2: VEHICLE SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD:
   A.   Width, Length And Height:
      1.   The maximum width and height of any vehicle and its load shall not
exceed the limits expressed in the state traffic law 1 .
      2.   No passenger type vehicle shall be operated on the streets with a
load extending beyond the left side of a vehicle nor extending more than six
inches (6") beyond the right side of any vehicle.
      3.   No vehicle, unladen or with load, shall exceed a length of forty two
feet (42') extreme over all dimension. No combination of vehicles coupled
together shall consist of more than two (2) units, and no such combination of
vehicles, unladen or with load, shall exceed a total length of fifty feet
(50'), but such length limitation shall not apply to vehicles operated in the
daytime when transporting poles, pipes, machinery or other objects which cannot
be readily dismembered nor to such vehicles operated at nighttime by a public
utility when engaged in emergency repair work, but such loads carried at night
shall be clearly marked with sufficient lights to show the full dimensions of
the load.
      4.   No part of the load of a vehicle shall extend more than three feet
(3') in front of the extreme front portion of the vehicle. (1979 Code Ch. 15,
Art. VII, § 5)
   B.   Weight 3 :
      1.   It shall be unlawful to drive on any street any motor vehicle with a
weight, including load, in excess of that permitted by the state traffic law
for driving on improved highways or with a weight distributed in a manner not
conforming to such law 3 . (1979 Code Ch. 15, Art. VII, § 10)
      2.   It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle on any street in the
city except State Routes 104, 29, 48 and Federal Aid Routes 65 and 25, when the
gross weight on the surface of the road exceeds sixteen thousand (16,000)
pounds, except for the purpose of making delivery in the city or picking up a
load within the city, in which case, such vehicle may be driven on such street
for not more than the minimum distances necessary for that purpose. (Ord. 3143,
9-15-2003)
 
Notes
1 2. 625 ILCS 5/15-101 et seq.
3 3. See also section
  6-4-7 of this title.
3 1. 625 ILCS 5/15-111.
6-1-3: SIGNS POSTED:
Signs in the type and description as required by statute 1  shall be installed
at the appropriate places advising motorists of the restrictions contained in
this title. (1993 Code)

1 2. 625 ILCS 5/11-301 et seq.

6-2-1: ARRESTS:
Any person arrested for a violation of any provision of this title shall be
released upon proper bail being furnished as required by statute 1 . The police
officer in command at the station may prescribe the amount of bail or bond in
each instance; provided, that any arrested person may, at his request, have the
amount of such bond set by a judge or circuit clerk as provided by statute.
(1979 Code § 15-10-2)
 
Notes
1 1. ILCS S. Ct. Rule 526.
6-2-2: TRAFFIC TICKETS:
For offenses other than driving while intoxicated or reckless driving, police
officers, after making note of the license number of the vehicle (and name of
the offender where possible), may issue a traffic violation ticket notifying
the offender to appear in court at the time designated for hearing such cases.
If the offender desires to plead guilty at or prior to the initial court
appearance, the prescribed penalty for all city offenses in this title, except
parking violations listed in sections
6-2-3-1 through
6-2-3-11 of this chapter, shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00), including
costs, for each such offense and is payable at the office of the circuit clerk
of Christian County. Such officer may sign a complaint for the issuance of a
warrant if the offender does not appear at the time and place so specified.
(Ord. 2734, 12-18-1995)
6-2-3: PARKING VIOLATIONS:
6-2-3-1: FINES:
   A.   Fines Established: In addition to the towing and impoundment provisions
of this code relating to parking violations, the following penalties will be
applicable to the owner or operator who is issued a traffic violation notice
for violating any of the provisions listed below, providing the amount listed
is paid to the city treasurer within fourteen (14) days beginning on the first
day after the issuance of the notice or as specified below. Payments received
by mail shall be credited as paid on the date of postmark.
Blocking alley                                   $ 10.00
Double parking                                   10.00
Improper parking                                 10.00
No parking zone                                  10.00
Overtime parking in limited parking zone or area 10.00
Parking by a fire hydrant                        10.00
Parking in a handicapped parking space           250.00
Parking in fire zone                             10.00
Parking on wrong side of street                  10.00
All other traffic violations not listed          15.00
 
   B.   Late Payment Of Fines: If the violation notice is not paid within
fourteen (14) days, beginning on the day after issuance of the notice, the
person may avoid prosecution for violating a parking provision only by paying
the following amounts:
Blocking alley                                   $ 15.00
Double parking                                   15.00
Improper parking                                 15.00
No parking zone                                  15.00
Overtime parking in limited parking zone or area 15.00
Parking by a fire hydrant                        15.00
Parking in a handicapped parking space           350.00
Parking in fire zone                             30.00
Parking on wrong side of street                  15.00
All other traffic violations not listed          30.00
 
(Ord. 3146, 10-20-2003; amd. Ord. 3394, 8-4-2008)
   C.   Failure To Pay Fines: The owner or operator of any vehicle or
pedestrian cited for violation of any parking or pedestrian restriction of this
section who shall fail to pay the sums provided above to avoid prosecution for
the offense, shall be prosecuted for violating this section and upon
conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) for overtime parking, and not less than thirty dollars ($30.00) for
all other violations, excluding the fine for parking in handicapped parking
spaces. All fines are exclusive of court costs. No fine shall be more than
three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for any single offense. (Ord. 3414, 1-20-
2009)
   D.   Payment Of Fines; Receipt; Disposition Of Funds: The sum as herein
provided shall be paid to the municipality by inserting such sum in the
envelope type notice of such violation attached to the illegally parked vehicle
and depositing the same in any of the courtesy boxes conspicuously located in
the city square, such box being plainly marked for such purpose, or by
delivering the sum specified on such notice of violation to the office of the
city treasurer in the city hall.
A receipt shall be issued for all money so received in person by the city
treasurer's office and such money shall be deposited by the city treasurer to
be used in the manner provided for the disposition of fines for traffic
violations. Upon payment of such sums as herein provided, the members of the
police department are hereby authorized to refrain from instituting a
prosecution for the alleged offense involved.
   E.   Responsibility: In all cases of parking violations except as provided
in subsection F of this section, the persons in whose name the vehicle is
registered shall be responsible for the violation, as well as the person in
whose actual possession the vehicle was, at the time of the violation.
   F.   Information Provided: Every person in whose name a vehicle is
registered pursuant to law and who leases the vehicle to others after receiving
written notice of a violation of this traffic code or any ordinance restricting
or prohibiting parking involving the vehicle, shall, upon written request by
the city, provide the city with the name, address, and other identifying
material of the lessee at the time of the offense, and the identifying number
upon the registration sticker or stickers of the vehicle. (Ord. 2733, 12-18-
1995)
   G.   Prosecution: The city may prosecute in a court of law any person
receiving parking violations as defined in this title and/or refer any one or
more of said parking violations to a collection agency to collect the amount
due the city. (Ord. 3435, 8-3-2009)
