      5.   Restrictions On Issuance Of Permit: A building sewer permit will
only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be
demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump
stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity
to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load.
   B.   Separate Sewers Required: A separate and independent building sewer
shall be provided for every building; except, that where one building stands at
the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can
be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or
driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the
rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer.
   C.   Construction Specifications:
      1.   Private Sewers: All new private sewers within a building or within
five feet (5') of any part of a building or within ten feet (10') of a water
service pipe shall be cast iron soil pipe ASTM specification (A 74) and shall
comply with the Illinois state plumbing code, latest edition 1 . New private
sanitary sewers beyond the limits described above for connection with the
public sewer shall be one of the following:
         a.   Cast iron soil pipe - ASTM specification A 74.
         b.   Vitrified clay sewer pipe - ASTM specification C 13 or C 700.
         c.   Concrete sewer pipe - ASTM specification C 14, C 75 or C 76.
         d.   ABS sewer pipe.
         e.   PVC sewer pipe - ASTM D-3033, SDR 34 for 4", SDR 41 for 6",
schedule 40.
Any pipe material not conforming to the requirements of the above ASTM
specifications will not be permitted unless specific approval is granted by
vote of the city council.
      2.   Public Sewers:
         a.   Joints on all house sewers shall be made permanently gastight and
waterproof.
         b.   Cast iron soil pipe shall be jointed with lead and jute by a
competent plumber.
         c.   Vitrified clay pipe shall be fitted with factory made plastic
joint conforming to ASTM specifications C-425.
         d.   Concrete pipe shall be fitted with factory furnished rubber
gaskets which shall conform to ASTM specification 361, section 13. Rubber
gasket joints shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's
instructions and shall provide a watertight and gastight joint.
         e.   Joints between vitrified clay and concrete pipe or metal shall be
made with jute and a bituminous jointing material. Bituminous material for such
joints shall not soften sufficiently to destroy the effectiveness of the joints
when subjected to a temperature of one hundred sixty degrees Fahrenheit (160°F)
nor be soluble in any of the wastes carried by the drainage system. The
superintendent of streets and sewers may, at his discretion, require the
additional protection of a concrete envelope on such joints.
         f.   ABS pipe shall be chemically welded joints conforming to ASTM
specification D2680-72 and latest revisions.
         g.   PVC pipe shall have rubber gasketed joints.
   D.   Connections To Public Sewers:
      1.   The applicant for a permit to tap a public sewer shall notify the
city when such sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public
sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent
of streets and sewers or his authorized representative.
      2.   The connection of the building or property sewer shall be made at a
"Y" or "T" branch if such a branch is available at a suitable location. If no
properly located "Y" or "T" branch is available, a neat hole may be cut into
the public sewer to receive the building or property sewer, with entry in the
downstream direction, at an angle of about forty five degrees (45°). A "saddle"
shall be used to make such connections, the spigot end to extend not past the
inner surface of such sewer. The centerline of the building sewer at the point
of connection shall be at the same or a higher elevation than the centerline of
the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made and the connection made
secure and watertight by encasement, if necessary, in concrete. Other fittings
may be used for the connection only when approved by the superintendent of
streets and sewers.
      3.   The sewer systems from any residences or commercial establishments
constructed after the effective date hereof shall be constructed and connected
with the public sewer in full compliance with this chapter. Where existing
septic tanks combine sanitary sewage with roof drains or foundation drains or
drain tile capable of collecting surface or subsurface water, a complete
separation shall be made so that only sanitary sewer wastes are carried
directly in watertight joints to the public sewer. Where any doubt exists on
the type or quality of construction, the superintendent of streets and sewers
may require the owner to uncover the existing service for inspection. Where any
doubt exists on the complete separation of roof drains, surface drains or
surface drain tile, the superintendent of streets and sewers may require the
owner of the establishment to prove, by excavation and exposure, that complete
separation exists.
      4.   Where a building presently connected to a septic tank desires to
connect to the public sewer, the connection shall be made from the public sewer
to the service piping upstream of the septic tank if it is demonstrated that
the existing service piping is in satisfactory condition. Under no
circumstances shall the connection be made on the downstream side of the septic
tank nor shall any septic tank laterals be connected to the public sewer.
      5.   No basement, half basement or any other portion of a building having
a floor elevation beneath the ground surface over the public sewer at the point
of connection may be connected into the public sewer by gravity. In areas where
the ground line over the public sewer is to be altered, the proposed final
ground elevation shall be used. The maximum depth to the top of the building
service sewer shall be three feet (3') below finished grade at the point where
it enters such building. In all buildings in which the building drain is too
low to provide gravity flow to the public sewer, all sewage carried by such
drain shall be lifted by approved mechanical means and discharged into the
building sewer. No water operated sewage ejector shall be used.
   E.   Extensions/Connections:
      1.   If an extension of one of the sewer mains is required for
connection, the city council shall first determine if an extension of a sewer
main is economically feasible based on the estimated cost of the extension and
the number of existing or potential users that will use the sewer along the
extension and if such extension will enhance the overall economic benefit to
the city.
If the extension is approved, the city may, in its sole discretion, install and
pay, in whole or in part, the cost of such extension to the nearest property
boundary line of the first property to be serviced from such extension. If the
city elects, in its sole discretion, not to pay such cost, in whole or in part,
then the property owner(s) shall pay the cost, which the city has elected not
to pay, to extend such sewer main from the nearest location of the then
existing sewer main to the property to be serviced.
In any event, and in all cases in which there is to be any connection to the
city's sanitary sewer main, the property owner (developer) shall pay the cost
to extend the sanitary sewer main the entire width or length (depending upon
the direction of such extension) of the property owner's property to be
serviced and/or for such additional distance or direction along the property
owner's property to be serviced, as determined by the city council from time to
time, and shall be installed at the maximum depth and at minimum grade as
determined by the city engineer or the street and sewer superintendent, so that
such extension, after completion thereof, immediately borders adjacent property
in such a manner that future extensions can directly be made to service
adjacent property or properties.
Such "costs", as referred to herein, shall include, but not be limited to, all
engineering fees, the city's attorney fees, all recording fees, all cost for
survey and easement plats, all costs relating to easement instruments, all
title insurance fees and all costs, materials, equipment, and labor relating to
and for the construction of such sewer main extension.
Such sewer main extension shall be constructed according to such plans and
specifications as may be determined by the city council from time to time. If
the city elects not to perform the work to install such extension or have
others do so on behalf of the city, then the property owner(s) must obtain the
written consent and approval of the city as to the contractor(s) who will
install such sewer extension. Any such "costs" owed to the city shall be paid
to the city by such property owner(s) within fourteen (14) days of mailing of a
bill therefor to such property owner(s) or their representative, or prior to
any connection to such extension, whichever event first occurs. Prior to any
such extension, the property owner(s) shall sign and provide the city with
permanent easements and temporary construction easements for such sewer main
extension in such form as the city council may determine from time to time. The
foregoing requirements shall also be deemed as additional requirements under
title 11 of this code.
      2.   If someone other than the city installs an extension of one of the
sewer mains, the city must approve all plans and specifications for any
extensions. Ownership, rights of way and title must be conveyed to the city for
all extensions installed by anyone other than the city. The city will maintain
the mains thereafter.
No extension will be permitted if, in the opinion of the city council, the
system does not have the necessary capacity to serve the proposed extension.
   F.   Surface Water Runoff:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to construct or permit the construction of any
stormwater drain which discharges water onto any sidewalk in the city, and it
shall be unlawful to construct or permit the maintenance of any such drain
which discharges into any public street or alley at a height greater than
eighteen inches (18") above the ground or pavement.
      2.   No drain tile or foundation tile which could or does collect surface
or subsurface water shall be constructed directly to the sanitary sewer system
of the city.
   G.   Cross Connections: It shall be unlawful to permit any sanitary sewage
to flow into any drain, gutter or pipe installed for the flow of surface water
drainage only or to permit sanitary sewage to flow into the stormwater drainage
system.
   H.   Excavations:
      1.   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
      2.   Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in
the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city.
      3.   The provisions of all city ordinances relating to excavations 1  in
streets or other public places shall be complied with in making sewer
connections.
   I.   Liability Of Property Owner:
      1.   All costs and expenses incident to the initial installation of the
property owner's building sewer service line and connection (tap on) of the
property owner's building sewer service line to the City's public sewer system
(trunk line) shall be borne and paid by the property owner. Such initial
installation and connection work shall be performed by an Illinois licensed
plumber; and all such installation and connection work must be performed to the
satisfaction of the City Street and Sewer Superintendent or his designee. The
City shall provide the "saddle tap" for the connection (tap on) of the property
owner's building sewer service line to the City's public sewer system (trunk
line); and any "Y" tap must be separated from the City's public sewer system
(trunk line).
      2.   The property owner shall be solely responsible and liable for the
expenses, maintenance, repair, and/or replacement of the property owner's
building sewer service line up to its connection (tap on) to the City's public
sewer system (trunk line) wheresoever located. All such maintenance, repair,
and/or replacement work shall be performed by an Illinois licensed plumber.
In extenuating cost circumstances, the City Council may, in its sole discretion
and upon recommendation from the City's Street and Sewer Committee from time to
time, review and determine responsibility of the property owner for any
maintenance, repair, and/or replacement work to the property owner's building
sewer service line up to its connection (tap on) to the City's public sewer
system (trunk line) to the extent said building sewer service line is located
outside the property owner's property boundary lines but is located within City
property.
      3.   The City shall repair and/or replace such portion of the City's
public sewer system (trunk line) and/or the public sewer connection (tap) to
the property owners' sewer service line (but not the property owner's sewer
service line itself) that is located within the City's property or within the
City's right of way or easement.
Provided the property owner provides the City with free access to the property
owner's property, the City may also repair such portion of the City's public
sewer system (but not the property owner's sewer service line itself) up to the
property owner's sewer service line connection (tap) to the City's public sewer
system (trunk line) that is located within the property owner's property
boundary lines (but outside of the City's right of way or easement area located
on the property owner's property).
      4.   The City's Street and Sewer Superintendent or his designee shall
determine in his or her sole discretion the reasonableness and necessity and
the nature and extent of any and all of the aforesaid repair or replacement
work to protect and maintain and avoid any further damage to the City's public
sewer system.
   J.   Disconnection From Sewers: Any person desiring or planning to
disconnect from a sewer outlet in the city sewer and sanitary system shall
first notify the superintendent of streets and sewers of the intention to so
disconnect and, in no event, shall such person commence action to disconnect
from the sewer outlet until either the superintendent of streets and sewers or
his duly authorized representative is available to inspect and approve the
disconnection.
   K.   South Houston Street Storm Sewer Project:
      1.   The term "storm sewer" as used in this subsection K shall mean the
underground stormwater sewer, approximately three thousand five hundred thirty
(3,530) linear feet of thirty six inch (36") diameter storm sewer pipe, to be
constructed by the city in 2004, commencing from the existing ward III storm
sewer line at the intersection of Vandeveer Street and South Houston Street
thence south approximately one thousand seven hundred ten feet (1,710'), thence
east approximately seven hundred ten feet (710') along the south line of
Houston Street Subdivision (such 710 feet of storm sewer to be constructed and
installed, including all materials, labor, and equipment, by Windsor
Development Group, Inc., and Michael Niehaus at their sole costs and expense),
thence south approximately three hundred ten feet (310'), thence east
approximately six hundred feet (600'), thence north two hundred feet (200') to
a point at or near the existing Taylorville sanitary district existing combined
sanitary and storm sewer line in Cheney Street.
      2.   The term "area benefited by the storm sewer" shall mean all real
property located within the area as is located within the following described
boundary lines: Commencing at the intersection of Henrietta Street and
Vandeveer Street, thence east along Vandeveer Street to the intersection of
Shumway Street, then south along Shumway Street to West Calvert Street, then
southwesterly along West Calvert Street to the intersection of Cheney Street,
then north along Cheney Street, to the intersection of Gilpin Street, then west
along Gilpin Street to the intersection of Houston Street, then northwesterly
to the point of beginning. A map of the "area benefited by the storm sewer" is
on file with the city clerk's office and is available for public inspection
during the city clerk's normal business hours.
      3.   It shall be unlawful to utilize, uncover, make any connection with,
or opening into, use, alter, or disturb the storm sewer without first obtaining
a written permit issued by the city clerk, after approval by the city council.
      4.   Commencing February 1, 2004, and thereafter, no final subdivision
plat and/or development project involving any land located within the "area
benefited by the storm sewer", which subdivision or development project is
subject to any of the provisions of title 11, "Land Subdivisions", and/or title
12, "Flood Control", of this code, as now enacted or hereafter amended, shall
be approved by the city until and unless the applicant for such approval shall
first obtain a city permit and pay the city a permit fee in accordance with the
rate set forth in subsection K6 of this section.
      5.   Any person, firm, or corporation desiring such permit shall make
written application to the city, which application shall be supplemented by
detailed plans and specifications for utilization of the storm sewer or for the
construction of a proposed storm sewer connection. Such application shall also
contain a signed statement by a registered engineer that the size of the storm
sewer connection will in his or her opinion be adequate to drain the area
served by the storm sewer connection.
      6.   Such permit fee shall be computed at the rate of one thousand four
hundred twenty five dollars ($1,425.00) per acre or the prorated amount of said
one thousand four hundred twenty five dollars ($1,425.00) for any portion of an
acre. In determining the appropriate permit fee, the entire tract of land or
lands that will be subdivided or the entire tract of land or lands upon which
the development project will occur shall all be considered in computing the
acreage for application of rate of one thousand four hundred twenty five
dollars ($1,425.00) per acre.
      7.   Such permit fee shall be paid at the time the application for such
permit is submitted. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the
twenty five thousand dollar ($25,000.00) permit fee for Windsor Development
Group, Inc., and Michael Niehaus identified in that certain intergovernmental
cooperation agreement by and between the city of Taylorville sanitary district,
said corporation, and Niehaus with an effective date of February 1, 2004, shall
control and be applicable to said corporation and Niehaus subject to the terms
of said agreement. Furthermore, such permit fee shall not be applicable to the
city nor to the Taylorville Community Unit school district who has agreed to
grant a permanent easement to the city to allow the construction and
maintenance of the storm sewer on a portion of school property or to the
Taylorville sanitary district who has agreed to pay up to the sum of fifty five
thousand dollars ($55,000.00) toward the installation and construction costs
and engineering fees for the storm sewer.
      8.   All costs and expenses incidental to the installation of the storm
sewer connection shall be borne by the applicant. The applicant shall indemnify
and hold harmless the city from any loss or damage that may directly or
indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the storm sewer connection. The
connection when authorized shall be made under the supervision of the city's
street and sewer superintendent, and shall be made only by a licensed master
plumber who has filed the required bond, if any, in accordance with this code.
      9.   It shall be unlawful to throw, run, drain, or otherwise dispose of,
into the storm sewer, or cause, suffer, permit to be thrown, run, drained,
allowed to seep, or otherwise disposed of, into the storm sewer, any organic or
inorganic matter that may cause pollution of the waters in the storm sewer.
      10.   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this
subsection K shall be fined and/or sentenced, upon conviction, in accordance
with section
1-4-1 of this code.
   L.   Use Of City Storm Sewer:
      1.   The term "sewer" as used in this subsection shall mean the
underground storm sewer throughout the city of Taylorville.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to uncover, make any connection with, or
opening into, use, alter, or disturb the "sewer" without first obtaining a
written permit from the street and sewer department of the city of Taylorville.
      3.   Any person, firm or corporation desiring a permit shall make written
application to the city, which application shall be supplemented by plans and
specifications for the construction of the proposed storm sewer connection.
Said application shall also contain a signed statement by a registered engineer
that the size of the storm sewer connection will in his opinion be adequate to
drain the area served by the storm sewer connection.
      4.   The fee for construction of a connection into the sewer shall be
computed as follows:

      5.   All costs and expenses incidental to the installation of the
stormwater sewer connection shall be borne by the applicant. The applicant
shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or
indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the connecting stormwater
sewer. The connection when authorized shall be made under the direct
supervision of the superintendent of streets and sewers of the city of
Taylorville, and shall be made only by a licensed master plumber who has filed
the required bond, if any, in accordance with applicable city ordinances and
providing a certificate of insurance to the city clerk's office listing the
city of Taylorville as certificate holder and as additional insured with the
following language "city of Taylorville, Illinois, a municipal corporation, and
its elected and/or appointed mayor, city council, officials, officers,
employees and agents".
      6.   It shall be unlawful to throw, run, drain, or otherwise dispose of,
into the "sewer", or cause, suffer, permit to be thrown, run, drained, allowed
to seep, or otherwise disposed of, into such sewer, any organic or inorganic
matter that shall cause pollution of the waters in such sewer.
      7.   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this
subsection shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense; and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues. (Ord. 2078, 11-15-1982; amd.Ord. 2538, 3-21-1994; Ord.

8-5-5: USE RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Prohibited Substances: No person shall discharge or cause to be
discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public
sewers:
      1.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid or gas.
      2.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids
or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other
wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a
hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance or create any hazard in
the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
      3.   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having any other
corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment
and personnel of the sewage works.
      4.   Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of
causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper
operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders,
sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood,
unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and
paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage
grinders.
   B.   Materials Under Special Review:
      1.   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following
described substances, materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely, in the
opinion of the superintendent of streets and sewers, that such wastes can
endanger life, limb, public property or constitute a nuisance. In forming his
opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the superintendent will give
consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation
to flows and velocities in the sewers and materials of construction of the
sewers. The substances prohibited are:
         a.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (65°C).
         b.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or
oil, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter
(100 mg/l) or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at
temperatures between thirty two degrees (32°) and one hundred fifty degrees
Fahrenheit (150°F) (0° and 65°C).
         c.   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/
4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to review and
approval of the superintendent.
         d.   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes
or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not.
         e.   Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc or
similar objectionable or toxic substances, or wastes exerting an excessive
chlorine requirement.
         f.   Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 milligrams per liter at any time
except as permitted by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state
and federal regulations.
      2.   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be
discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess
the characteristics enumerated in subsection B1 of this section and/or which
are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in chapter 1, EPA
rules and regulations, subchapter D, Water Programs Part 128-Pretreatment
Standards, federal register volume 38, No. 215, Thursday, November 8, 1973, and
any amendments thereto, and which, in the judgment of the superintendent, may
have a deleterious effect upon the sewer system or which otherwise create a
hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may:
         a.   Reject the wastes.
         b.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to
the public sewers.
         c.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge.
If the superintendent permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows,
the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the
review and approval of the superintendent and subject to the requirements of
all applicable codes, ordinances and laws.
   C.   Interceptors: Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when,
in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper
handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts or any
flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except, that such
interceptors shall not be required for private living quarter or dwelling
units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the
superintendent and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for
cleaning and inspection.
   D.   Preliminary Treatment: Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing
facilities are provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory
and effective operation by the owner at his expense.
   E.   Control Manhole For Industrial Wastes: Each industry shall be required
to install a control manhole and, when required by the superintendent, the
owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes
shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters
and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation,
sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be
accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans
approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at
his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at
all times.
   F.   Measurements, Tests And Analyses:
      1.   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying
industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests and analyses of
waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and any special
conditions for discharge established by the city or regulatory agencies having
jurisdiction over the discharge. The number, type and frequency of laboratory
analysis to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the city, but
no less than once per year the industry must supply a complete analysis of the
constituents of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the
federal, state and local standards are being met. The owner shall report the
results of measurements and laboratory analysis to the city at such times and
in such manner as prescribed by the city. The owner shall bear the expense of
all measurements, analyses and reporting required by the city. At such times as
deemed necessary, the city reserves the right to take measurements and samples
for analysis by an outside laboratory service.
      2.   All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of
waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be
determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods For The
Examination Of Water And Wastewater", published by the American Public Health
Association and shall be determined at the control manhole provided or upon
suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special
manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the
nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the
building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily
accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works
and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. (The
particular analysis involved will determine whether a 24 hour composite of all
outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples
should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses
are obtained from 24 hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pHs are
determined from periodic grab samples.)
   G.   Special Agreements: No statement contained in this section shall be
construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city
and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or
character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment
therefor, by the industrial concern; provided such payments are in accordance
with federal and state guidelines for user charge system and industrial cost
recovery system. (Ord. 2078, 11-15-1982)
   H.   Control Of Fats, Oils, And Greases:
      1.   Scope And Purpose: To aid in the prevention of sanitary sewer
blockages and obstructions from contributions and accumulation of fats, oils,
and greases into the sanitary sewer system from industrial or commercial
establishments, particularly food preparation and serving facilities. Any
nonresidential facility connected to the city's sanitary sewer collection and
treatment system involved in the preparation or serving of foods shall be
subject to the conditions of this section.
      2.   Definitions:
         FATS, OILS, AND GREASES: Organic polar compounds derived from animal
and/or plant sources that contain multiple carbon chain triglyceride molecules.
These substances are detectable and measurable using analytical test procedures
established in the United States code of federal regulations 40 CFR 136, as may
be amended from time to time. All are sometimes referred to herein as "grease"
or "greases".
         FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS: Those establishments primarily engaged in
activities of preparing, serving, or otherwise making available for consumption
by the public such as restaurant, commercial kitchen, caterer, hotel, school,
hospital, prison, correctional facility, and care institution. These
establishments use one or more of the following preparation activities: cooking
by frying (all methods), baking (all methods), grilling, sauteing, rotisserie
cooking, broiling (all methods), boiling, blanching, roasting, toasting, or
poaching. Also included are infrared heating, searing, barbecuing, and any
other food preparation activity that produces a hot, nondrinkable food product
in or on a receptacle that requires washing.
         GREASE INTERCEPTOR: A structure or device designed for the purpose of
removing and preventing fats, oils, and grease from entering the sanitary sewer
collection system. These devices are often belowground units in outside areas
and are built as two (2) or three (3) chamber baffled tanks.
         GREASE TRAP: A device for separating and retaining waterborne greases
and grease complexes prior to the wastewater exiting the trap and entering the
sanitary sewer collection and treatment system. Such traps are typically
compact under the sink units that are near food preparation areas.
         MINIMUM DESIGN CAPABILITY: The design features of a grease interceptor
and its ability or volume required to effectively intercept and retain greases
from grease laden wastewaters discharged to the public sanitary sewer.
         USER: Any person, including those located outside the jurisdictional
limits of the city of Taylorville, who contributes, causes or permits the
contribution or discharge of wastewater into sewers within the city's
boundaries, including persons who contribute such wastewater from mobile
sources, such as those who discharge hauled wastewater.
      3.   Food Service Establishment Permit Requirement: All permitted food
service establishments discharging wastewater to the city of Taylorville
sanitary sewer collection system are subject to the following requirements:
         a.   Grease Interceptor Requirements: All permitted food service
establishments are required to install, operate, and maintain an approved type
and adequately sized grease interceptor necessary to maintain compliance with
the objectives of this subsection H. All grease interceptors must meet the
requirements of the state of Illinois plumbing code.
         b.   Implementation: All new food service establishment facilities are
subject to grease interceptor requirements. All such facilities must obtain
prior approval from the state plumber/city engineer and county inspector for
grease interceptor sizing prior to submitting plans for a building permit. All
grease interceptors shall be installed outside the building for cleaning and
inspection. Existing facilities with planned modification in plumbing
improvements, with a building permit evaluation of twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) or more will be required to include plans to comply with the
grease interceptor requirements. These facilities must obtain approval from the
state plumber/city engineer and county inspector for grease interceptor sizing
prior to submitting plans for a building permit.
All existing food service establishments, determined by the state plumber/city
engineer and county inspector, to have a reasonable potential to adversely
impact the city's sewer system will be notified of their obligation to install
a grease interceptor within the specified period set forth in the notification
letter.
         c.   Variance From Grease Interceptor Requirements: Grease
interceptors required under this subsection H shall be installed unless the
state plumber/city engineer and county inspector authorizes the installation of
an indoor grease trap or other alternative pretreatment technology and
determines that the installation of a grease interceptor would not be feasible.
The food service establishment bears the burden of demonstrating that the
installation of a grease interceptor is not feasible. The state plumber/city
engineer or county inspector may authorize the installation of an indoor grease
trap where the installation of a grease interceptor is not feasible due to
space constraints or other considerations. If an establishment believes the
installation of a grease interceptor is infeasible, because of documented space
constraints, the request for an alternate grease removal device shall contain
the following information:
            (1)   Location of sewer main and easement in relation to available
exterior space outside building.
            (2)   Existing plumbing at or in a site that uses common plumbing
for all services at that site.
Alternative pretreatment technology includes, but is not limited to, devices
that are used to trap, separate and hold grease from wastewater and prevent it
from being discharged into the sanitary sewer collection system. All
alternative pretreatment technology must be appropriately sized and approved by
the State plumber/City Engineer and County inspector.
      4.   Grease Interceptor Requirements:
         a.   Grease interceptor sizing and installation shall conform to the
current edition of the State of Illinois Plumbing Code.
         b.   Grease interceptors shall be constructed in accordance with
design approved by the State plumber/City Engineer and County inspector and
shall have a minimum of two (2) compartments with fittings designed for grease
retention.
         c.   Grease interceptors shall be installed outside at a location
where it shall be easily accessible for inspection, cleaning, and removal of
intercepted grease. The grease interceptor may not be installed in any part of
the building where food is handled. Location of the grease interceptor must
meet the approval of the State plumber/City Engineer and County inspector.
         d.   All such grease interceptors shall be serviced and emptied of
accumulated waste content at least every three (3) months or when needed in
order to maintain minimum design capability or effective volume. These devices
should be inspected at least monthly. Users who are required to maintain a
grease interceptor shall:
            (1)   Provide for a minimum hydraulic retention time in accordance
with the State of Illinois Plumbing Code.
            (2)   Remove any accumulated grease cap and sludge pocket as
required. Grease interceptors shall be kept free of inorganic solid materials
such as grit, rocks, gravel, sand, eating utensils, cigarettes, shells, towels,
rags, etc., which could settle into this pocket and thereby reduce the
effective volume of the device.
         e.   The user shall maintain a written record of inspection and
maintenance for two (2) years. All such records will be made available for on
site inspection by representative of the City of Taylorville during all
operating hours.
         f.   The users shall give the City of Taylorville written record of
cleaning of grease interceptor every three (3) months or when City of
Taylorville Sewer Superintendent or County inspector say when written records
are required. If not in compliance, City of Taylorville may fine user seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and/or shut off water. The fine set forth
herein is an addition to any penalty as set forth in Section
 8-5-9 of this Chapter.
         g.   Sanitary wastes are not allowed to be connected to sewer lines
intended for grease interceptor service.
         h.   Access manholes, with a minimum diameter of twenty four inches
(24"), shall be provided over each grease interceptor chamber and sanitary tee.
The access manholes shall extend at least to finished grade and be designed and
maintained to prevent water inflow or infiltration. The manholes shall also
have readily removable covers to facilitate inspection, grease removal, and
wastewater sampling activities.
      5.   Grease Trap Requirements:
         a.   Upon approval by the State plumber/City Engineer and County
inspector, a grease trap complying with the provisions of this Section must be
installed in the waste line leading from sinks, drains, and other fixtures or
equipment in food service establishments where grease may be introduced into
the drainage or sewage system in quantities that can effect line stoppage or
hinder sewage treatment or private sewage disposal.
         b.   Grease traps sizing and installation shall conform to the State
of Illinois Plumbing Code.
         c.   No grease trap shall be installed which has a stated rate flow of
more than fifty five (55) gallons per minute, nor less than twenty (20) gallons
per minute, except when specially approved by the State plumber/City Engineer
and County inspector.
         d.   Grease traps shall be maintained in efficient operating
conditions by periodic removal of the accumulated grease. No such collected
grease shall be introduced into any drainage piping, or public or private
sewer.
         e.   No food waste disposal unit or dishwasher shall be connected to
or discharge into any grease trap.
         f.   Wastewater in excess of one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit
(140°F)/(60°C) shall not be discharged into a grease trap. (Ord. 3514, 5-16-
2011)
8-5-6: WASTEWATER SERVICE RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Rates And Charges Established: There are hereby established rates or
charges for the use of the sewer system of the City based upon the amount of
water used, as shown by the water metered as follows:
      1.   Service Charge:
         a.   Each sewer user who is also a City water user at the same
premises shall pay a service charge in the amount of two dollars ($2.00) per
monthly period.
         b.   Each residential sewer user who is not also a City water user at
the same premises shall pay a service charge in the amount of five dollars
($5.00) per monthly period.
         c.   Each commercial sewer user who is not also a City water user at
the same premises shall pay a service charge in the amount of fifteen dollars
($15.00) per monthly period.
      2.   Volume Charge: In addition to a service charge, each sewer user
shall pay a volume charge based on the volume of water used as shown by the
water meter at the following rates:
         a.   Commencing January 1, 2025: $0.00400 per gallon of water; and
         b.   Commencing January 1, 2026: $0.00425 per gallon of water; and
         c.   Commencing January 1, 2027: $0.00450 per gallon of water; and
         d.   Commencing January 1, 2028: $0.00475 per gallon of water.
      3.   In the event of sewer users who do not purchase water from the City,
the volume charge will be based on metered water use, metered sewer use, or an
estimate of sewer use as determined by the Superintendent of Public Works and/
or Superintendent of Streets and Sewers.
      4.   Debt Service Charge: (Rep. by Ord. 2822, 2-3-1998)
      5.   Annual Review; Revisions: Following each annual audit of fiscal
years ending April 30, the City will review (on the basis of the past year's
audit and volumes and strengths of wastes treated) the sewer rates, including
service charges, volume charges and debt service charge. Revisions will be
made, if appropriate, to take effect as soon as practicable.
   B.   Bills For Sewer Service; Delinquencies: Rates or charges for sewer
service shall be payable monthly. Each sewer customer for use of the sewer
service at the subject premises shall be jointly and severally liable to pay
for the sewer service on such premises, and the sewer service is furnished to
such premises by the City only upon the condition that each sewer customer for
the use of the sewer service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the
City. All sewer service bills will be issued with the water service bills
issued by the City, and all payment provisions, delinquent charges and
collection procedures used by the City in the collection of water service bills
shall be used in the collection of the sewer user charges. For purposes of this
Section, "sewer customer" shall mean and include each person and/or entity in
whose name the sewer service is in and/or who has signed any City document to
provide for sewer service for the subject premises according to the City's
records at the time of the rendering of such bill.
The City Treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and
all other funds and monies incident to the operation of such system as the same
may be delivered to him or her and deposit the same in the account of the fund
designated as the "Sewerage Fund of the City". The City Treasurer shall
administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by statute of the
"Revised Cities and Villages Act", effective January 1942 1 .
   C.   Disposition Of Revenues: All revenues and monies derived from the
operation of the sewerage system shall be deposited in the sewerage account of
the Sewerage Fund. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the City
Treasurer separate and apart from his private funds and separate and apart from
all other funds of the City, and all of said sum, without any deductions
whatever, shall be delivered to the City Treasurer not more than ten (10) days
after receipt of the same or at such more frequent intervals as may, from time
to time, be directed by the Mayor and Council.
   D.   Books And Accounts; Audit:
      1.   The City Treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and
shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct
entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and
at regular annual intervals, he shall cause to be made an audit by an
independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the sewerage system.
In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report
shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater
facilities, including a replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service
charges under the waste cost recovery system do in fact meet these regulations.
In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report shall
include the following:
         a.   Billing data to show total number of gallons billed.
         b.   Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
         c.   Number of users connected to the system.
         d.   Number of nonmetered users.
         e.   A list of users discharging nondomestic wastes (industrial users)
and volume of waste discharged.
      2.   The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or its authorized
representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of
the City which are applicable to the City system of user charges for the
purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to
ensure compliance with the term of the special and general conditions to any
State grant.
   E.   Notice Of Rates: A copy of this Section, properly certified by the City
Treasurer, shall be filed in the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of Christian
County and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of the charges
of the sewerage system of the City on their properties. In addition, the City
Treasurer shall notify each user at least annually, in conjunction with a
regular bill, of the rate attributable to treatment services.
   F.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of subsections B through E
of this Section shall be fined in the amount not exceeding fifty dollars
($50.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2089, 4-4-1983; amd. Ord. 2822, 2-3-1998; Ord. 3728, 9-9-2015; Ord. 3831,
2-5-2018; Ord. 3887, 3-4-2019; Ord. 4019, 2-16-2021; Ord. 4285, 12-16-2024)

8-5-7: PROTECTION FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break,
damage, destroy or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which
is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be
subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. (Ord. 2078, 11-
15-1982)
8-5-8: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   A.   The Superintendent of Streets and Sewers and other duly authorized
employees of the City, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and the
U.S. environmental protection agency, bearing proper credentials and
identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of
inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter. The superintendent or his representative shall
have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical,
chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point
having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or
waterways.
   B.   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in subsection A of this section, the superintendent or duly authorized
employees of the city, the Illinois environmental protection agency and the
U.S. environmental protection agency shall observe all safety rules applicable
to the premises established by the owner, and the owner shall be held harmless
for injury or death to the city employees, and the city shall indemnify the
owner against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against
liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted
against the owner and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation by city
employees or officials, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure
of the owner to maintain safe conditions as required in subsection 8-5-5E of
this chapter.
   C.   The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city,
bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all
private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for
the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying
within said easement. All entry and subsequent works, if any, on said easement
shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved. (Ord. 2078, 11-15-1982)
8-5-9: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
   A.   Notice Of Violation: Any person who violates any provision of this
chapter, except section
 8-5-7 of this chapter, shall be served by the city with a written notice
stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit (not
to exceed a 30 consecutive calendar days time period) for the satisfactory
correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in
such notice, permanently cease or correct or remedy all violations.
   B.   Penalties: Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time
limit provided for in subsection A of this section shall be fined for each
offense as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
   C.   Revocation Of Permit; Water Termination: In addition, and not in lieu
of any fines or costs imposed, the city may revoke any permit for sewage
disposal or a private sanitary sewage system as a result of any violation of
any provision of this chapter and may also terminate any and all water service
to the subject property until and unless the violation(s) is/are corrected to
the satisfaction of the city. (Ord. 3683, 9-2-2014)
8-5-10: SURFACE WATER RUNOFF:
   A.   Definitions: When used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
   BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sanitary
sewer or other place of disposal.
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, partnership, association, society,
corporation or group.
   PUBLIC SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which is controlled by public authority which
carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters, and groundwaters are
not intentionally admitted.
   SHALL/MAY: The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive.
   SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS AND SEWERS: The superintendent of streets and
sewers for the city of Taylorville, or his authorized deputy, agent or
representative.
   B.   Connection Of Sources Of Roof Water, Surface Water Runoff Or
Groundwater To Building Sewers Restricted:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to and no person shall hereafter make
connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, tile
drains, subsurface drains or other sources of roof water, surface water runoff,
or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
      2.   All existing connections of roof downspouts, exterior foundation
drains, areaway drains, tile drains, subsurface drains, or other sources of
roof water, surface water runoff, or groundwater to a building sewer or
building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public
sanitary sewer are hereby declared unlawful. Any person who now has such
connections declared herein to be unlawful shall have until January 1, 1995, in
which to disconnect, at their sole expense, any and all roof downspouts,
exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, tile drains, subsurface drains, or
other sources of roof water, surface water runoff, or groundwater from any
building sewer or drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a
public sanitary sewer. No such person shall be deemed in violation of this
section by virtue of such illegal connection until after January 1, 1995. In
addition thereto, such person shall, immediately at the time of such
disconnection, properly cap and cover the point of disconnect with the building
sewer or building drain in accordance with and in the manner as may be required
by the superintendent of streets and sewers.
   C.   Right Of Entry For Inspection And Observation: The superintendent of
streets and sewers and other authorized employees of the city bearing proper
credentials and identification shall have access to and be permitted to enter
all properties for the purposes of inspection and observation to determine
whether compliance has been accomplished in accordance with the provisions of
this section. Any person refusing to permit the said officer or employees the
above described right of access to his/her/its premises or properties shall be
subject to cessation of water and sewer services until the required opportunity
to inspect and observe is accorded said officer or employees of the city.
   D.   Violation; Penalty:
      1.   Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this
section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be
fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each violation. Each day in which such violation
continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
      2.   With respect to any violation of this section, and in addition to
and not in lieu of the fine provisions hereinabove set forth, the city
corporate authorities may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction and
obtain injunctive relief, mandatory and/or restraining, to enforce and effect
compliance with the provisions of this section. In such event, such person
against which injunctive relief is obtained shall be responsible for and pay
for the reasonable attorney fees incurred by the city in obtaining such
injunctive relief. (Ord. 2538, 3-21-1994)
8-5-11: SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
   A.   No territory or premises located outside the city's corporate limits
which is contiguous to the city's corporate limits shall be connected with the
city's sanitary sewer and/or storm sewer and/or combined sewer distribution
system until and unless a valid petition for annexation of said territory or
premises is presented to the city clerk and such territory or premises is
actually annexed to the city, which annexation can be denied for any reason or
for no reason whatsoever in the sole discretion of the city council from time
to time.
Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, if the city council
elects not to annex contiguous territory or premises at the time city sanitary
sewer and/or storm sewer and/or combined sewer distribution system services are
requested by the record owner(s) of such contiguous territory or premises, then
the city council may, in its sole discretion, approve sanitary sewer and/or
storm sewer or combined sewer distribution system services for such contiguous
territory or premises provided each then owner of record of such contiguous
territory or premises signs an annexation petition and enters into and signs an
annexation agreement with the city in forms approved by the city council from
time to time, whereby each said owner and their respective heirs, devisees,
legal and personal representatives, successors and assigns, agree to and shall
immediately annex said contiguous territory or premises to the city when and if
at any time thereafter during the remaining term of said annexation agreement
or renewal thereof the city council determines in its sole discretion that such
contiguous territory or premises shall be annexed into the city.
   B.   No territory or premises located outside the city's corporate limits
which is not contiguous to the city's corporate limits shall be connected with
the city's sanitary sewer and/or storm sewer and/or combined sewer distribution
system until and unless each owner of record of such territory or premises
signs an annexation petition and enters into and signs an annexation agreement
with the city, whereby said owners agree to and shall immediately annex said
territory or premises to the city when and if said territory or premises has
become contiguous to the city's corporate limits and at any time thereafter
during the remaining term of said annexation agreement or renewal thereof the
city council determines in its sole discretion that such contiguous territory
or premises shall be annexed into the city.
   C.   At the time of annexation as set forth in subsections A and B of this
section, the annexing party or parties as the case may be shall pay any and all
expenses related to said annexation and all other fees as set forth in this
code including, but not limited to, the recording fee for said annexation,
which fee shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00) or the fee actually assessed
by the recorder's office for Christian County, Illinois, at the time or
recording, whichever amount shall be greater.
   D.   Unless said annexation petition and annexation agreement has been
signed and filed with the city clerk as provided in subsection A or B of this
section, then in the event a territory or premises located outside the city's
corporate limits is connected with the city's sanitary sewer and/or storm sewer
and/or combined sewer distribution system and is contiguous to the city's
corporate limits, the city clerk shall send notice to the owner of said
territory or premises that if a petition to annex the territory or premises
into the city's corporate limits is not properly signed by all record owners of
said territory or premises and filed with the city clerk within thirty (30)
days of the date of the notice, the territory or premises shall be disconnected
from the city's sanitary sewer and/or storm sewer and/or combined sewer
distribution system; and if a proper petition to annex is signed and filed, but
annexation of the territory or premises into the city's corporate limits is not
completed within sixty (60) days of the date of the notice by the city clerk as
set forth herein, said territory or premises shall be disconnected from the
city's sanitary sewer and/or storm sewer and/or combined sewer distribution
system; and the street and sewer superintendent, or his designee, shall make
such disconnection. (Ord. 3720, 7-20-2015)
8-5-12: POLICY FOR MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR OF CITY'S SEWER MAIN AND PROPERTY
OWNER'S SEWER:
   A.   The city council will refuse to pay any plumbing charges incurred prior
to contacting the city sewer department. Any time a plumber or sewer cleaning
entity is contacted, they should not proceed with any work until the city has
been contacted to determine if the problem is in the sewer main or the property
owner's sewer.
   B.   A five hundred dollar ($500.00) excavation fee must be paid to the City
of Taylorville before any tunneling under or excavation begins in any street,
alley, or public place. If the five hundred dollar ($500.00) fee is not paid to
the City of Taylorville before excavation begins as otherwise set forth herein,
an automatic seven hundred fifty dollar ($750.00) fine will be imposed on the
person failing to pay before proceeding to excavation.
   C.   Sewer taps must be inspected by authorized personnel of the street and
sewer department and tap card signed by a licensed plumber before being
covered. If covered before inspection, plumber will have to uncover for
inspection and pay a seven hundred fifty dollar ($750.00) fine.
   D.   Inspections by authorized personnel of the street and sewer department
not done during working hours (7:00 A.M. to 12:00 noon and 1:00 P.M. to 4:00
P.M.) will require an additional fee of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for
overtime.
   E.   The city sewer department may locate sewer taps by TV camera when given
forty eight (48) hours' notice (not including weekends or holidays), or may
give measurement from books or plans which may or may not be accurate.
   F.   The following are fill instructions when streets have been dug up:
Asphalt street:
Six inches (6") sand over pipe material
Followed by flowable fill
Followed with four inch (4") concrete leaving two inch (2") asphalt replacement
(edges must be square and straight)
Plumber will be billed by the city when asphalt has been replaced
Other streets: Oil/chip
Flowable fill leaving two inches (2") for chip mix replacement
Alley: Unpaved
Six inches (6") of sand
CA7 to within six inches (6") of top
CA6 to finish
   G.   All excavators and plumbers must have insurance on file in the city
clerk's office naming the city as additional insured before working on city
easements. (Ord. 3452, 12-21-2009; amd. Ord. 3541, 12-5-2011; Ord. 4087, 12-20-
2021)
