9-8-6: Obsolete Signs
9-8-7: Unsafe And Unlawful Signs
9-8-8: Ground Signs
9-8-9: Roof Signs
9-8-10: Wall Signs
9-8-11: Projecting Signs
9-8-12: Marquee Signs
9-8-13: Electric Signs
9-8-14: Inspections; Fee
9-8-15: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See also Section
  3-3-5-1 of this Code.
9-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
   ERECT: To build, construct, attach, hand place, suspend or affix and shall
also include the painting of wall signs.
   GROUND SIGN: An outdoor advertising sign when such sign is supported by
uprights or braces in or upon the ground.
   ILLUMINATED SIGN: Any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs
or outlines illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes as a part of the
sign proper.
   INCOMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL: Any material which will not ignite at or below a
temperature of one thousand two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (1,200°F) and will
not continue to turn or glow at that temperature.
   MARQUEE: A canopy or covered structure projecting from and supported by a
building, when such canopy or covered structure extends beyond the building,
building line or property line.
   MARQUEE SIGN: An outdoor advertising sign attached to or hung from a
marquee.
   OUTDOOR ADVERTISING SIGN: Any sign consisting of any letter, figure,
character, mark, point, place, marquee sign, design, poster, pictorial picture,
stroke, stripe, line, trademark, reading meter or illuminating device
constructed, attached, erected, fastened or manufactured in any manner
whatsoever so that the same shall be used for the attraction of the public to
any place, subject, person, public performance, article, machine or merchandise
whatsoever and displayed in any manner whatsoever out of doors for recognized
advertising purposes.
   PROJECTING SIGN: An outdoor advertising sign which is affixed to any
building, wall or structure and extends beyond the building wall, structure,
building line or property line more than fifteen inches (15").
   ROOF SIGN: An outdoor advertising sign erected, constructed and maintained
above the roof of any building.
   WALL SIGN: An outdoor advertising sign which is affixed to the front, side
or rear walls of any building, when such sign shall project not more than
fifteen inches (15") from the building wall. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-1984)
9-8-2: SIGN CONTRACTORS:
   A.   License Required: No person shall engage in the business of erecting,
constructing, altering, maintaining, servicing, painting or posting outdoor
advertising signs or structures without first having obtained a license from
the City Clerk to do so.
   B.   Application For License; Fee: Application for the license required by
this Section shall be upon forms provided by the City Clerk and shall be
accompanied by a license fee, payable to the City, in the amount of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) per year. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-1984)
   C.   Insurance: Each such contractor or installer shall maintain in full
force and effect at all times general liability insurance coverage in an amount
not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per person and two million
dollars ($2,000,000.00) per occurrence for personal injuries, including death,
and property damages, including, but not limited to, property damages to City
property or property of others that may result, in whole or in part, from the
erecting, constructing, altering, maintaining, servicing, painting, or posting
outdoor advertising signs or structures. Such general liability insurance
coverage shall be an "occurrence" type policy and not a "claims made" type
policy and shall name as additional named insureds the "City of Taylorville,
Illinois, a municipal corporation, and its elected and/or appointed Mayor, City
Council, officials, officers, employees, and agents". Such person(s) shall file
and refile, from time to time, with the City Clerk a certificate of insurance
evidencing the aforesaid insurance requirements at each time such insurance is
obtained or renewed or prior to the time any prior certificate of insurance on
file with the City Clerk will expire. (Ord. 3131, 7-21-2003)
9-8-3: SIGN PERMIT:
   A.   Permit And Compliance Required; Application And Fee: Except as
otherwise provided herein, no outdoor advertising sign or structure shall be
erected, constructed, altered, rebuilt or relocated except as provided in this
Chapter and until a permit for the same has been issued by the Health and
Building Officer upon application therefor submitted in such form as the Health
and Building Officer may prescribe so as to include such information as may be
required by him for a complete understanding of the proposed work. Such
application shall be accompanied by a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) to be paid
to the City. (Ord. 2228, 11-17-1986)
   B.   Insurance: Each person or entity maintaining a sign, marquee, rigid
canopy, or other tangible property of any kind, nature or extent whatsoever
which overhangs City property or City right-of- way or is in danger of falling
on City property or City right-of- way shall maintain in full force and effect
at all times general liability insurance coverage in an amount not less than
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per person and two million dollars
($2,000,000.00) per occurrence for personal injuries, including death, and
property damages, including, but not limited to, property damages to city
property or to property of others that may result, in whole or in part, from
the construction or maintenance of such sign, marquee, canopy, or tangible
property. Such general liability insurance coverage shall be an "occurrence"
type policy and not a "claims made" type policy and shall name as additional
named insureds the city of Taylorville, Illinois, a municipal corporation, and
its elected and/or appointed mayor, city council, officials, officers,
employees and agents. Such persons and entities shall file and refile, from
time to time, with the city clerk a certificate of insurance evidencing the
aforesaid insurance requirements at each time such insurance is obtained or
renewed or prior to the time any prior certificate of insurance on file with
the city clerk will expire. (Ord. 3625, 7-1-2013)
   C.   Examination Of Plans; Issuance Of Permit: It shall be the duty of the
health and building officer, upon the filing of an application for an erection
permit as required by subsection A of this section, to examine such plans and
specifications and other data and the premises upon which the proposed sign or
other advertising structure is to be erected. If it shall appear that the
proposed structure is in compliance with the requirements of this chapter and
all other laws and ordinances of the city, the health and building officer
shall then issue the erection permit.
   D.   Expiration Of Permit: If the work authorized under an erection permit
required by subsection A of this section has not been completed within six (6)
months after the date of issuance, the permit shall become null and void. (Ord.
2131, 2-20-1984)
   E.   Exemptions From Permit: No permit will be required under this chapter
for the following: (Ord. 3131, 7-21-2003)
      1.   Any temporary ground sign or for any ground sign less than five feet
(5') in height or less than nine (9) square feet or for a sign painted on the
premises or for plaques securely attached to the premises.
      2.   Projecting signs weighing less than six (6) pounds. (Ord. 2131, 2-
20-1984)
      3.   A window sign not exceeding ten (10) square feet of display surface.
(Ord. 2290, 5-16-1988)
      4.   A sign not exceeding three (3) square feet of display surface on a
residence building stating merely the name and profession of the occupant.
      5.   A ground sign advertising either the sale or rental of the premises
upon which it is maintained when such sign does not exceed twenty five (25)
square feet of display surface.
      6.   Political wall signs affixed to building or structure and projecting
not more than five inches (5").
      7.   Street, warning and other official or nonadvertising signs erected
by any government or by others where required by or pursuant to a legal
authority.
The exemptions permitted by this subsection shall apply only to the requirement
of a permit and shall not be construed as relieving the owner of the sign from
responsibility for its erection and maintenance in a good and safe condition.
(Ord. 2131, 2-20-1984)
9-8-4: COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Except as allowed under the provisions of this chapter relating to
projecting and marquee signs, every outdoor advertising sign for which a permit
is required shall rigidly conform to the requirements of front, rear and side
yards and setback restrictions of the zoning area district of the lot upon
which such sign is to be or is located and of any lot contiguous thereto as
fully as if such sign were a part of a building wall; except, that lighting
reflector may project beyond the face of such sign 1 .
   B.   Every outdoor advertising sign shall rigidly conform to the
requirements of the height restrictions 2  of the zoning height district of the
lot upon which such a sign is to be or is located and of any lot contiguous
thereto as fully as if such sign were a part of the building wall or roof;
except, that lighting reflectors may project beyond the top of such sign 1 .
(Ord. 2131, 2-20-1984)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
2 2. See subsection
  9-8-8A of this chapter.
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
9-8-5: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Wind Pressure: Ground signs shall be designed and constructed to
withstand wind pressure of not less than twenty five (25) pounds per square
foot of exposed area, but all other signs must be designed and constructed to
withstand wind pressure of not less than fifty (50) pounds per square foot of
exposed area.
   B.   Anchors And Supports: Allowable stresses and materials shall conform to
the latest approved specifications of the American standard building code
requirements for structural steel, approved by the American Standards
Association, and of the national design specifications for stress grade lumber
and its fastenings, recommended by the National Lumber Manufacturers
Association. The working stress of chains, wire ropes and steel guy rods and
their fastenings shall not exceed one-fourth (1/4) of their ultimate strength.
   C.   Maintenance: The owner of any sign, as defined and regulated by this
chapter shall be required to have such sign properly painted, including all
parts and supports of the sign, unless such parts and supports are galvanized
or otherwise treated to prevent rust.
   D.   Obstructing Fire Escapes, Doorways, Etc.: No outdoor advertising sign
shall be erected, constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape
or any window or door or opening used as a means of egress or for firefighting
purposes or so as to prevent free passage from one part of a roof to another
part thereof. No sign shall be attached in any form, shape or manner to a fire
escape nor be placed as to interfere with an opening required for legal
ventilation. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-1984)
9-8-6: OBSOLETE SIGNS:
Any sign which no longer advertises a bona fide business conducted or a product
sold shall be taken down and removed by the owner, agent or person having the
beneficial use of the building or structure upon which sign may be found within
ten (10) days after written notification from the health and building officer,
and upon failure to comply with such notice within the time specified in such
order, the health and building officer is hereby authorized to cause removal of
such sign, and any expense incident thereto shall be paid by the owner of the
building or structure to which such sign is attached. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-1984)
9-8-7: UNSAFE AND UNLAWFUL SIGNS:
If the health and building officer shall find that any sign or other
advertising structure is unsafe or insecure or is a menace to the public or has
been constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the
provisions of this chapter, he shall give written notice to the permittee
thereof. If the permittee fails to remove or alter the structure so as to
comply with the standards set forth in this Chapter within ten (10) days after
such notice, such signs or advertising structure may be removed or altered to
comply with this Chapter by the Health and Building Officer at the expense of
the permittee or owner of the property upon which it is located. The Health and
Building Officer may cause any sign or other advertising structure which is an
immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily and without
notice. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-84)
9-8-8: GROUND SIGNS:
   A.   Maximum Height:
      1.   No ground sign shall be erected, constructed, altered, rebuilt or
relocated to a height exceeding thirty feet (30') above the ground, but such
maximum height for any part of any ground sign shall be further restricted to
two feet (2') of height above the ground for each one foot (1') or portion
thereof that such part of such ground sign is to be located from the property
line of any lot in the residence districts relative to zoning. (Ord. 2131, 2-
20-84; 1993 Code)
      2.   No ground sign for which a permit is required shall be erected to a
height of more than twelve feet (12') above the ground unless the face is
constructed of sheet metal or other noncombustible facing materials.
   B.   Bottom of Sign Facing: The bottom of the facing of every ground sign
shall be at least thirty inches (30") above the ground, which space may be
filled with platform or decorative trim of light wood or metal construction.
   C.   Supports and Anchors:
      1.   Generally: Ground signs shall be adequately supported to resist dead
load and the wind load specified in subsection
9-8-5A of this Chapter acting in any direction on the sign.
      2.   Height Does Not Exceed Twenty Five Feet: Ground signs which do not
exceed twenty five feet (25') in height may have supports which consist only of
vertical posts driven into or set in the soil or which consist of vertical
posts rigidly attached to bases embedded in the soil. There shall be two (2) or
more vertical posts spaced not to exceed a distance equal to one-half (1/2) the
height of the sign above the ground; except, that a sign which does not exceed
fifty (50) square feet in area may be supported by a single post.
      3.   Height Exceeds Twenty Five Feet: All ground signs over twenty five
feet (25') in height shall be braced by frames or inclined braces placed in
vertical planes, preferably normal to the face of the sign, at intervals not
exceeding its height; except, that metal beams of at least six inches by
fourteen inches (6" x 14") or wooden poles of at least eight inches (8") in
diameter shall be used as braces and set in concrete at a minimum depth below
the ground level of five feet (5'). At least two (2) frames or braces shall be
provided.
      4.   Posts Supporting Unbraced Signs: The posts, or bases for rigidly
attached posts, supporting unbraced ground signs shall be so proportioned that
the bearing loads imposed upon the soil in either a horizontal or vertical
direction shall not exceed safe values. Braced ground signs shall be anchored
to resist the specified wind load acting in any direction. Anchors and supports
shall be designed for safe bearing loads on the soil and for an effective
resistance to pull out amounting to a force of twenty five percent (25%)
greater than the required resistance to overturning.
      5.   Wood Anchors or Supports: Whenever anchors or supports consist of
wood embedded in the soil, the wood shall be treated under pressure with
creosote or other approved preservative before erection. This requirement shall
not apply to temporary signs which will not remain in place for more than six
(6) months.
   D.   Soil Used For Backfill; Depth of Anchors and Supports: The soil used
for backfill for the dug-in type of anchor or post support shall be carefully
placed and thoroughly compacted. The anchors and supports shall penetrate to a
depth below ground greater than that of the frost line.
   E.   Portable Signs: Portable signs supported by frames or posts rigidly
attached to bases shall be so proportioned that the weight and size of the
bases are adequate to resist the wind pressure specified in subsection 9-8-5A
of this Chapter. Such signs shall not exceed six feet (6') in height.
   F.   Maintenance of Area Around Sign: The owner of a lot upon which there is
a ground sign or the person occupying such lot or both are hereby required to
keep such lot and such ground sign clean, sanitary, inoffensive and free and
clear of all obnoxious substances and unsightly conditions. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-
84)
9-8-9: ROOF SIGNS:
   A.   Construction Materials: Every roof sign shall be constructed entirely
of fire-resistive materials, including the uprights, supports and braces;
except, that the ornamental moldings, battend, cappings and nailing strips,
platforms and the decorative trimmings may be constructed of combustible
material.
   B.   Projections: No roof sign shall project beyond the exterior wall, but
if illuminated, lighting reflectors may project beyond the face of the wall.
   C.   Space Between Roof and Sign: Roof signs shall be so constructed as to
leave a clear space, except for the structure supporting such sign, of not less
than four feet (4') between the roof and the lowest part of such sign.
   D.   Anchors:
      1.   Roof signs shall be thoroughly secured and anchored to the building
over which they are constructed and erected. The dead and wind loads from the
signs shall be distributed to the structural elements of the building in such
manner that no element shall be overstressed.
      2.   Uplift due to overturning of roof signs shall be adequately resisted
by proper anchorage to the building walls or structure or by sufficient
concrete counterweights to resist uplift. Proper anchorage to the building
walls or structure shall include such alterations to the building as may be
needed to integrate and adequately interconnect sufficient dead load to equal
not less than ten percent (10%) in excess of the computed uplift applied to the
building by the sign. Where uplift is resisted by counterweights, their weight
shall exceed the amount of the uplift by ten percent (10%). (Ord. 2131, 2-20-
84)
9-8-10: WALL SIGNS:
Wall signs attached to exterior walls of solid masonry or concrete shall be
safely and securely attached to the same by means of metal anchors, bolts or
expansion screws of not less than three-eighths inch (3/8") in diameter which
shall be embedded at least five inches (5"). No wooden blocks or anchorage with
wood used in connection with screws or nails shall be considered proper
anchorage, except in the case of wall signs attached to buildings with walls of
wood. No wall sign shall be entirely supported by an unbraced parapet wall.
(Ord. 2131, 2-20-84)
9-8-11: PROJECTING SIGNS:
   A.   Maximum Projection; Height Above Sidewalk: Signs shall in no case
project from a building or structure to any point within two feet (2') of a
line drawn perpendicularly upward from the curb line, except signs, the lowest
point of which is a minimum of seventeen feet (17') above the pavement, in
which case, said signs may project out from the curb line not to exceed two
feet (2'). No projecting sign shall in any case project over a sidewalk so as
to endanger persons using the sidewalk.
   B.   Attachment to Building: Projecting signs shall be securely attached to
a building or structure by metal bolts, anchors, supports, chains, wire ropes
or steel rods. No staples or nails shall be used to secure any projecting sign
to any building or structure.
   C.   Supports:
      1.   The dead load of projecting signs, not parallel to the building or
the structure, and the load due to wind pressure shall be supported by
structural shapes, chains, wire ropes or steel guy rods. Such supports shall be
erected and maintained preferably at an angle of forty five degrees (45°) or
more with the face of the sign in an approximately horizontal place to resist
wind pressure. The lateral supports shall be placed not more than eight feet
(8') apart and shall be secured to a bolt or expansion screw capable of
developing the strength of the supporting chain, wire rope or steel guy rod.
The expansive device and details of the anchorage shall be subject to the
approval of the Health and Building Officer. Turn buckles or other approved
means of adjustment shall be placed in all chains, wire ropes or steel guy rods
supporting or bracing projecting signs.
      2.   Chains, wire ropes or steel guy rods used to support the dead or
wind loads of projecting signs may be fastened to solid masonry walls with
expansion bolts or other devices approved by the Health and Building Officer,
but no such support shall be attached to an unbraced parapet wall. Where the
supports must be fastened to walls made of wood, the supporting device must be
fastened securely in a manner approved by the Health and Building Officer.
      3.   All metal supports and braces for projecting signs shall be
galvanized or of corrosive-resistant material or painted at least once
annually. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-84)
9-8-12: MARQUEE SIGNS:
Fire-resistant marquee signs may be attached to or hung from a marquee. When
attached to or hung from a marquee, such signs shall be at least eight feet
(8') at its lowest level above the sidewalk or ground level. 1  No such sign
shall extend outside the vertical lines of such marquee. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-84)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  10-7-2B of this Code.
9-8-13: ELECTRIC SIGNS:
All signs and displays using electrical power shall have a cut-off switch on
the outside of the premises and on the outside of the sign. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-
84)
9-8-14: INSPECTIONS; FEE:
The Health and Building Officer shall inspect signs at such times as he deems
necessary and each electrical sign, projecting sign or marquee sign regulated
by this Chapter for the purpose of ascertaining whether the same is secure or
insecure and whether it is in need of removal or repair. The Health and
Building Officer shall have the right and option, when he deems necessary, to
employ the services of a qualified electrician for the purpose of inspecting
said electrical sign, projecting sign or marquee sign. To meet the expense of
such inspection, the permittee thereof shall pay to the City the sum of ten
dollars ($10.00) plus any additional cost incurred through the employment of a
qualified electrician in said inspection. (Ord. 2131, 2-20-84)
9-8-15: PENALTY:
Any person violating or failing to comply with any provision of this Chapter
shall, for each offense, be punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 9
MOBILE HOMES AND TRAILER COACH PARKS 1
SECTION:
9-9-1: Definitions
9-9-2: Use Of Mobile Homes And Trailers
9-9-3: Removal Of Wheels
9-9-4: Trailer Coach Park License
9-9-5: Mobile Home Sites
9-9-6: Park Sanitation And Safety
9-9-7: Park Supervision
9-9-8: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  10-4-3A2 and A3 of this Code.
9-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
   TRAILER COACH OR MOBILE HOME OR HOUSE TRAILER: Any structure so constructed
so as it may be moved from place to place as a dwelling for one or more
persons; and there is or was affixed on the rear of such structure a red metal
label identifying such structure as a mobile home.
   TRAILER COACH PARK: Means and includes an area of land on which two (2) or
more occupied trailer coaches and/or mobile homes and/or house trailers are
harbored, either free of charge or for revenue, together with any building,
structure or enclosure used as part of the equipment of any such park. (Ord.
2762, 9-3-1996)
9-9-2: USE OF MOBILE HOMES AND TRAILERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any trailer coach, mobile home,
house trailer, double wide trailer coach, double wide mobile home, double wide
house trailer, or similar housing as a dwelling unit upon any plot of ground in
the City or, after September 16, 1996, in the recreational areas, campground
sites or lake lots at Lake Taylorville, except as follows:
   A.   In a licensed trailer coach park.
   B.   For temporary construction purposes.
   C.   For emergency use following fire, tornado or other disaster. (Ord.
2762, 9-3-1996)
9-9-3: REMOVAL OF WHEELS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove the wheels or other transporting
device from any trailer coach, mobile home, double wide mobile home or similar
housing or otherwise to affix said trailer coach, mobile home or double wide
mobile home or similar housing permanently to the ground. (1979 Code Ch. 18,
Art. VII, § 10)
9-9-4: TRAILER COACH PARK LICENSE:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to establish, maintain or
operate any trailer coach park in the City without first having obtained a
license therefor.
   B.   Application For License: Application for such licenses shall be made,
in writing, to the City Clerk in compliance with the ordinances relating to
license application 1  and shall contain the name of the applicant, the
location for the proposed park and the number of trailers to be accommodated.
(1979 Code Ch. 18, Art. VII, § 2)
   C.   Plan: Each such application shall be accompanied by a plat or sketch
showing the size and location of all buildings and structures. (1979 Code Ch.
18, Art. VII, § 3)
   D.   License Fee: The annual fee for such licenses shall be fifty dollars
($50.00). (1979 Code Ch. 18, Art. VII, § 4)
   E.   Character Of Applicant: No such license shall be issued to any but a
person of good character nor to any corporation if any officer thereof is not a
person of good character. (1979 Code Ch. 18, Art. VII, § 5)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code.
9-9-5: MOBILE HOME SITES:
Each trailer coach shall be allotted a site of not less than one thousand two
hundred fifty (1,250) square feet. The trailer spaces will not be located any
closer to the bounding property lines of the park than the appropriate yard
requirements for the district would allow or closer than ten feet (10') to a
public street, alley or building. Each individual trailer site shall abut or
face on a driveway or clear unoccupied space which shall have unobstructed
access to a public highway or alley. There shall be an open space of at least
ten feet (10') between the ends of every trailer coach. (1979 Code Ch. 18, Art.
VII, § 7)
9-9-6: PARK SANITATION AND SAFETY:
   A.   Garbage Disposal: It shall be the duty of the owner, his agent or
caretaker to provide for the collection and removal of garbage or other waste
material and to otherwise maintain the park in a clean and sanitary condition.
(1979 Code Ch. 18, Art. VII, § 8)
   B.   Lights: The parks shall be kept properly and adequately lighted at all
times so that the grounds shall be safe for occupants and visitors. (1979 Code
Ch. 18, Art. VII, § 9)
9-9-7: PARK SUPERVISION:
Each trailer coach park, while operated, shall be in the charge of a
responsible attendant or caretaker at all times who shall be responsible, with
the licensee, for compliance with the provisions of this Chapter relating to
the conduct of such parks. (1979 Code Ch. 18, Art. VII, § 7)
It shall be unlawful to hire or keep as manager, superintendent or person in
charge of a trailer coach park any person who is not a person of good character
or any person who has been convicted of a felony. (1979 Code Ch. 18, Art. VII,
§ 11)
9-9-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this Chapter shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1993 Code)
CHAPTER 10
HOUSE NUMBERS
SECTION:
9-10-1: Numbering Plan
9-10-2: Chart Of House Numbers
9-10-3: House Numbers Required; Size
9-10-1: NUMBERING PLAN:
All lots, buildings and structures in the city shall be numbered in accordance
with the following plan:
   A.   Main Cross Street shall be the base line for north and south numbers
and Main Street shall be the base line for east and west numbers.
   B.   Odd numbers shall be on the north and west sides of the streets; even
numbers shall be on the south and east sides of the streets.
   C.   There shall be one hundred (100) numbers to each block, one number to
every twenty five feet (25') of frontage. (1979 Code Ch. 9, Art. III, § 1)
   D.   The developer of a subdivision shall be responsible for securing house
numbers from the Christian County 911 office for the subdivision. The
subdivision developer shall also be responsible for placing on the final
subdivision plat the house numbers obtained from the Christian County 911
office. The subdivision developer shall also submit with the final subdivision
plat a letter from the Christian County 911 coordinator indicating approval of
the house numbers listed in the final subdivision plat presented to the
planning and zoning commission and Taylorville city council. The planning and
zoning commission, in conjunction with the city engineer, shall approve final
plats of a subdivision only after lot numbers are assigned on the final plat by
the subdivision developer and approved by the Christian County 911 office/
coordinator. (Ord. 3253, 10-17-2005)
9-10-2: CHART OF HOUSE NUMBERS:
The city clerk shall keep a chart showing the proper street number of every lot
in the city which shall be open to inspection by anyone interested. (1979 Code
Ch. 9, Art. III, § 2)
9-10-3: HOUSE NUMBERS REQUIRED; SIZE:
It shall be the duty of the owners and occupants of every house in the city to
have placed thereon, in a place visible from the street, figures at least two
and one-half inches (21/2") high showing the number of the house. Any person
failing to so number any house, building or other structure occupied by him or
if, after receiving notice to do so from the clerk, shall continue in his
failure to so number such house, building or structure shall be fined twenty
five dollars ($25.00) for each day during or on which a failure to so number
continues. (1979 Code Ch. 9, Art. III, § 3)
CHAPTER 11
RESIDENTIAL OCCUPANCY LIMITATIONS
SECTION:
9-11-1: Definitions
9-11-2: Restrictions On Number Of Residents In A Dwelling Unit
9-11-3: Penalty
9-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall be construed as set
forth below:
   DWELLING: Any building which contains one or more "Dwelling Units" used,
intended, or designed to be built, used, rented, leased, let or hired out to be
occupied, or which are occupied for residential living purposes.
   DWELLING UNIT: A single unit providing complete, independent living
facilities for one or more persons for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and
sanitation.
   SAME FAMILY: The same family shall consist of an individual person, or two
(2) persons living together on a resident conjugal basis, or one married
couple, and the minor children of such individual person or such two (2)
persons or such married couple living together in a dwelling unit with not more
than a total of two (2) other persons, either acting as servants or who are
related directly to such individual person or two (2) persons or such married
couple by blood, marriage, or law; or the same family shall consist of a group
of not more than five (5) unrelated persons, living together in a dwelling
unit. (Ord. 2966, 6-5-2000)
9-11-2: RESTRICTIONS ON NUMBER OF RESIDENTS IN A DWELLING UNIT:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or tenant of any dwelling unit to permit or
allow such dwelling unit to be occupied or used, at any time, for residential
living purposes by any person who is not of the "same family" (as defined
above). (Ord. 2966, 6-5-2000)
9-11-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall, for each offense, be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2966, 6-5-2000)
CHAPTER 12
RESIDENTIAL CAMPER REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-12-1: Definitions
9-12-2: Restrictions
9-12-3: Penalty
9-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
   CAMPER: Any tent, or shelter, or self-contained traveling home, or trailer
capable of being hauled by a motor vehicle, or any recreational vehicle, or any
vehicle, or any structure or unit or vehicle or thing so constructed such that
it may be moved from place to place, any of which that is capable of being used
as a permanent or temporary living accommodation, sleeping quarters, or
dwelling for one or more persons.
   RESIDENTIAL: The use of a camper by any person for a living accommodation,
or as sleeping quarters, or as a dwelling for a period of more than ten (10)
days within any consecutive thirty (30) day period on any lot or parcel of
public or private land within the city of Taylorville, Illinois. (Ord. 3214,
12-20-2004)
9-12-2: RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or maintain or use or occupy any
residential camper upon any land within the city of Taylorville, Illinois,
except as follows:
   A.   For emergency residential use following fire, tornado, or any other act
of God disaster for a period of time as may be approved by the city council
from time to time; or
   B.   On any campsite or lake lot that such person or persons are leasing
from the city at Lake Taylorville provided such use of a residential camper
thereon is being used in accordance with any such lease. (Ord. 3214, 12-20-
2004)
9-12-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating or failing to comply with any provision of this chapter
shall, for each offense, be fined the sum of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00). Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed
a separate offense. (Ord. 3214, 12-20-2004)
TITLE 10
ZONING
CHAPTER 1
ZONING TITLE, PURPOSE AND DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
10-1-1: Short Title; Contents
10-1-2: Purpose
10-1-3: Interpretation
10-1-4: Rules And Definitions
10-1-1: SHORT TITLE; CONTENTS:
This comprehensive zoning title shall be known as the ZONING ORDINANCE OF THE
CITY OF TAYLORVILLE, ILLINOIS. The zoning maps herein referred to are
identified by the titles "Taylorville, Illinois zoning districts, map A, A-
1 and A-2; and Lake Taylorville zoning districts, map C" and dated January
1977. All explanatory matter thereon is hereby adopted and made a part of this
title 1 . (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-2-2 of this title.
10-1-2: PURPOSE:
These zoning regulations and districts have been made with these objectives:
   A.   The assuring that adequate light, air and safety from fire and other
dangers may be secured;
   B.   That property values be conserved;
   C.   That traffic congestion be lessened or avoided; and
   D.   That public health, safety, comfort, morals and welfare might otherwise
be promoted. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
10-1-3: INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of this
title, the provisions contained herein shall be held to be minimum requirements
adopted for the promotion of public health, morals, safety and general welfare.
(Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
   B.   Covenants And Deeds: In the case of any conflict between this title, or
part thereof, and the whole or part of any existing or future private
restrictive covenants or deeds, the provisions of this title, and not the
provisions of such private restrictive covenants or deeds, shall apply for
purposes of enforcement of this title by the city. (Ord. 3024, 6-18-2001)
10-1-4: RULES AND DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this title, certain terms or words used herein shall be
interpreted as follows:
All words used in the present tense include the future tense; all words in the
singular include the plural, and all words in the plural include the singular;
the word "shall" is mandatory and not directory; the word "used" shall be
deemed to include "designed, intended, or arranged to be used".
   ACCESSORY USE OR BUILDING: A use customarily incidental and subordinate to
the principal use or building and located on the same lot with such principal
use or building.
   AGRICULTURAL USES, BONA FIDE: The growing of crops in the open, raising of
stock and poultry, forestry, mushroom growing, flower gardening, operation of
apiaries and aviaries, nurseries, orchards, fur farms, roadside stands, signs
and billboards relating to the sale or use of products produced thereon and
necessary structures and farm dwellings for such uses.
   ALLEY: Any public or private way dedicated to public travel and less than
twenty feet (20') in width.
   AUTO WRECKING YARD: Any place where three (3) or more motor vehicles not in
running condition, or the parts thereof, are stored in the open and are not
being restored to operation or any land, building or structure used for the
wrecking or storing of such automobiles or the parts thereof.
   BUILDING: Any structure constructed or placed or used for residence,
business, commercial, or industrial use or for other public or private purposes
or accessory uses thereto and including, but not limited to, portable storage
containers, portable awnings, accessory buildings, canopies, coverings, or
roofs of any kind, nature or extent whatsoever, tents, lunch wagons, dining
cars, trailers, billboards, signs and similar structures whether stationary or
movable or portable or affixed to real estate.
   DWELLING: A permanent building used primarily for human habitation, but not
including facilities for the housing of transient residents, nor to include
mobile homes.
Dwelling, Multiple-Family: A permanent building or portion thereof providing
separate living accommodations for three (3) or more families.
Dwelling, Single-Family: A permanent building, separate and freestanding, in
itself providing living accommodations for one family.
Dwelling, Two-Family: A permanent building designed exclusively for occupancy
by two (2) families.
   HEIGHT OF BUILDING: The vertical distance from the established average
sidewalk grade, street grade or finished grade at the building line, whichever
is the highest, to the highest point of the building.
   HOME OCCUPATION: The conduct of an art or profession, the offering of a
service or the conduct of a business, or the handcrafted manufacture of
products within a dwelling in a residential district, which is incidental and
secondary to the use of the structure for dwelling purposes.
   LOT: A piece, parcel or plot of land occupied or to be occupied by one
principal building and its accessory buildings and including the open spaces
required under this title.
   NONCONFORMING USE: A use of building or land lawful at the effective date
hereof that does not conform with the "permitted use" provisions of this title.
   SCHOOLS: Accredited elementary schools, junior high and high schools
(nonboarding).
   STREET: Any public or private way dedicated to public travel twenty feet
(20') or more in width. The word "street" shall include the words "road",
"highway" and "thoroughfare".
   TRAILER OR MOBILE HOME: Any vehicle or similar portable structure originally
constructed with wheels, whether or not the wheels are still contained thereon,
and designed and constructed to permit occupancy for dwelling or sleeping
purposes but does not include camping vehicles used for recreational purposes.
   USE: The purpose or activity for which a building or structure is occupied
or maintained.
   YARD: An open space on the same lot with a principal building, open,
unoccupied and unobstructed by buildings, except as otherwise provided in this
title.
Front Yard: The yard extending across the entire width of the lot between the
principal building and the right of way line or street line which the building
faces.
Rear Yard: The yard extending across the entire width of the lot between the
rear lot line and the nearest part of the principal building.
Side Yard: The yard extending along the side lot line from the front yard to
the rear yard and lying between the side lot line and the nearest part of the
principal building. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977; amd. Ord. 2079, 11-7-1982; Ord. 3081,
7-15-2002; Ord. 3734, 11-2-2015)
CHAPTER 2
ZONING DISTRICTS; GENERAL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
10-2-1: Districts Established
10-2-2: Zoning Map
10-2-3: Boundaries Of Districts
10-2-4: Application Of Regulations
10-2-5: Restrictions On Continuance Of Nonconforming Use
10-2-6: Clear View At Intersections
10-2-1: DISTRICTS ESTABLISHED:
For the purpose of this Title, all land within the City is hereby designated on
the zoning maps as being in one of the following districts:
Agricultural Districts
   AG-1 district - agricultural
   AG-2 district - agricultural
Residence Districts
   R-1 district - one- and two-family residential
   R-2 district - multiple-family residential
Commercial Districts
   C-1 district - general retail
   C-2 district - service retail
Industrial Districts
   I-1 district - light industrial
   I-2 district - heavy industrial
   I-3 district - energy
(Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977; amd. Ord. 3177, 6-7-2004)
10-2-2: ZONING MAP 1 :
The City Council shall cause to be published, as needed, a map clearly showing
the existing zoning divisions and classifications. The City Engineer shall
maintain a current zoning map, with amendments, for the City Council and the
Plan Commission's use. The Plan Commission shall review the zoning map,
annually, during the month of March to determine whether or not a new
publication shall be required. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
 
Notes
1 1. See also Section
  10-1-1 of this Title.
10-2-3: BOUNDARIES OF DISTRICTS:
Unless otherwise indicated on the Zoning District maps, the boundary lines of
the districts follow lot lines, centerlines of streets, alleys or railroad
rights of way or such centerlines extended, centerlines of creeks or the
corporate limit line as existing at the effective date hereof. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-
1977)
10-2-4: APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS:
   A.   Generally: No building or land shall hereafter be used and no building
or part thereof shall be erected, moved, altered or remodeled unless for a use
expressly permitted by and in conformity with the regulations for the Zoning
District in which it is located. (Ord. 3797, 3-6-2017)
   B.   Zoning Of Agricultural Uses: Notwithstanding subsection A of this
Section none of the following regulations in this Title, with the exception of
front yard requirements, shall be applicable to bona fide agricultural uses as
defined in Chapter 3 of this Title. This shall not be construed, however, as to
eliminate the necessity of bona fide agricultural uses from applying for and
obtaining the necessary building permit prior to construction, alteration or
moving of buildings. No fee, however, shall be required for a building permit
for such agricultural uses.
   C.   Zoning Of Annexed Areas: All territory which may hereafter be annexed
to the City shall, from time of annexation, be considered as being the same
Zoning District designated to said territory under the zoning provisions
established by the Christian County, Illinois Zoning Board until and unless
otherwise designated by zoning ordinance amendment as specified in the
procedure in Section
10-9-6 of this Title. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
10-2-5: RESTRICTIONS ON CONTINUANCE OF NONCONFORMING USE:
Any lawful use of land or structure existing at the effective date hereof or
subsequent amendments hereto may be continued with the following limitations:
   A.   Expansion Or Alteration Of Nonconforming Use: Any structure containing
a nonconforming use may not be expanded nor substantially remodeled. The Board
of Appeals 1  may approve any remodeling and incidental repairs which do not
tend to prolong the life of the nonconforming use.
   B.   Damaged Buildings: Any structure containing a nonconforming use which
has been damaged to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its current fair
value, as estimated immediately prior to damage, shall not be repaired or
reconstructed except in conformity with this Title.
   C.   Discontinuance Of Nonconforming Use: No nonconforming use shall be
reestablished after having been discontinued for twelve (12) months. Vacating
of premises or building or nonoperative status shall be evidence of a
discontinued use.
   D.   Change Of Use: No nonconforming use may be substituted for any other
nonconforming use or any conforming use. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 2, Chapter 2 of this Code.
10-2-6: CLEAR VIEW AT INTERSECTIONS:
On any corner lot in all districts except the C-1 fire limits area, as
described in this Code 1 , there shall be no obstructions to traffic visibility
within thirty five feet (35') of the intersection of the two (2) street
property lines of the corner lots. (Ord. 1836, 1-16-1978)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  9-1-3A of this Code.
CHAPTER 3
AGRICULTURAL DISTRICTS
SECTION:
10-3-1: Purposes
10-3-2: Uses Permitted
10-3-3: Special Uses
10-3-4: Site and Structure Requirements
10-3-5: Off-Street Parking
10-3-1: PURPOSES:
   A.   AG-1 Districts: The purpose of the AG-1 District is:
      1.   To encourage the preservation of a proper setting for and pleasant
approaches to the City;
      2.   To provide an area for agricultural pursuits protected from
infringement of unguided urban development;
      3.   To create and preserve a setting for rural small estate residential
development;
      4.   To conserve areas physically unsuitable for intensive development;
and
      5.   To provide in the area immediately surrounding the City an
environment capable of accommodating future expansion of the City in an orderly
and efficient manner.
   B.   AG-2 District: The purpose of the AG-2 District is to protect the area
around the proposed Lake Taylorville 1  from encroachment and intermixing of
land uses which can be detrimental to the public health, welfare and
conservation of property values. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-77)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 7 of this Code.
10-3-2: USES PERMITTED:
   A.   AG-1 District: The following uses are permitted in the AG-1 District:
Agricultural uses, commercial grain storage.
Community buildings, utility and service system buildings and lands, libraries
and museums, picnic grounds, religious, educational or charitable institutions.
One- and two-family residential dwellings, home occupations.
Unlighted signs notifying of sale, rental or lease of land or sale of farm
goods on the premises on which the sign is maintained having not over fifty
(50) square feet of sign area; signs announcing meeting time and place of civic
organizations.
   B.   AG-2 District: Within any AG-2 Agricultural District, except for bona
fide agricultural uses as defined in Section
10-1-4 of this title, no building or premises shall be used or arranged or
designed to be used except for one or more of the following uses which shall be
subject to all regulations and requirements for permit of this Title:
Lakes (artificial).
Public parks and forest preserves.
Public picnic grounds, marinas and beaches.
Public utility substations, booster stations, radio and television relay
towers, repeater stations, etc., but not including power generation or gas
manufacturing plants. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-77)
10-3-3: SPECIAL USES:
The following uses are permitted as special uses when authorized by the Mayor
and City Council after a public hearing and recommendation by the Plan
Commission. Such special use shall be subject to the following requirements and
any other requirements the Plan Commission feels necessary to further the
purpose of the Agricultural Districts as stated in Section
10-3-1 of this Chapter:
   A.   AG-1 District:
Cemeteries.
Commercial resort uses such as lodges, restaurants, rental cottages, riding
stables, golf courses, swimming pools, tennis courts and other such
recreational facilities.
Outdoor advertising structures, providing not closer than three hundred feet
(300') to the nearest highway right of way or five hundred feet (500') to the
nearest residential or public or semi-public property, and that permits are
issued for not longer than five (5) years.
Uses of land including quarrying and mining of natural resources, sanitary
landfill and other types of landfill, refuse disposal and dumps.
   B.   AG-2 District: No special uses provided. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-77)
10-3-4: SITE AND STRUCTURE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Lot Area and Lot Width:
      1.   AG-1 District: No dwelling shall be located on a lot less than one
acre in area nor one hundred fifty feet (150') in width.
      2.   AG-2 District: Lot area and lot width not specified.
   B.   Yards: All structures shall have the following minimum yard spaces:
      1.   Front Yard: Fifty feet (50').
      2.   Side Yards: Each not less than fifteen feet (15').
      3.   Rear Yard: Each not less than thirty feet (30').
Corner lots shall provide the minimum front yard requirements on each street
side of the lot.
   C.   Building Height:
      1.   AG-1 District: No residential dwelling shall exceed two (2) stories
or thirty feet (30') in height.
      2.   AG-2 district: No height limitation is specified.
10-3-5: OFF-STREET PARKING:
There shall be provided in the AG Districts off-street parking in accordance
with Chapter 8 of this Title. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-77)
CHAPTER 4
RESIDENCE DISTRICTS
SECTION:
10-4-1: Purpose
10-4-1-1: Definition Of Lot For Single-Family Or Two-Family Residential
Dwellings
10-4-2: Uses Permitted
10-4-3: Special Uses
10-4-4: Site And Structure Requirements
10-4-5: Off-Street Parking
10-4-6: Mobile Homes
10-4-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the residence districts is to provide an area for residential
uses and those public and semipublic uses or businesses normally considered an
integral part of and is reasonably compatible with the residential neighborhood
they serve or business uses which may have a unique, special or unusual impact
upon the use or enjoyment of neighboring property, and planned developments.
(Ord. 3716, 7-20-2015)
10-4-1-1: DEFINITION OF LOT FOR SINGLE-FAMILY OR TWO-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL
DWELLINGS:
Notwithstanding anything in this Title to the contrary, one single-family
residence dwelling or one two-family residence dwelling may be constructed,
located, and occupied in an R-1 District or in an R-2 District on any two (2)
or more lots if such lots are adjoining and contiguous with one another and all
such lots have a common owner or owners. In such event, the total dimensions of
all such adjoining and contiguous lots used for such residential construction,
location, and occupancy shall be construed as comprising only one "lot" for the
purpose of determining compliance with any requirement(s), restriction(s), or
provision(s) as set forth in this Title when such requirement(s), restriction
(s), or provision(s) references the term "lot" in said Title. (Ord. 3014, 4-2-
2001)
10-4-2: USES PERMITTED:
   A.   R-1 District: The following uses are permitted in the R-1 District:
Accessory buildings and uses.
Light agricultural uses including nurseries and raising of farm products (not
to include livestock or sale of products on premises).
Municipal public water treatment plants and related facilities, buildings and
lands uses. No special use is required.
Single-family and two-family residence dwellings, leasing of rooms to not more
than two (2) families and home occupations as defined in Section
10-1-4 of this Title.
Unlighted real estate, nonconforming business use signs and public building or
church signs or bulletin boards pertaining to the property on which they are
placed and not having over twelve (12) square feet of sign area; provided
however, a twelve foot (12') wide by six foot (6') high sign with one light
thereon may be located and maintained on the sites of Municipal public water
treatment plants and related facilities, buildings and land uses. (Ord. 3817,
9-5-2017; amd. Ord. 3874, 11-5-2018)
   B.   R-2 District:
Any use permitted in the R-1 District.
Clubs, lodges, hospitals, sanatoriums and rest homes.
Multiple-family dwelling of not more than four (4) units, tourist homes and
lodging uses with accommodations for not more than fifteen (15) persons or for
over four (4) units or more than one multiple-family dwelling on a single
tract. (See subsection
10-4-3A6 of this Chapter.)
Unlighted signs as described in the R-1 District. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977; amd.
Ord. 1923, 8-6-1979; Ord. 2150, 10-8-1984)
10-4-3: SPECIAL USES:
One or more of the following uses may be permitted as one or multiple special
uses in the R-1 and R-2 Districts only when authorized and approved by the City
Council after a public hearing and recommendation by the Plan Commission. Such
special use or special uses shall be subject to the following requirements and
to any and all other requirements or conditions the Plan Commission or City
Council believes necessary and directs to further the purpose of the residence
districts as stated in Section
10-4-1 of this Chapter: (Ord. 3716, 7-20-2015)
   A.   Special Uses Enumerated:
      1.   Planned residential development under single ownership in which
incidental business and recreational facilities for the convenience of the
occupants may be furnished; provided, however, that the property shall have a
gross area of thirty (30) acres and that permitted business uses shall be
limited to those uses allowed in C-1 District, and they shall occupy not more
than ten percent (10%) of the gross land area of the development. Such planned
developments may vary the dwelling type requirements, yard, height or area per
dwelling requirements; providing, however, that the total number of dwelling
units to be accommodated is not greater than would otherwise be allowed under
normal development.
      2.   Individual mobile homes 1  for emergency use only following a fire,
tornado or other disaster; providing that:
         a.   Such mobile home shall be connected to sanitary sewer and public
water;
         b.   Such mobile home shall be for temporary use only lasting no
longer than two (2) years;
         c.   Such mobile home shall meet the single-family dwelling
requirements for lot area and yards for the particular residence district in
which it is located; and
         d.   That such mobile home will not in its proposed location impair
public health, safety, comfort, morals or welfare of the community.
      3.   Trailer parks 2  with permanent accommodations for mobile homes;
providing that:
         a.   Such trailer park will have permanent accommodations for a
minimum of five (5) trailers;
         b.   Trailer accommodations will include, for each trailer, individual
underground sewer and water connections, concrete trailer platform, forty foot
(40') wide pavement with vehicle access to all trailers;
      3A.   The retail sales of mobile homes on site in a trailer park by the
owner of a trailer park that has been granted a special use for a trailer park
under subparagraph A.3 of Section
10-4-3 of this Chapter.
         c.   The plan of development will provide a minimum of one thousand
two hundred fifty (1,250) square feet per trailer space; and
         d.   The trailer spaces will not be located any closer to the bounding
property lines of the park than the appropriate yard requirements for the
district would allow. A certificate of occupancy shall be required for each
individual trailer to be located in the park prior to occupancy as provided in
section
10-9-3 of this title. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
      4.   Professional business offices, medical or dental offices or clinics,
law, insurance, or real estate offices, financial institutions, finance or
utility companies. (Ord. 2888, 12-21-1998)
      5.   Daycare center, nursery school or preschool centers which are
licensed by the state of Illinois, department of children and family services.
(Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977)
      6.   Apartments, condominiums, residential conversion condominiums,
residential add-on condominiums (all in R-2 zoned areas only).
         a.   Requirements: All condominiums, including those listed above,
shall be governed by the condominium property act 3 , including the definitions
therein as found in 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes 605/1. If multiple
condominium buildings are to be presented, then this project will first fall
under the subdivision ordinance 4 .
         b.   Plat Review: To provide for a successful review of a condominium
or an apartment complex, the petitioner should submit a plat, and approval will
constitute a successful review of the plat by the plan commission and approval
then by the governing body, the city council. Such plat should contain:
            (1)   A location map. The location map should outline the area to
be subdivided.
            (2)   Existing streets and city utilities on the joining property.
            (3)   The north point on the map.
            (4)   Name and address of the owner, name of the proposed complex
(apartment or condominium), boundary line bearings and distances and acreages,
names of persons who prepared the plat, the owner's attorney, representative
agent, graphic scale and date, contours at two foot (2') intervals.
            (5)   Location of existing lot lines, public streets, public
utilities, water mains, sewers, drainpipes, culverts, watercourses, bridges,
railroads, buildings within the boundaries of the proposed complex.
            (6)   Locations and widths, other dimensions and names of proposed
means of ingress and egress, alleys, utilities and other easements, common
places and other open spaces or reserved areas.
            (7)   Grades of proposed streets and alleys.
            (8)   Cross sections of proposed streets extending from the street
line to street line or right of way line to right of way line showing the
roadway locations, type of curb and gutter, paving and sidewalks to be
installed.
            (9)   The layout of proposed water mains, sanitary sewers, storm
sewers.
            (10)   Drainage of the land including proposed storm sewers,
ditches, culverts, bridges.
         c.   Conversion Condominium Plat: A successful condominium will
contain a comprehensive building report which includes age, material and
condition, where applicable, of the following:
            (1)   Type and age of construction.
            (2)   Walls (interior and exterior).
            (3)   Plumbing.
            (4)   Electrical.
            (5)   Roof.
            (6)   Walks.
            (7)   Garaging.
            (8)   Insulation.
            (9)   Life safety systems.
            (10)   Trash disposal.
            (11)   Tiling.
            (12)   Fixtures and appliances.
            (13)   Drainage.
            (14)   Landscaping.
            (15)   Swimming pools, saunas, fountains, recreational facilities.
            (16)   Driveways.
            (17)   Wall and fences.
            (18)   Stone or brick work.
            (19)   Heating.
            (20)   Air conditioning.
            (21)   Fireplaces.
            (22)   Floors.
            (23)   Laundry facilities.
            (24)   Exterior lighting.
            (25)   Deferred maintenance.
            (26)   Number and composition of existing tenants.
            (27)   Length of existing leases and average rents.
            (28)   Average length of tenancy for existing tenants.
            (29)   Estimated schedule for conversion.
            (30)   Estimated price range of converted units.
            (31)   List of improvements contemplated.
            (32)   Copy of proposed CC&Rs.
            (33)   Estimate of available similar housing in the area.

      7.   Churches, schools, libraries, museums and art galleries, parks,
playgrounds, community centers, cemeteries, public services, utility buildings.

For purpose hereof, such parking lot or lots shall not be deemed "immediately
adjacent to and abutting" if a street or alley lies between such parking lot or

Furthermore, such special use shall be limited solely to the existing owners of

liquor license shall be issued or renewed for any applicant or entitled to be
held by any city liquor license holder concerning any such restaurant, club,
reception hall, or banquet hall business until and unless the applicant for
such liquor license, the liquor license holder, and such business each
qualifies at all times for the issuance, maintenance, or renewal of a city
liquor license and such business is conducted in accordance with all
requirements and conditions of the city council, the plan commission, this
code, and with Illinois law.
All business or advertising signs or signage for each authorized and approved
special use shall conform to the following requirements: a) the illumination of
all signs or signage shall be diffused or indirect and shall be arranged so as
not to reflect direct rays of light or illumination into any adjacent
residential property located in an R-1 or R-2 district or into the public way;
and b) any sign or signage located in the direct line of any traffic control
signal shall not have flashing, intermittent red, green or amber illumination.
(Ord. 3716, 7-20-2015)
   B.   Change Of Special Use: No special use shall be changed except by
authorization of the city council after a public hearing and recommendation by
the plan commission.
   C.   Termination Of Special Use: Special uses as described herein shall
terminate if not used for a period of twelve (12) months. (Ord. 1793, 2-7-1977;
amd. Ord. 3910, 9-3-2019)

   B.   Yards: All structures to be constructed, altered or moved in the R-

      2.   Side Yards: Five feet (5') minimum, one side yard; twelve feet (12')

the principal building located on the same lot.
